column1: When Angel Amankwaah traveled from Denver to North Carolina Central University for incoming student orientation this summer
column2: she decided she had made the right choice.

column1: She had fun learning the chants that fans perform at football games. But she also saw that “there are students who look like me
column2: and professors who look like me” at the historically Black university
column3: said Amankwaah
column5: who is Black. “I knew that I was in a safe space.”

column1: This has in the past two years become an important consideration for college-bound students from all backgrounds and beliefs. With so much attention focused on these issues
column2: USA TODAY and The Hechinger Report present the first-of-its-kind College Welcome Guide showing state laws and institutional policies that affect college and university students
column3: from bans on diversity
column4: equity and inclusion initiatives and “critical race theory” to rules about guns on campus and whether student IDs are accepted as proof of residency for voting purposes.

column1: The digital tables also list
column2: for every four-year institution in the country
column3: such things as racial and gender diversity among students and faculty
column4: the number of student veterans enrolled
column5: the incidence of on-campus race-motivated hate crimes
column6: free-speech rankings and if the university or college serves many students from rural places.

column1: Test our new College Welcome Guide:These tools offer a new lens on campus life.
Students have long picked schools based on their academic reputations and social life. But with campuses in the crosshairs of the culture wars
column2: many students are now also taking stock of attacks on diversity
column3: course content and speech and speakers from both ends of the political spectrum. They’re monitoring hate crimes
column4: anti-LGBTQ+ legislation
column5: state abortion laws and whether students like them ‒ Black
column6: rural
column7: military veterans
column8: LGBTQ+ or from other backgrounds ‒ are represented and supported on campus.

column1: “There’s no question that what’s happening at the state level is directly affecting these students
column2: ” said Alyse Levine
column3: founder and CEO of Premium Prep
column4: a private college admissions consulting firm in Chapel Hill
column5: North Carolina. When they look at colleges in various states now
column6: she said
column7: “There are students who are asking
column8: ‘Am I really wanted here?’”

column1: For some students on both sides of the political divide
column2: the answer is no. In the chaotic new world of American colleges and universities
column3: many say they feel unwelcome at certain schools
column4: while others are prepared to shut down speakers and report faculty with whose opinions they disagree.

column1: It’s too early to know how much this trend will affect where and whether prospective students end up going to college since publicly available enrollment data lags real time. But there are early clues that it’s having a significant impact.
One in 4 prospective students has already ruled out a college or university for consideration because of the political climate in its state
column2: according to a survey by the higher education consulting firm Art & Science Group.

column1: Among students who describe themselves as liberal
column2: the most common reason to rule out colleges and universities in a particular state
column3: that survey found
column4: is because it’s “too Republican” or has what they consider lax gun regulations
column5: anti-LGBTQ+ legislation
column6: restrictive abortion laws and a lack of concern about racism. Students who describe themselves as conservative are rejecting states they believe to be “too Democrat” and that have liberal abortion and gay rights laws.

column1: Sixty percent of prospective students of all backgrounds say new state restrictions on abortion would at least somewhat influence where they choose to go to college
column2: a separate poll by Gallup and the Lumina Foundation found. Of these
column3: 8 in 10 say they would prefer to go to a state with greater access to reproductive health services. (Lumina is among the funders of The Hechinger Report
column4: which produced this story.)

column1: “We have many young women who will not look at certain states
column2: ” said Levine. One of her own clients backed out of going to a university in St. Louis after Missouri banned almost all abortions following the Supreme Court’s Dobbs decision
column3: she said.

column1: Institutions in Alabama
column2: Florida
column3: Louisiana and Texas are the most likely to be knocked off the lists of liberal students
column4: according to the Art & Science Group survey. They’re generally most likely to steer clear of the South and Midwest
column5: while conservative students avoid California and New York.

column1: One in 8 high school students in Florida say they won’t go to a public university in their own state because of its education policies
column2: a separate poll
column3: by the college ranking and information website Intelligent.com
column4: found.

column1: With 494 anti-LGBTQ+ laws proposed or adopted this year
column2: according to the American Civil Liberties Union
column3: prospective students who are LGBTQ+ and have experienced significant harassment because of it are nearly twice as likely to say they don't plan to go to college at all compared with students who experienced lower levels of harassment
column4: according to a survey by GLSEN
column5: formerly the Gay
column6: Lesbian and Straight Education Network.

column1: “You are attacking kids who are already vulnerable
column2: ” said Javier Gomez
column3: an LGBTQ+ student in his first year at Miami Dade College. “And it’s not just queer students. So many young people are fed up.”

column1: It’s not yet evident whether the new laws are affecting where LGBTQ+ young people are choosing to go to college
column2: said Casey Pick
column3: director of law and policy at The Trevor Project
column4: which supports LGBTQ+ young people in crisis. But LGBTQ+ adults are moving away from states passing anti-LGBTQ+ laws
column5: she said. And “if adult employees are taking this into account when they decide where they want to live
column6: you can bet that college students are making the same decisions.”

column1: Since DeSantis takeover
column2: surge in dropouts at New College of Florida

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in an era of pushback against diversity
column3: equity and inclusion policies in many states
column4: and against affirmative action in college admissions nationwide
column5: Amankwaah is one of a growing number of Black students choosing what they see as the relative security of an HBCU. Enrollment at HBCUs increased by around 3% in 2021
column6: the last year for which the figure is available
column7: while the number of students at other universities and colleges fell.

column1: “The real attack here is on the feeling of belonging
column2: ” said Jeremy Young
column3: who directs the Freedom to Learn program at PEN America
column4: which tracks laws that restrict college and university diversity efforts and teaching about race. “What it really does is hoist a flag to say to the most marginalized students
column5: ‘We don’t want you here.’”

column1: More than 40% of university and college administrators say the Supreme Court ruling curbing the use of affirmative action in admissions will affect diversity on their campuses
column2: a Princeton Review poll found as the school year was beginning.

column1: College students of all races and political persuasions report feeling uncomfortable on campuses that have become political battlegrounds. Those on the left are bristling at new laws blocking programs in diversity
column2: equity and inclusion and the teaching of certain perspectives about race; on the right
column3: at conservative speakers being shouted down or canceled
column4: unpopular comments being called out in class and what they see as an embrace of values different from what they learned at home.

column1: More than 1 in 10 students at four-year universities now say they feel as if they downright don’t belong on their campus
column2: and another 2 in 10 neither agree nor strongly agree that they belong
column3: another Lumina and Gallup survey found. It found that those who answer in these ways are more likely to frequently experience stress and more likely to drop out.

column1: Military veterans who use their GI Bill benefits to return to school say one of their most significant barriers is a feeling that they won’t be welcome
column2: a survey by the D’Aniello Institute for Veterans and Military Families at Syracuse University found. Nearly two-thirds say that faculty and administrators don’t understand the challenges they face
column3: and 70% say the same thing about their non-veteran classmates.

column1: Colleges should be “safe and affirming spaces
column2: ” said Pick
column3: of the Trevor Project ‒ not places of isolation and alienation.

column1: Yet a significant number of students say they don’t feel comfortable sharing their views in class
column2: according to another survey
column3: conducted by College Pulse for the right-leaning Sheila and Robert Challey Institute for Global Innovation and Growth at North Dakota State University. Of those
column4: 72% say they worry their opinions would be considered unacceptable by classmates and 45%
column5: by their professors. Conservative students are less likely than their liberal classmates to believe that all points of view are welcome and less willing to share theirs.

column1: “Is that really an intellectually diverse environment?” asked Sean Stevens
column2: director of polling and analytics at the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression
column3: or FIRE
column4: which has launched a campus free-speech ranking based on students’ perceptions of comfort expressing ideas
column5: tolerance for speakers and other measures.

column1: “Anecdotally and from personal experience
column2: there’s certainly a pocket of students who are weighing these factors in terms of where to go to college
column3: ” Stevens said.

column1: Eighty-one percent of liberal students and 53% of conservative ones say they support reporting faculty who make comments that they find offensive
column2: the same survey found. It used sample comments such as
column3: “There is no evidence of anti-Black bias in police shootings
column4: ” “Requiring vaccination for COVID is an assault on individual freedom” and “Biological sex is a scientific fact.”

column1: A professor at Texas A&M University became the subject of an investigation when a student accused her of criticizing the state’s lieutenant governor during a lecture
column2: though she was ultimately exonerated. An anthropology lecturer at the University of Chicago who taught an undergraduate course called “The Problem of Whiteness” said she was deluged with hateful messages when a conservative student posted her photo and email address on social media.

column1: More than half of all freshmen say that colleges have the right to ban extreme speakers
column2: according to an annual survey by an institute at the University of California
column3: Los Angeles; the College Pulse poll says that sentiment is held by twice the proportion of liberal students as conservative ones.

column1: A group of Stanford students in March disrupted an on-campus speech by a federal judge whose judicial record they said was anti-LGBTQ+. When he asked for an administrator to intervene
column2: an associate dean for diversity
column3: equity and inclusion confronted him and asked: “Is it worth the pain that this causes and the division that this causes?” The associate dean was put on leave and later resigned.

column1: “Today it is a sad fact that the greatest threat to free speech comes from within the academy
column2: ” pronounced the right-leaning American Council of Trustees and Alumni
column3: which is pushing colleges to sign on to its Campus Freedom Initiative that encourages teaching students about free expression during freshman orientation and disciplining people who disrupt speakers or events
column4: among other measures.

column1: “I have to imagine that universities that have a bad track record on freedom of expression or academic freedom
column2: that it will affect their reputations
column3: ” said Steven Maguire
column4: the organization’s campus freedom fellow. “I do hear people saying things like
column5: ‘I’m worried about what kind of a college or university I can send my kids to and whether they’ll be free to be themselves and to express themselves.’”

column1: Some colleges are now actively recruiting students on the basis of these kinds of concerns. Colorado College in September created a program to ease the process for students who want to transfer away from institutions in states that have banned diversity
column2: equity and inclusion initiatives; Hampshire College in Massachusetts has offered admission to any student from New College in Florida
column3: subject of what critics have described as a conservative takeover. Thirty-five have so far accepted the invitation.

column1: Though many conservative critics of colleges and universities say faculty are indoctrinating students with liberal opinions
column2: incoming freshmen tend to hold left-leaning views before they ever set foot in a classroom
column3: according to that UCLA survey.

column1: Fewer than 1 in 5 consider themselves conservative. Three-quarters say abortion should be legal and favor stricter gun control laws
column2: 68% say wealthy people should pay more taxes than they do now and 86% that climate change should be a federal priority and that there should be a clear path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.

column1: Prospective students say they are watching as new laws are passed and controversies erupt on campuses and actively looking into not just the quality of food and available majors at the colleges they might attend
column2: but state politics.

column1: “Once I decided I was going to North Carolina Central
column2: I looked up whether North Carolina was a red state or a blue state
column3: ” Amankwaah said. (North Carolina has a Democrat as governor but Republicans control both chambers of the legislature and hold a veto-proof supermajority in the state Senate.

column1: Florida’s anti-LGBTQ+ laws prompted Javier Gomez to leave his native state and move to New York to go to fashion school. But then he came back
column2: transferring to Miami Dade.

column1: “People ask me
column2: ‘Why the hell are you back in Florida?’” said Gomez. “The reason I came back was that there was this innate calling in me that you have to stick around and fight for the queer and trans kids here. It’s overwhelming at times. It can be very mentally depleting. But I wanted to stay and continue the fight and build community against hatred.”

column1: Thousands of Israelis and Palestinians have been killed and Palestinians have been ordered to evacuate from the northern Gaza Strip ahead of Israel's impending ground invasion
column2: leading to a humanitarian crisis that has brought protests from the United Nations and around the world.

column1: The U.N. said about 1 million Gaza residents have been displaced in just a week
column2: about half of them finding refuge in U.N. schools and other facilities where water supplies are diminishing. The war has claimed more than 4
column3: 000 lives since Hamas launched an unprecedented surprise attack Oct. 7.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the World Health Organization pleaded with Israel on Sunday to immediately reverse evacuation orders for hospitals in northern Gaza
column3: saying the deadlines are impossible to meet and risk additional loss of life. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned that attacks on health care facilities are already causing deaths and injuries.

column1: The health situation in north Gaza is dire, Tedros wrote on social media. "Evacuation orders by Israel to hospitals are practically impossible to implement and are a death sentence for the sick and injured."
Here are several organizations that are providing aid to people caught in the conflict.

column2: Gaza are graphic
column3: but some can't look away

column1: The Alliance for Middle East Peace (ALLMEP) is a coalition of more than 170 nongovernmental organizations that includes tens of thousands of Palestinians and Israelis who share the goal of building peace between the two communities.

Our members are speaking loudly and clearly about the values that unite our community: Opposition to this horrific violence, and a commitment to Israeli/Palestinian partnership on the path to ending it, and achieving peace and equality, the agency said in a statement.

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is a humanitarian organization that aims to protect and aid victims of conflicts. The ICRC has been in Israel and the occupied territories since 1967. The organization is asking for donations to improve access to essential services like water and to support livelihood projects.
Doctors Without Borders is a nongovernmental organization that describes itself as an "independent
column2: impartial and neutral" charity that provides humanitarian aid to people affected by conflict
column3: disease outbreaks and natural and human-made disasters.

column1: The agency is seeking donations to continue to provide medical care in the area. The agency has reported overcrowding in hospitals
column2: a lack of medical supplies
column3: and dangerous working conditions as it tries to support the thousands injured by the fighting.

column1: UNRWA has designated shelters to host the estimated 127
column2: 000 people displaced in Gaza. The agency is seeking donations to support its work.

column1: The Jewish Agency for Israel North American Council
column2: an American charity organization
column3: is accepting donations to help victims of terrorism.

column1: Save the Children issued an emergency alert in response to the conflict
column2: noting that escalating violence has left 1.2 million children in need of humanitarian aid. The agency is accepting donations.

column1: National and international organizations that aid victims in the conflict include the Palestine Children's Relief Fund (PCRF)
column2: which works to provide lifesaving medical relief and humanitarian aid.

column1: Founded by former President Jimmy Carter and his wife

column3: in partnership with Emory University
column4: The Carter Center is a humanitarian aid organization that has been promoting peace and a viable two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for decades.

column1: WASHINGTON — President Joe Biden urged Americans in an Oval Office address on Thursday evening to stand with Ukraine and Israel
column2: arguing that U.S. leadership abroad and congressional aid to both countries is essential.

column1: Biden sought to drive home the value of continued U.S. support for the close allies to a war-weary public less than a day after his visit Israel to meet with the country's prime minister. He pressed for the release of hostages that are being held by Hamas and connected the militant group's assault on Israel to Russian President Vladimir Putin's war against Ukraine.
Hamas and Putin represent different threats, but they share this in common: they both want to completely annihilate a neighboring democracy, Biden said.
He added
column2: "I know these conflicts can seem far away
column3: and it's natural to ask
column4: why does this matter to America."

column1: Speaking from behind the Resolute Desk
column2: the U.S. president said it is vital to America's national security to prevent dictators and terrorists from spreading chaos and destruction.

column1: They keep going. And the cost and the threats to America and the world keep rising, Biden said. "If we don't stop Putin's appetite for power and control in Ukraine
column2: he won't limit himself to just Ukraine."

column1: Biden will detail a request to Congress on Friday to pay for more weapons for Ukraine
column2: buy new equipment for the American military to replace what it has sent Kyiv and replenish the Iron Dome air defense system that protects Israel.

column1: Biden plans to request more than $98 billion in emergency funding for the wars in Israel and Ukraine
column2: U.S. border security and other international crises
column3: according to a source familiar with the funding request who asked for anonymity because they are not authorized to speak publicly.

column1: The source said Biden wants $60 billion for the war in Ukraine
column2: with half of the money going toward replenishing U.S. military stockpiles. Biden is also seeking $14 billion for Israel and $14 billion for the U.S. border as part of the request
column3: which also includes money for the Indo-Pacific and $10 billion for humanitarian assistance.

column1: Biden made the case for the request during a primetime address from the White House. It was only his second speech from the Oval Office as commander-in-chief. The ask amends Biden's previous supplemental request to Congress for more money for the U.S. border and Ukraine's counteroffensive against Russia.
His speech follows a visit to Tel Aviv
column2: during which he told Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that the U.S. would make sure sure that the ally has what it needs to defend itself against future attacks.

column1: He arrived at the White House early Thursday morning and spoke with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy later in the day.
Earlier this week
column2: long-range missiles that Ukraine had been requesting from the Biden administration showed up on the battlefield in Russian-held territory inside of Ukraine. The U.S. secretly supplied to weapons to Ukraine after Zelenskyy's visit to Washington last month.

column1: As he flew back from Israel
column2: the White House said Biden would make a rare address to the nation on Thursday that outlined the U.S. response to both conflicts. His first Oval Office address came in June after he reached a deal with Congress to avert a default on the nation's debt.

column1: Biden's latest funding request pairs money for Ukraine with assistance to Israel

column1: The terrorist group Hamas unleashed pure unadulterated evil in the world, but sadly the Jewish people know perhaps better than anyone that there is no limit to the depravity of people when they want to inflict pain on others, Biden said.

Getting an aid package through Congress could be an uphill climb

column1: The chamber has been without a speaker for 16 days since lawmakers ousted Rep. Kevin McCarthy

column1: Further complicating matters: a possible government shutdown in mid-November. A temporary funding bill that has kept government agencies running expires on Nov. 17. Lawmakers must pass another funding bill by then or all government functions will cease except those deemed necessary.

column1: Two weeks into the conflict that began when members of Hamas massacred civilians in rural communities and at a music festival on Israel's border with the Gaza Strip
column2: Israelis and Palestinians have been collecting

column4: unpredictable and dangerous circumstances.

column2: where some 1
column3: 400 civilians and soldiers have died and where all Jews are by religious tenet supposed to be buried immediately after death − a few days at most − this has involved emergency responders going to great lengths to recover victims which they have discovered in scenes of unspeakable horror

column1: 'I won't condemn Hamas':Some Palestinians find it hard to denounce attacks on Israel
I'm not eating. I'm not sleeping, said Israeli search and rescue volunteer Yossi Landau
column3: as he struggled not to weep Wednesday recounting some of what he witnessed in villages in southern Israel in the immediate aftermath of the nation's deadliest ever attack.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in Gaza
column3: photographer Ali Jadallah said "we have reached a catastrophic situation
column4:
where Israel's bombs are killing scores of Palestinian families − sometimes entombing them in their collapsed homes; sometimes leaving their mutilated bodies scattered among the ruins.
On both sides of the Israel-Gaza border, faith traditions define the rules of burial. For Jews, who believe the dead must be watched until buried, and that every part of a body must be buried, the idea of an unguarded corpse is an almost unthinkable lapse. Within the Muslim tradition, the body is wrapped in a shroud and the head is positioned to face Mecca with the eyes and mouth closed.
Jadallah said he's lost nine family members to Israeli airstrikes, according to updates he's been posting on his Instagram account. He filmed himself this week as he was driving in his car. Across the back seat his father, killed in one of those Israeli strikes, lay dead.

he said.
I'm taking him alone (to bury him). I know people can't attend the funeral. No one can. But please pray for him. He was a decent and beloved man."

column2: Landau works for ZAKA
column3: a volunteer organization whose members are almost all ultra-orthodox Jews. Its mission is to collect the remains of the dead

column5: so they can be buried in accordance with Jewish religious law.

column1: For the past three decades
column2: Landau has deployed for ZAKA all over the world. He was in New York during the 9/11 attacks. He has responded to natural disasters in India. He has rushed many times to the scene of suicide bombings to collect body parts.

column1: He helped recover the dead in Surfside

column3: when a 12-story condominium building collapsed early in the morning of June 24

Yet Landau said that what he encountered in several of the kibbutzim that dot the frontlines where Israeli civilians and soldiers were killed by Hamas on Oct. 7 was more than he could bear.
I broke. I blanked out, he said.
Landau said that in one home
column2: in Kibbutz Be'eri
column3: he saw small children as young as six with their hands tied behind their back in the same room where their parents were also executed. They were missing fingers and eyes. In another home
column4: he found a pregnant woman lying face down in a pool of blood. When Landau and other ZAKA volunteers turned the woman over
column5: they found her belly had been "butchered open" and the unborn child connected to her had been stabbed.

column1: I don't know if you know − and you should never know − what it means to separate parts of a burned body, he said

column1: The killing scenes Landau described were corroborated by half a dozen other ZAKA volunteers who were present in Be'eri and elsewhere with him as part of their emergency response.

column2: and a USA TODAY review of government documents and court records

Israel Defense Forces Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Herzi Halevi said Oct. 12 in his first public statement since the war began. “We will attack them, we will dismantle them, dismantle their system.” 
Arouri lacks the same profile. One of his current titles is deputy chief of Hamas’ political bureau, but sources say Arouri’s role in Hamas has become much more prominent than that. In addition to still playing a role in the Qassam Brigades, Arouri has spent years helping rebuild Hamas operations in the other Palestinian territory blockaded by Israel, the West Bank, according to former Israeli and U.S. counterterrorism officials who have tracked him.  
And, they say, he acts as a chief deputy of sorts to Ismail Haniyeh, one of several Hamas leaders based in Qatar as they try to do political outreach for the group, including to Iran and Hezbollah. 
Five days after the attacks, Arouri offered Al Jazeera Arabic some of the first inside details about the operation, including how 1,200 members of the Qassam Brigades had been given “detailed instructions” about their targets, the Israeli military’s Gaza Brigade, just across the border from the Gaza Strip. 
“We were surprised that the Gaza Brigade collapsed in less than three hours, faster than we expected,” Arouri said.  
Officially, Iran has denied playing a role in the attack even as it congratulates Hamas. President Joe Biden told 60 Minutes on Oct. 15 that there’s no evidence “at this point” that Iran was behind the attack. Israeli officials have made similar comments, stressing that the investigation is in its early stages. 
But U.S. and Israeli intelligence analysts say that if anyone could give the group the ability to launch such stunning land, air and sea attacks against the Israeli military, it would be Iran and its Revolutionary Guard. Even as the hunt for Arouri continued this week, Iran and Hezbollah both raised prospects of openly entering the conflict to respond to Israel’s strikes at Gaza. 
Arouri’s role as an alliance-builder among terrorist organizations has been known to Israel since at least 2018. And his role in raising money and plotting terrorist attacks for Hamas has been known to both governments for a generation.
“It's not just the guys who pulled the trigger or approved the battle plan or gave the final order to do it but the people who are directing all of the strategy and really promoting the (anti-Israel) militarism,” said former FBI counterterrorism analyst and U.S. Treasury terror finance official Matthew Levitt. “And that's Saleh al-Arouri.” 
Yet he has evaded authorities for years.  
“He knows that if he steps anywhere close, we will kill him,” a former top Israeli intelligence official until earlier this year told USA TODAY. He was on the run. You can imagine that there were several plans regarding that
column6: but it just didn't happen.”

Janita “Gigi” Hayes first started using hair straightener as a child because it made her feel prettier. As she got older
column2: Hayes
column3: who is Black
column4: continued to turn to them because she felt employers perceived her as more professional when her hair was straight.

column1: Now
column2: Hayes is one of thousands of women who blame hair straightening products for damaging her reproductive health and is among those suing their manufacturers. She said she believes long-term use of the products caused her to develop uterine fibroids
column3: a condition that forced her to undergo a hysterectomy.

column1: “I never realized that long term use would affect me like this ... my body is changed forever
column2: said Hayes, 41, of Birmingham, Alabama. I no longer have the parts that I was born with. The confidence that I had as a woman is no longer there.”

column1: This week
column2: the FDA said it will investigate the products
column3: which research has connected to an increased risk of some types of cancer.

column4: ” he said.

column1: The FDA proposed a rule that would ban formaldehyde and other formaldehyde-releasing chemicals from being used in hair-smoothing and straightening products sold in the United States. The products have been used most extensively by Black women.
On hair treatments
column2: the ingredients show up as formaldehyde
column3: formalin or methylene glycol
column4: according to the FDA
column5: and are found in some hair relaxers and keratin treatment products.

column1: Using the chemicals has been linked to long-term health concerns

column3: and can cause short-term risks such as breathing problems
column4: the agency said.

column1: Cancer concerns:FDA proposes ban on hair-straightening

column1: The FDA is soliciting public comment about the proposal

column3: though some have been as short as 10 days or as long as nine months.

column1: If the agency issues a final rule
column2: it is published in the Federal Register along with an explanation of regulatory requirements
column3: the industrial impact of those requirements and any response to public comments. The regulatory requirements also are published under Title 21 of the Code of Federal Regulations.

If the administration moves forward with its proposal
column2: Pitts said the products could be removed from shelves within days

column4: he said.

column1: Links between hair dye and chemical straighteners and an increased risk of breast cancer were made in a 2019 study published in the International Journal of Cancer.

column5: D-Ohio
column6: wrote a letter to FDA Commissioner Robert Califf asking the agency to investigate the matter.

column1: We urge the FDA to investigate the potential health threat posed by chemical hair straightening products, the letter said. "Consumers need to be reassured that the cosmetic products they use do not threaten their health. It is critical that the agency act quickly to address these legitimate concerns."
Pressley called the FDA's proposed rule a win for public health "especially the health of Black women
column2: who are disproportionately put at risk by these products as a result of systemic racism and anti-Black hair sentiment.”

column1: Over time
column2: some women who once felt reliant on the hair relaxers and straightening products gave them up
column3: said Sam Ennon
column5: of San Mateo
column6: California
column7: in part because they can cause breakage and bald spots
column8: and in part because society became somewhat more accepting of Black women’s natural hair.

column1: Ennon
column2: the founder and president of the Black-owned Beauty Supply Association
column3: said he’s been working in the cosmetics industry for 20 years
column4: including stints at Clairol and Worlds of Curls.

column1: He said hair straightening tools
column2: such as an electronic flat iron or hot combs
column3: can achieve similar looks
column4: though they don’t last as long as relaxers do.

column1: After she had uterine fibroids surgically removed
column2: Brown
column3: the congresswoman from Ohio
column4: said she no longer relaxes her hair and wears wigs or braids instead.

column1: “We are
column2: as Black women
column3: under a lot of pressure to wear our hair a certain way
column4: ” she said.

column1: Proposed federal legislation called the CROWN Act
column2: versions of which have been adopted by several states
column3: would prohibit discriminating against a person for their hair or hairstyle based on race or national origin. A federal bill
column4: sponsored by Rep. Bonnie Coleman
column5: D-N.J.
column6: passed in the House in 2022 but has not been reintroduced this session of Congress.

column1: Brown was among the bill’s sponsors.
“I wear my hair in braids
column2: ” she said. “That was something important for me to put on display because of the public pressure many Black women receive to wear their hair.”

column1: ARLINGTON
column2: Texas – Postseason baseball is not supposed to be like this.

column1: In a sport where you can’t simply go one-on-one
column2: where a pitcher may simply choose not to throw you the ball in a spot you can hit it
column3: where solid contact and 100-mph line drives are no guarantee of success
column4: one player cannot determine the outcome of a game
column5: the fate of a team.

column1: Yet night after night
column2: series after series and now year after year
column3: Yordan Alvarez is the body around which the Houston Astros rotate
column4: digging them out after they fall into a hole
column5: influencing outcomes even when he’s two
column6: three or four spots away in the lineup.

column1: They are now two games away from a third consecutive World Series appearance and six victories away from defending their championship after a 10-3 thrashing of the Texas Rangers in Game 4 of the American League Championship Series
column2: a win that squared the ALCS at two games apiece.

column1: The heroes were many: Jose Altuve got his flowers
column2: celebrated for playing in his 100th postseason game and characteristically banging out three hits. Alex Bregman got the party started
column3: a two-run
column4: first-inning triple igniting a team-wide strafing of the Rangers’ pitching staff.

column1: FOLLOW THE MONEY: MLB player salaries and payrolls for every major league team
And Jose Abreu
column2: a first-year Astro
column3: administered the kill shot
column4: a three-run home run that put the Rangers to sleep.

column1: It is Alvarez
column2: though
column3: who is bracketed by Bregman and Abreu in the lineup
column4: who banged out two more hits
column5: drove in three more runs and broke a tie by hitting a ball 411 feet for a sacrifice fly
column6: a plate appearance that was the baseball equivalent of a crushing lead block that enabled Abreu to waltz into the end zone.

column1: In eight postseason games
column2: Alvarez is now batting .419 (13 for 31)
column3: reaching base at a .471 clip
column4: and has driven in 13 runs. It won’t appear on his playoff game log
column5: but let the record reflect that the hitters in front and behind him in the lineup combined to drive in five runs.

column1: And after getting shut out 2-0 in Game 1 of this ALCS
column2: the Astros have scored four
column3: eight and 10 runs in their next three games. The swagger is back
column4: largely because of their cleanup hitter who often moves in silence but might give Bryce Harper a run as the most impactful hitter in the game.

column1: “Alvarez is on fire right now. And he’s the best hitter in the world
column2: ” says outfielder Chas McCormick
column3: whose third career postseason home run gave Houston a 9-3 lead. “So when our guy’s going
column4: and we get Altuve going and Jose Abreu going
column5: we’re one of the best teams in the world.

column1: “Having Alvarez hit like he’s been hitting
column2: nothing can stop us right now.”

column1: Thursday’s action offered plenty of evidence.
For both teams
column2: Game 4 was the get-through game: No Justin Verlander
column3: no Max Scherzer or Nathan Eovaldi or Framber Valdez on the hill. It figured that itinerant starters Andrew Heaney and Jose Urquidy would give way to a bullpen battle
column4: and by the fourth inning
column5: it was 3-3 and those fellows were footnotes.

column1: Dane Dunning
column2: Heaney’s capable piggyback partner
column3: started the inning issuing two walks and a single
column4: and after striking out Alex Bregman
column5: was not going to face Alvarez with the bases loaded.

column1: So Cody Bradford
column2: a soft-throwing but deceptive rookie lefty
column3: was summoned for the impossible task. Bradford was unscored upon in 4⅓ playoff innings this year. But Alvarez was a different ask.

column1: They battled for nine pitches
column2: Alvarez fouling off four pitches
column3: fastballs at 91 and changeups far slower than that
column4: before Bradford finally left one in the zone.

column1: Alvarez clubbed it just to the right of dead center field
column2: 111 mph off his bat and looking for all the world like it was his seventh homer in eight games this postseason. Bradford backpedaled and looked
column3: hoping for the best. The ball went 401 feet and would have been a grand slam in 17 of 30 ballparks
column4: according to Statcast.

column1: In this one
column2: it was a go-ahead sacrifice fly.

column1: Yet for Rangers manager Bruce Bochy
column2: Alvarez was the focal point of the sequence. The three-batter minimum ensured Bradford would have to face Abreu
column3: too.

column1: And if Alvarez was pounding away and softening up a piece of red meat
column2: it was Abreu who got to eat.

column1: He pummeled a Bradford fastball
column2: a low screamer that eventually rose over the Astros bullpen and the first layer of seats
column3: landing in the second level of Globe Life Field. It was 7-3 Houston.

column1: “Yordan's hit two balls 111 to center field that haven't been homers. It’s crazy
column2: ” says Bregman
column3: recalling a similar shot in Game 3 that center fielder Leody Taveras brought back over the fence to rob a home run. “I've never seen it before in my life. And for him to come through like that time and time again for us
column4: it's huge.

column1: “And then Abreu coming up with another big swing
column2: it was massive for our team.”

column1: You’d think Abreu had the best job in baseball
column2: hitting behind Alvarez
column3: but the year has at times been a struggle for the White Sox legend. He’s found a groove in October
column4: hitting four home runs
column5: three of them at least 430 feet.

column1: Even if there’s not much on the table when he comes up.
“It’s been difficult at times
column2: I’m not going to lie
column3: ” says Abreu through a team translator. “The most important things are the victories. If we keep getting the victories
column4: I’ll continue hitting there.”

column1: Um
column2: why is it so difficult?

column1: “He drives in all the runs.”
When told of his Cuban countryman’s gripe
column2: Alvarez allowed a little grin.

column1: “Like I always say
column2: if they leave a pitch over the middle of the plate
column3: and I’m able to make contact
column4: I’m going to try to drive them in
column5: ” he says. “Both of us couldn’t have missed (Bradford). I couldn’t get it done.”

column1: OK
column2: so sometimes he’s pretty modest. But he does have his pride
column3: and a good memory. When asked if this October was his most locked-in
column4: he offered a mild rebuttal.

column1: “I don’t know. I think 2021 was also pretty interesting
column2: ” he said
column3: to the laughter of onlookers.

column1: That’s fair. Alvarez posted a .315 average and 1.049 OPS and the Astros reached Game 6 of the World Series before falling to the Atlanta Braves. And 2022 wasn’t too bad.

Who could forget his two ninth-inning home runs to almost singlehandedly knock Seattle out of the AL Division Series? Or his gargantuan go-ahead home run off Jose Alvarado in the sixth inning of Game 6 of the World Series
column2: a shot that made it rain champagne hours later?

column1: But he batted .192 last postseason
column2: drawing six walks to 16 strikeouts. Yet even at his less than best
column3: he had a massive impact on Houston’s championship.

column1: As for this year?
“He’s the best hitter in the game
column2: hands down. He does that every day
column3: ” says center fielder Mauricio Dubon
column4: who had five hits in nine at-bats in Games 3 and 4. “It’s a little bit more magnified because it’s the postseason. But he does that every day.

column1: “He can beat you with a single to left field
column2: or he can put it 460 feet dead center. Not many guys can do that. It’s crazy. The other team doesn’t want you to beat him.

column1: “At the same time
column2: it’s inevitable.”

column1: It’s starting to feel that way
column2: even if Alvarez
column4: strangely slips under the radar. The loudest boos during pregame introductions here are for Altuve and Bregman
column5: members of the Astros teams who partook in the 2017-18 sign-stealing scheme.

column1: Yet the Rangers were terrible those years. You’d think the guy squeezing the life out of their 90-win team
column2: unsullied by scandal
column3: might attract more enmity.

column1: Oh
column2: well. The Astros
column3: now in their seventh consecutive ALCS
column4: have responded as both internal and external observers believed – very much alive and likely now the favorites to win two of these final three games.

column1: “When you give hope to the Houston Astros and some fuel
column2: some adversity too
column3: we take that really well
column4: ” says McCormick. “We had a huge amount of confidence coming here.”

column1: It’s only growing. Four relievers covered the final 6⅔ innings
column2: with high-leverage stars Hector Neris
column3: Bryan Abreu and Ryan Pressly getting a needed night off. Justin Verlander will pitch Game 5. And the Astros have outscored the Rangers 57-18 the past five games at Globe Life.

column1: They’ll also have the best player on the field
column2: perhaps any field
column3: batting cleanup.

column1: “You can’t pitch around him because there’s danger in front of him
column2: ” says Game 4 winning pitcher Ryne Stanek
column3: “and danger behind him. You’ve got to pitch to everybody.”

column1: No
column2: Alvarez is not a one-man team. Just one man who influences outcomes like few before him.

column1: NEW YORK – The Rolling Stones will not go quietly.
Nearly 60 years since dropping their blues-steeped debut
column2: the legendary rock band rooted by Mick Jagger and Keith Richards continues to make a glorious noise
column3: continues to pique our attention with every utterance of a new tour and
column4: simply
column5: continues to matter.

column1: The band’s latest album
column2: “Hackney Diamonds
column3: ” their first new material since 2005’s “A Bigger Bang
column4: ” arrived Friday.

column1: But a few hours before the clock struck midnight
column2: the Rolling Stones roared through a seven-song set that blurred the lines between vintage and fresh – the the dozen tracks on “Hackney” really are that robust – at an invite-only club show at Racket NYC.

column1: “Yes
column2: yes
column3: yes
column4: ” Jagger uttered as he roamed the corners of the small stage to greet the crowd of about 650 before offering a sly smile. “We’re gonna play some old
column5: and we’re gonna play some new.”

column1: More:Inside Rolling Stones 'Hackney Diamonds' London album party with Fallon
column2: Sydney Sweeney

column1: What Jagger didn’t mention was the band was going to welcome a surprise guest to close their set – and really
column2: how could there not be something special at a show this intimate? – in the form of an absolutely kinetic Lady Gaga
column3: who performs on “Hackney.”

column1: The groove-infested “Shattered
column2: ” their 1978 seedy ode to New York
column3: proved the ideal opener for the night. Jagger
column4: his vocal delivery as elastic as his facial expressions
column5: slithered between Ronnie Wood and Richards
column6: his feet following his hips
column7: as he spat the lyrics “pride and joy and greed and sex
column8: that's what makes our town the best” and the famous aside
column9: “shadoobie.”

column1: But first Jagger
column2: Richards
column3: Wood
column4: longtime bassist Darryl Jones
column5: drummer Steve Jordan (who took the seat of the late Charlie Watts in 2021)
column6: keyboardist Matt Clifford and singer Chanel Haynes had a few other tunes to unleash.

column1: Seesawing between classic and new
column2: the band stomped through the staccato rocker “Angry
column3: ” the Stones-iest Stones song in decades. Richards
column4: all scarves and bandannas
column5: ripped out the instant classic riff
column6: filling in the notes between Jones’ rumbling bass lines.

column1: Everyone on stage appeared to be steeped in joy. Wood
column2: who has endured a few recent bouts of cancer
column3: grinned as he stepped up to solo during “Whole Wide World
column4: ” while Jones thundered behind his kit
column5: already a master at Watts’ signature playing style of never hitting the high hat and snare drum simultaneously. (Watts played on two songs on “Hackney Diamonds” – “Live By the Sword” and “Mess It Up.")

column1: Jagger
column2: as if it needs to be said
column3: remains an indefatigable wonder at 80
column4: his moves a blend of peacock strutting and karate chopping
column5: his voice as distinctive and grainy as ever.

column1: While the turbo-charged newcomer “Bite My Head Off” (featuring Paul McCartney playing bass on the album) already sounds primed for the stadiums the Stones still rule
column2: it was the memory-ingrained guitar chords of “Tumbling Dice” and “Jumpin’ Jack Flash” that galvanized a crowd speckled with celebrities including Chris Rock
column3: Daniel Craig
column4: Trevor Noah
column5: Elvis Costello
column6: Diana Krall
column7: Jimmy Fallon and Christie Brinkley.

column1: The band
column2: however
column3: saved its showstopper for the inevitable encore. “Sweet Sounds Of Heaven
column4: ” a muscular gospel-blues standout on the new album
column5: was already landing with visceral intensity thanks to Jagger singing like a preacher
column6: drawing the crowd in with his gestures and falling to his knees.

column1: But then Lady Gaga strutted out with her blond hair in a Debbie Harry-esque rocker ruffle
column2: sparkly jumpsuit cut low in the front and divided vertically between pink and black.

column1: She immediately confirmed she is a worthy sparring partner for Jagger as the pair circled one another
column2: each approaching the other as prey. Their intensity was palpable as they traded soulful wails
column3: simultaneously bounced – she in platform heels – and fed off the force of the music. After Lady Gaga tossed down the mic stand in a frenzied moment of singing
column4: Jagger ceded the spotlight to her to close out the song with iron-lunged ferocity.

column1: The two pros were left breathless from being completely possessed by the song
column2: and as Jagger led her to the front of the stage to take a bow with the band
column3: it solidified that not only do the Rolling Stones still matter
column4: but their legacy continues to inspire.

column1: PHOENIX — OK so it didn’t quite have the drama of Luis Gonzalez’s walk-off hit in 2001.
This was a Game 3 in the National League Championship Series
column2: not a World Series Game 7.

column1: This didn’t produce a title for the Arizona Diamondbacks over the powerful New York Yankees that made Gonzalez a hero in Arizona.
But
column2: on a record-setting hot day in Arizona with temperatures hitting 103
column3: the name of Ketel Marte will forever resonate in D-backs history.

column1: It was Marte’s walk-off single with one out in the ninth inning that not only saved the Diamondbacks’ season with a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies in the National League Championship Series
column2: but also prevented manager Torey Lovullo from being vilified all winter.

column1: FOLLOW THE MONEY: MLB player salaries and payrolls for every major league team
Brandon Pfaadt
column2: the D-backs’ 25-year-old rookie
column3: was pitching the greatest game of his career Thursday when he looked towards the dugout in the sixth inning and saw Lovullo walking to the mound. He couldn’t believe it. Neither could the crowd of 47
column4: 075 at Chase Field. Or even Pfaadt’s teammates.

column1: “He looked good
column2: man
column3: he was great
column4: D-backs right fielder Tommy Pham said. “If anything, I would have left him in. You don’t want to take out a guy like that with so much momentum on our side. Let him keep going.

column1: Pfaadt had given up just two hits
column2: striking out nine
column3: and had thrown just 70 pitches in 5 ⅔ shutout innings. He joined Don Newcombe of the 1949 Brooklyn Dodgers as the only rookies to strike out at least nine batters without a walk in postseason history.

column1: Still
column2: Lovullo walked to the mound
column3: and was serenaded by loud boos
column4: with fans showing their disgust at the decision
column5: saying
column6: according to Lovullo
column7: “Has the manager lost his absolute mind?’

column1: “I'm sure I was the most unpopular guy in the city of Phoenix
column2: in the downtown area
column3: and maybe in the entire state of Arizona
column4: right? I was booing myself as I walked out to the mound
column5:
Lovullo said. “I didn’t need to be in the stands. … 
“I want everybody to know, that is trying to think along with me, that we have a strategy. I have a strategy for everything that's done. Everything that's done has been well talked about. It's not just analytics. I know how quickly playoff baseball can change. 
“So, yes, I am prepared to get booed. I am prepared to get second-guessed. It's my job.

column1: The decision to remove him was mostly scripted
column2: with Lovullo saying before the game that he was counting on Pfaadt to face about 18 batters
column3: which was exactly number Pfaadt saw. Yet
column4: Lovullo brushed back at the notion it was simply a matter of analytics
column5: and that a decision was made without discussing it with pitching coach Brent Strom and his staff.

column1: “So
column2: the conversations are very typical
column3:
Lovullo said. “I’m asking them if the manager is an idiot after taking his out after five and two-thirds [innings]. I know it's a very unpopular decision, but we have great information.’’ 
Pfaadt wasn’t too keen with the decision either, but hey, he’s a rookie. What’s he going to say? Besides, it all worked out in the end. 
“Obviously I'm a competitor, Pfaadt said. “I want to keep going. Everybody does
column4: but at the end of the day
column5: you just have to trust his decision and move forward
column6: go to the bullpen
column7: let them do their jobs."

column1: Despite a few shaky moments by the bullpen after Pfaadt’s departure
column2: coughing up a run in the seventh inning on reliever Ryan Thompson’s wild pitch
column3: the D-backs quickly recovered to score the game-tying run in the seventh.

column1: It set up the ninth inning with the Diamondbacks capitalizing on veteran closer Craig Kimbrel’s wildness
column2: retiring just one of the four batters he faced
column3: culminating on Marte’s sharp single to center field
column4: setting off a wild celebration.

column1: And
column2: yes
column3: a whole lot of relief
column4: with the D-backs winning their first NLCS game since beating Atlanta in 2001.

column1: “It feels great
column2: Marte said. “In my opinion, that’s what we needed right? The support, a little bump, or a little push so we can kind of turn it back against them. ... I’m excited to be fighting.

column1: Really
column2: Marte was destined to be the Diamondbacks’ hero.

column1: He’s the only guy hitting for Arizona. Marte is 6-for-13 (.462) in the series while his teammates are hitting just .179.
“He has an unbelievable heartbeat
column2:
Lovullo said. “He loves to be in that moment. He is one of our best players for a reason. … 
“Ketel thrives in that situation. He just has the heart of a lion. He wants to get the job done and be the main guy to help his team win a baseball game.

column1: If it wasn’t for Tommy Pham
column2: who was busy putting together motorized rally cars in the clubhouse afterwards
column3: Marte may never have gotten the chance to be a hero.

column1: Pham
column2: who was in a zero-for-12 slide and struck out in his first two at-bats Thursday
column3: was told that he was going to be taken out of the game for a pinch-hitter in the sixth inning. Yet
column4: he was on the on-deck circle when the inning ended.

column1: Lovullo stuck with Pham to open the seventh inning
column2: and he delivered a sharp leadoff single to center field off reliever Orion Kerkering. Speedy Alek Thomas was brought in to pinch-run for Pham
column3: and he scored easily on Lourdes Gurriel’s sharp double into the left-field corner
column4: tying game at 1-apiece.

column1: “They wanted to take me out
column2:
Pham said, “but I’ve got to prove them wrong, I guess.’’ 
The Diamondbacks still trail in the NLCS, 2 games to 1, but now have life, knowing that their victory guarantees ace, Zac Gallen, will pitch Game 5 at Chase Field after going with a bullpen-by-committee Friday.
GAME 3 RECAP:Diamondbacks beat Phillies on Ketel Marte's walk-off
“Zac pitching at home, hey, that sounds pretty good, Pham. “I’ll take that any day."

column1: The D-backs still believe
column2: and if nothing else
column3: maybe they created a little doubt that the Phillies won’t steamroll them on their way to a return trip to the World Series.

column1: “We have a lot of talent on this club
column2:
Marte said. “We just have to believe it. And I think we do. We can compete with anybody in this league. 
“You’re seeing that.

After about a dozen years at the helm
column2: Costco's Craig Jelinek is stepping down from his role as chief executive.

column1: The transition is set to take place on Jan. 1
column2: with President and Chief Operating Officer Ron Vachris taking over as CEO. Jelinek will remain at Costco through April 2024 in an advisory role and will stand for reelection on the board in January
column3: according to a statement from the company.

column1: Jelinek became CEO in January 2012 and has continued his predecessor's focus on keeping prices low and employees happy within the country’s third-largest retailer.
But not everything has remained the same. Here are some of the changes ushered in during Jelinek’s time as CEO.
When Jelinek’s succession was announced
column2: Costco had 592 warehouses in operation
column3: 429 of which were in the United States. The company’s footprint has gone up 45% since then
column4: with 861 warehouses – including 591 in the U.S. – operating today.

column1: Jelinek has also helped increase Costco's international presence
column2: opening warehouses in China
column3: Spain
column4: France
column5: Iceland
column6: New Zealand and Sweden.

column1: The company's share price has surged under Jelinek
column2: from about $80 per share in early 2012 to over $550 today. Its share price has gone up over 25% so far this year
column3: outperforming the benchmark S&P 500.

column1: And revenue has more than doubled
column2: from $99 billion in 2012 to $242.3 billion in the latest fiscal year.

column1: Jelinek told Bloomberg Businessweek in 2013 that the company would be eliminating self-checkout in stores after experimenting with the technology
column2: noting that he thought employees did the job better.

column1: “They are great for low-volume warehouses
column2: but we don’t want to be in the low-volume warehouse business
column3: ” he said at the time.

column1: Costco reversed its decision in 2019 and is now cracking down on checking membership cards at self-checkout lanes to prevent unauthorized card-sharing.
Costco in 2019 opened a $450 million poultry complex in Fremont
column2: Nebraska to help keep its rotisserie chicken prices at $4.99.

column1: In a 2019 earnings call
column2: Chief Financial Officer Richard Galanti said the plant can process about 2 million birds a week. The plant was estimated to save Costco about 35 cents per bird in 2015
column3: or about $35 million annually.

column1: Costco membership fees went up from $55 to $60 in 2017 under Jelinek
column2: the first price hike since a $5 increase in 2011.

column1: Membership prices are expected to jump again soon
column2: with Galanti noting in an earnings call that “it’s a question of when
column3: not if.” He noted that membership hikes typically take place every five to six years.

column1: How much is Costco's annual fee?Costco membership price increase 'a question of when
column2: not if
column3: ' CFO says

column1: Certain food court items
column2: including the chicken bake and soda
column3: have seen price hikes in recent months
column4: according to Insider.

column1: But there is one item on the menu with a price that has remained unchanged since 1985: the Costco hotdog.
During an earnings call last year
column2: Galanti said other parts of the business should help the company keep its hotdog prices stable “forever.” And when Jelinek was asked on CNBC last year if he would raise the food court item’s price from $1.50
column3: he had a simple answer: “No.”

column1: CONCORD
column2: N.H.−It’s a “really bad day” for former President Donald Trump
column3: according to GOP presidential hopeful Chris Christie.

column1: That’s because Sidney Powell
column2: Trump’s former attorney
column3: pled guilty Thursday to six misdemeanor charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election results in Georgia.

column1: Under the terms of the agreement
column2: Powell will serve a six-year probation
column3: pay a fine of $6
column4: 000 and testify at the trials of several co-defendants in the case. She also agreed to write an apology letter to Georgia residents.

column1: “The interesting part of that plea is that she will be testifying against Mark Meadows
column2: against Rudy Giuliani
column3: against Donald Trump
column4: ” Christie told reporters shortly after filling to put his name on the ballot in New Hampshire’s first-in-the-nation primary. “You don't give a no-jail plea deal unless that person's got something very good to say that will help your case against the others.”

column1: Powell was among 19 defendants named in Fulton County
column2: Georgia District Attorney Fani Willis’ Georgia election interference case
column3: which also included Trump.

column1: “I did this for seven years in the fifth largest office in the country
column2: said Christie, who served as the U.S. attorney in New Jersey from January 2002 to December 2008. You don't give a no-jail plea deal unless that person's got something very good to say that will help your case against the others."

column1: More school buses across the country could be fitted with Wi-Fi after a vote Thursday by the Federal Communications Commission.
In a 3-2 vote along party lines
column2: commissioners adopted a declaratory ruling allowing districts to use money from the E-Rate program
column3: which helps schools and libraries buy affordable broadband
column4: toward Wi-Fi and supported devices on buses.

column1: Democrats on the commission and in Congress lauded the proposal as a way of supporting students
column2: particularly those in rural areas
column3: with lengthy commutes to and from school. Greater access to Wi-Fi
column4: they said
column5: would help close disparities in homework completion and academic success.

column1: Republicans
column2: however
column3: cautioned against what they saw as potentially wasteful government spending that they claimed could increase students’ access to unsupervised internet use.

column1: Chairwoman Jessica Rosenworcel
column2: a Democrat
column3: said the proposal was an effort to make sure the E-Rate program
column4: which is paid for by a system of subsidies and fees from telecommunications companies
column5: keeps up with the times

column1: Classrooms on wheels:Free Google Wi-Fi transforms rural school buses into rolling classrooms

Congressional Republicans opposed the proposal in recent weeks. Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas and Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington state in a letter last month raised concerns about "subsidizing unsupervised internet access to social media sites like TikTok."

column2: homes

Cruz said in a statement. 
Fedders, the Vermont superintendent, said the devices on buses in his district have all the same firewalls and security measures as the network in the school building. 
“We are able to limit the access to content that we do not want them using,” he said. 
Keith Krueger, CEO of the education technology group the Consortium for School Networking, said a recent survey from his organization showed only 13% of districts say they provide Wi-Fi on school buses.
“From our perspective and the vast majority of educators, they see great value in recapturing time that students are commuting to school,” he told USA TODAY.
Zachary Schermele is a breaking news and education reporter for USA TODAY. You can reach him by email at zschermele@usatoday.com. Follow him on X at @ZachSchermele.
Back in the good old days, when Jim Harbaugh was provoking someone in college football on a near-daily basis, nothing could get him rolling on social media faster than an allegation of cheating. 
“If the Georgia coach is implying any intent on our part to break rules, he is barking up the wrong tree,” Harbaugh tweeted on Feb. 24, 2016, after Kirby Smart suggested the NCAA would be forced to step in after Michigan held spring practice at IMG Academy. 
The following year, when ESPN’s Paul Finebaum suggested that Michigan hiring the father of a top recruit to his coaching staff was unsavory (albeit allowed), Harbaugh fired back with a Tweet calling him “Pete Finebaum, the unabashed SEC water carrier.” 
But when you play in the gray area of the NCAA rulebook while walking around like you’ve just been blessed by the Pope, you tend to make a lot of enemies. 
And now that Michigan is residing near the top of college football again, all the fangs are coming out. 
For the second time this year, Harbaugh is in the middle of a snit with the NCAA over potential rules violations that were petty, completely avoidable and ultimately quite stupid if they indeed took place. 
Harbaugh served a self-imposed three-game suspension at the beginning of this season for misleading or not cooperating with NCAA investigators during an investigation into impermissible contact with recruits and coaching activities during the COVID-19 dead period. 
Now, in a story reported first Thursday by Yahoo! Sports and confirmed by the Big Ten, Michigan is under another inquiry for in-person scouting of opponents, which has been against the rules for nearly 30 years and is quite unnecessary these days, unless the goal is to glean extra information about an opponent's play-calls that teams often try to disguise on the sideline.
Now I know what you, the well-informed college sports fan, is thinking. If the NCAA couldn’t pin anything on Kansas basketball coach Bill Self just last week for having Adidas help him recruit players despite years of investigative work and loads of evidence pointing toward a significant punishment, how in the world is Harbaugh going to get popped for relatively petty crimes?
The answer is because NCAA enforcement is a lot like traffic cops. They’re not going to catch everybody. They may pick one speeding car to turn the siren on for over another for biased reasons. But when they have you on the radar gun going 90 miles per hour on the highway, they’re going to write you a ticket — especially if you act difficult and indignant when they pull you over. 
If all of this stuff is proven true, Harbaugh made it easy on them. And given his proclivity toward Michigan Man self-righteousness, the rest of college football is snickering away. 
Selective enforcement? Maybe. 
But the rules Michigan allegedly violated are so clear and straightforward — and ultimately offer so little upside — that all suspicions about the way Harbaugh conducts his program are now completely fair game. 
Back in 2020, when the world was figuring out COVID-19 one day at a time, NCAA schools agreed that it was better for everyone to just take a pause on recruiting and other normal offseason activities.
Is it a huge deal if Harbaugh went to a restaurant with a couple of recruits who were in town during that time? Not really, but it is a willful violation in order to gain a competitive advantage. And then to not be truthful or forthcoming about it with the NCAA? That’s another bright red line that the NCAA has used many times to penalize coaches, because catching them in a lie is one of the few hammers they actually have.
This alleged scouting violation is even sillier. Michigan is 7-0 and has won its games by 27, 28, 25, 24, 38, 42 and 45 points. 
If, as The Athletic reported Thursday, the Big Ten has evidence of a “vast network” being used to steal signs, it's the most comical use of espionage since Dan Aykroyd and Chevy Chase paired up in “Spies Like Us.”
If you need to steal signs to beat Nebraska and Rutgers, you’re more con man than Michigan Man.
Much of the focus now will turn to whether these dual investigations end up chasing Harbaugh back to the NFL, especially if the Wolverines -- who might really be the best team in the country -- end up winning a national title. 
It’s an interesting topic, but honestly, trying to predict Harbaugh’s mindset or his next move is a lost cause. Before this story dropped, there was talk of another extension in the works. But Harbaugh has said before he’s staying at Michigan one week, interviewed with an NFL team the next and then come back to say it was a one-time thing (at least until the next one-time thing). 
When you're that slippery, aloofness is a helpful trait -- and Harbaugh uses it to his advantage time and time again. 
But the more interesting part of the story is really how this comeuppance has been kind of in the works ever since Harbaugh got back into college football. 
You can stand up and say you do things by the book and take great offense to accusations that you’re shading the rules, but make no mistake: Harbaugh at Michigan has absolutely made a home in the gray area while tacitly accusing everyone else in the sport of being cheaters. 
In 2019, author John Bacon — someone who is closely tied to the Michigan program and wrote a book on Harbaugh — claimed that Rashan Gary was offered $300,000 by another school during his recruitment before choosing the Wolverines (this is before name, image and likeness would have allowed for similar arrangements).
Most people in college sports would look at that claim skeptically — not about the offer itself but the idea that somebody would choose to play for a school offering nothing but the standard scholarship when they could have pocketed $300,000 somewhere else, even if it was against the rules. 
Why even put that out there other than to glorify Mr. “Do it the right way” while casting aspersions on competitors? It’s not just unseemly, it’s phony. Because another huge part of the story in the Gary recruitment was that Harbaugh in 2015 hired Chris Partridge as director of player personnel and recruiting. Who is Chris Partridge? Well, he was the head coach at Paramus Catholic High School in New Jersey, where Gary played until enrolling at Michigan in 2016. 
Again, just like the example that got Harbaugh crossways with Finebaum, it’s not against the rules. Partridge was qualified for the job and is now in his second stint on the Michigan staff after working as the co-defensive coordinator and safeties coach the last three seasons. 
But hiring the high school coach of the No. 1 prospect in the country and then landing that prospect from several states away is a gray-area move. Just like Harbaugh holding so-called “satellite camps” for recruits in Southern states, sleeping over at a recruit’s house or even this summer, when former tight end Jake Butt told a story via X (formerly Twitter) about how Harbaugh exploited a loophole in the practice time limits to get more reps in the spring.
“Harbaugh is great at taking advantage of Grey areas,” Butt wrote.
How long of a leap is it from the gray to outright rule-breaking — even if the rules are picayune? Maybe not that long.
But it's worth harkening back to the prescient words of Kirby Smart from seven years ago, when his little spat with Harbaugh got started over the IMG trip. 
“They're obviously trying to gain a competitive advantage, and that’s their right,” he said. But I think the NCAA in due time will have to step in. I don’t know how it’s going to go down. It’s going to be interesting too see
column5: though.”

Honorees from 28 different cities around the world were recognized at a live awards ceremony in Singapore on Tuesday, marking the first time the ceremony has been held in Asia. 
Double Chicken Please in New York City was named second best for the first time, while Handshake Speakeasy in Mexico City took third place. 
The U.S. tied with England for most bars on the list, with a total of five U.S.-based bars included. Three of the bars named are in New York City. Café La Trova in Miami came in 24th place, while New Orleans bar Jewel of the South ranked 49 out of 50. 
Mexico City follows the U.S. and London closely, with four bars making the list. Argentina and Singapore were the countries with the third most number of winning bars with three wins each.
