column4: the president of the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene.

column1: “A global approach is especially important
column2: he said in a statement, since climate change allows insects that carry pathogens like Leishmania
column3: dengue virus and malaria to expand their range.”

column1: Eduardo Cuevas covers health and breaking news for USA TODAY. He can be reached at EMCuevas1@usatoday.com.
Out of all the personality conflicts in the reality TV world
column2: why did God
column3: ABC and/or Gerry Turner end the burgeoning "Golden Bachelor" battle between Kathy and Theresa so quickly?

column1: It was only last week that Kathy plunged the previously collegial mansion into the delicious heart of darkness by mobilizing against Theresa
column2: who played the perfect victim while intensifying Kathy's rage by raving constantly about her deep "connection" with Gerry.

column1: Yet before you could say "Real Housewives of New Jersey
column2:
the brewing brouhaha ended abruptly in Thursday's Episode 4.
Savor these fleeting moments in a power episode that featured a pickleball battle for Gerry's affections, a bawdy Never Have I Ever game with ice cream punishment, three women leaving the mansion (one of her own volition) and — saving the best for last — a shirtless Gerry, 72, presenting a rose during a steamy hot tub canoodle. Here's what happened in The Golden Bachelor" Episode 4:

column1: 'The Golden Bachelor' Episode 3 recapThe fight for Gerry Turner's roses is on. Who lost?
This was the cruelest month for therapist April
column3: who had no business going home this early. April audaciously faked a wipeout and ankle injury before Gerry's pickleball tournament
column4: then shooed concerned fellow contestants away so she could lean into Gerry's awkwardly protective embrace.

column1: The good 'ol mare ain't what she used to be, April said winsomely to Gerry. In the next solo scene
column2: she literally winked to the camera with a sly smile and sotto voce remark
column3: "Actually
column4: I am totally fine." Classic.

column1: April won the women-only Never Have I Ever game with nonstop confessions that included detailed experiences with car sex: "Front seat
column2: back seat
column3: on the steering wheel
column4:
she shrugged between bites of ice cream penance.
Inexplicably, Gerry didn't give April a rose.
All about the pickleball game'Golden Bachelor' Gerry Turner courts skills
Retired executive assistant Sandra, 75, is still alive in every way, even if she was last seen on bed rest from the hearty partaking of ice cream during the Never Have I Ever game. (Turns out she's lactose intolerant.) But she pushed through the dairy-filled gauntlet because she's a gamer.
Case in point, Sandra missed her daughter's wedding to impress Gerry in the pickleball tournament. She was a smashing first-timer, with a Jeter-esque lunge shot that should make ESPN highlights and play that propelled her team to runner-up status. (Kathy and hardcore pickleball enthusiast Ellen took the crown).
Gerry insisted Sandra make a joint FaceTime call to her just-wedded daughter. Their FaceTime moment was beautiful, complete with relatable iPhone tech fumbling. We're too old for this
column5:
Sandra said with a smile. Sweet.
Gerry rewarded Sandra, who was too ill for the ceremony, with an early rose.
Fitness instructor Leslie, 64, the self-professed muse to Prince's song Sexy Dancer
column6:
was excused from pickle play after drawing the one-on-one Gerry date. During their golden-light ATV jaunt, Gerry showed four-wheeler chivalry, riding behind Leslie to look after her.
But it wouldn't be a Bachelor" season without a hot tub kiss. Gerry did not disappoint
column7: after the two gazed into each other's mutually beautiful blue eyes.

column1: Without dousing his rose
column2: the suddenly shirtless Gerry helped Leslie into the tub
column3: which materialized in a picturesque field with Champagne. Their post-rose clinch was PG-13 steamy
column4: even with Gerry's right hand oddly stuck on the jacuzzi wall as if he was seeking the air-jets switch.

column1: Retired educational consultant Kathy
column3: snapped right back into outrage mode after financial professional Theresa
column5: boasted of her first-date details (again) to the group and visiting former "Bachelorette" Trista Sutter. "She could just be the one for Gerry
column6: Kathy said to the camera in an astute moment. She just can't seem to find the 'off' button."

column1: Theresa tried to patch things up with another apologetic heart-to-heart that ended with Kathy giving her "friendly advice" that would have spooked Tony Soprano.
Zip it, said Kathy.
This became "Snip it" when Theresa tearfully recounted the exchange to Gerry. But it worked. Gerry was outraged
column2: confronting Kathy with
column3: "I'm beginning to sense a rift here that I'm not happy about!"

column1: I'm not the villain here, Kathy insisted. But even she could see the game was up. "Because of Theresa
column2: I'm not getting a rose
column3:
she groused.
She was right about the rose. Not often portrayed as a healthy model for personal expression, Kathy made a graceful exit, giving a final wave to the group that included Theresa. She drove off in the black SUV with a brittle look of defiance.
I am who I am and people either like me or they don't
column4: Kathy said in her exit interview. Rejection is not fun. I might burn the house down before I leave." We think she was joking there.

column1: Retired interior designer Nancy
column3: had a tender Episode 2 Gerry moment
column4: but somehow sensed romantic futility. She voiced her suspicions privately to Gerry that she wasn't going to make the cut.

column1: I'm really not going to dispute that, Gerry said
column2: sounding like he was giving a statement from his legal counsel.

column1: Power move for Nancy
column2: with her boot cast from pickleball
column3: to just drive off before the rose ceremony that saw April and Kathy leave.

column1: Ellen: The pickleball ace won that showcase and heartily kissed Gerry afterward. She enjoyed more Gerry kisses in a one-on-one moment. Gerry had his eyes open for some. Just saying.
Faith: Working it
column2: but frets about her lack of Gerry time.

column1: Susan: Gerry gave emphatic kisses and a rose quartz gift.
Leslie: That ATV date went deep. Real deep.
Theresa: Kathy hates to be right about this. There's something real between Gerry and Theresa.
Sandra: Gerry hasn't truly realized her greatness
column2: but there's time.

column1: Editor's note: Part one of a five-part USA TODAY series revealing why America hasn't solved its long struggle with Type 2 diabetes.
For chef Robin Ray
column2: newly married with young stepchildren
column3: the turning point came when a stabbing chest pain sent her rushing to the emergency room.

column1: For Brian Castrucci
column2: the gravity hit when the ER doc who had treated him for a near-heart attack a few weeks earlier gave him a big bear hug. “I didn’t think you’d make it
column3: ” the doctor said.

column1: The crisis unspooled more slowly for James Haynes but started in 2019 when he stepped on a rusty nail and didn’t notice.
The moments were turning points for all three to get serious about addressing their diabetes.
Type 2 diabetes
column2: in which the body can’t properly regulate blood sugar
column3: has become so common it’s almost considered inconsequential. More than 1 in 10 Americans have the disease (though many don't know) and another nearly 4 in 10 are at risk for it. In total
column4: half of all adults and a quarter of teenagers have diabetes or pre-diabetes.

column1: Its financial costs are astronomical. The country spends more than $300 billion a year to address diabetes
column2: accounting for $1 out of every $4 spent on health care.

column1: And its personal tolls are even worse: heart attacks
column2: amputations
column3: blindness
column4: kidney disease
column5: double the risk of premature death. It also causes what’s known as “diabetes distress
column6: ” the daily burdens and emotional toll of living with and managing a chronic ailment that can lead to regular dips in energy
column7: foggy thinking and depression
column8: and a sense of isolation.

column1: The most frustrating aspect of Type 2 diabetes
column2: experts say
column3: is that it has long been largely preventable and controllable.

column1: “We have made tremendous gains in understanding diabetes
column2: ” said Dr. Donald Berwick
column3: a pediatrician and former administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. “The best diabetes care can make a very big difference. You can’t say we don’t know what to do.”

column1: And yet
column2: diagnosed rates of Type 2 diabetes have soared over the past 25 years
column3: and especially over the past dozen – particularly among working-age adults like Ray
column4: Castrucci and Haynes.

column1: Roughly 40% of people who died early in the coronavirus pandemic had Type 2 diabetes
column2: a rate four times higher than people without the disease. Even when elevated blood sugar levels are below the threshold for type 2 diabetes
column3: the risk for heart disease jumps 30% to 50% compared with people with normal blood sugar levels. (Type 1 diabetes
column4: which accounts for 5% to 10% of diabetes
column5: is caused by the immune system and is unrelated to diet or lifestyle.)

column1: America’s failure to address Type 2 diabetes highlights larger problems with our food and medical systems
column2: Berwick and other experts said.

column1: A soda costs less than a bottle of water
column2: a double cheeseburger and fries less than a carton of blueberries. Patients wait months for medical appointments only to see the back of a white coat for the short time they’re allotted. Treating disease costs society far more than preventing it but typically provides more profit for insurance companies
column3: hospitals and the pharmaceutical industry.

column1: The USA TODAY Health team spoke with scores of health care providers
column2: researchers
column3: community leaders and patients for this five-part series to understand why Type 2 diabetes continues to worsen in America despite known solutions.

column1: The answer isn't simple. It involves systemic problems facing everyone in society
column2: not just those with diabetes: a food system designed to sell products; a medical system in which cutting off a leg is less expensive than saving it; the high cost of healthy living and the fact that breaking habits takes a lot more than just personal willpower.

column1: This first story looks at what it takes for people to cope with or overcome the disease.
Then
column2: we explore one community in a David vs. Goliath battle against a food system that fails to prioritize people's health.

column1: More in series:Diabetes runs deep in rural Mississippi. Locals have taken to growing their own solutions.
We next travel to Colorado
column2: which has the lowest level of diabetes in the nation. Yet even in this state
column3: where hiking trails and gorgeous views abound
column4: economic and other disparities make it easier for some people to avoid diabetes than others.

column1: More in series:A diabetes disparity: Why Colorado's healthy lifestyle brand isn't shared by all
It's tough to manage a chronic illness in the face of high medical costs
column2: scattered care and caregiver frustration and burnout
column3: so we highlight that next.

column1: More in series:The steep cost of Type 2: When diabetes dragged her down
column2: she chose to fight

column1: Finally
column2: we explore solutions
column3: addressing why it will take a combination of education
column4: medication
column5: medical devices and improved food access to solve this national problem.

column1: More in series:Solutions exist to end the Type 2 diabetes dilemma but too few get the help they need
The system is fixable
column2: said Dr. Dariush Mozaffarian
column3: a cardiologist and professor at the Tufts University School of Medicine in Boston.

column1: But it will take "sensible action" from across many sectors
column2: including health care
column3: science
column4: nutrition
column5: business
column6: public health and politics to change the financial and other incentives that drive so many Americans toward sickness instead of health.

column1: If we do it all, we could fix a lot of this in 10 years, said Mozaffarian
column2: who serves on the President’s Council on Sports
column3: Fitness
column4: and Nutrition. "If we do it incrementally or don't do it at all
column5: we're all going to be toast in 50 years from diet-related illnesses and a depleted environment."

column1: There’s no question personal responsibility plays a role in fighting diabetes.
Haynes
column2: Ray and Castrucci radically changed their lifestyles and sought help after their come-to-Jesus experiences. They’ve reduced their dependence on daily medication and hope to have saved themselves the horrors of more amputations
column3: blindness and dialysis. They’ve extended their lives and improved the quality of that time.

column1: But like many medical problems
column2: the challenges of diabetes go well beyond individual responsibility and blame.

column1: “There are structural issues that we have to start paying attention to and addressing
column2: ” said Dr. Shivani Agarwal
column3: an endocrinologist who specializes in research and treating young adults with diabetes at Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York. Agarwal recently led a series of studies in the journal The Lancet that looked at diabetes rates around the world.

column1: Poverty
column2: the studies showed
column3: was a major driver of diabetes
column4: along with racism and unequal access to healthy food and high-quality medical care.

column1: Personal stories illustrate how these structural issues play out in the lives of so many Americans.
Ray
column3: director of culinary operations at HOSCO/North Sarah Food Hub in St. Louis
column4: got weight-loss surgery and then put her culinary expertise to good use.

column1: Castrucci
column3: who runs a public health nonprofit outside Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: used his advantages provided by his work
column6: salary and insurance to “buy” himself better health.

column1: “I’m healthy because of privilege – not diet
column2: not exercise
column3: not determination
column4: ” he said.

column1: Haynes
column3: a former truck driver and maintenance technician in Gulfport
column4: Mississippi
column5: has fewer material assets
column6: but his attitude and the advantages he does have explain why he's still around
column7: despite all he has been through.

column1: “It’s going to be all right after a while
column2: as long as I keep this spirit
column3: ” he said.

column1: Ray’s love for food began when she was 8 years old
column2: watching Julia Child on TV. During family gatherings
column3: she would run around taking everyone’s dinner order. Then she’d scurry back to the kitchen with a notepad full of scribbles.

column1: Throughout her life
column2: she made fried chicken
column3: pork chops
column4: baked mac and cheese
column5: collard greens
column6: and even a whole roasted chicken filled with wild rice and two sticks of butter – everything that made her soul sing.

column1: In her world
column2: food was home. Food was family. Food was love.

column1: But that was some pretty tough love.

column2: Ray was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes. Her father
column3: grandmother
column4: aunts and uncles all had diabetes. She knew what it meant.

column1: “For you to tell me I can’t have ice blue raspberry Kool-Aid was like you shut down my world
column2: ” Ray said. “I didn’t want to accept it. So
column3: I ate
column4: because you eat through your emotions.”

column1: She didn't dwell on the diagnosis and continued with life. Her culinary career took her to Italy
column2: where she learned and fell even more in love with food. She returned to St. Louis
column3: got married and became a mom to her husband’s two children ‒ “beautiful bonus babies
column4: ” as she described them. Through the years
column5: she continued to express love through cooking and eating.

column2: a stabbing chest pain sent her to the emergency room. Doctors assured Ray she hadn’t had a heart attack
column3: but they warned that her life was on the line. At 5-foot-2
column4: she weighed 334 pounds and had an A1C
column5: a measure of average blood sugar of 11%
column6: well above the 6.5% cutoff to be considered diabetic. Her diabetes – and her diet – were out of control.

column1: “That scared me. … It was gut-wrenching and terrifying
column2: ” she said. “I’m fighting against something that’s fighting me back and I did not know how to win.”

column1: She and her primary care doctor decided she would pursue weight loss surgery.
But she also decided to use her culinary prowess to transform her diet. She reconfigured favorite foods
column2: substituting healthier ingredients: Collard greens cooked in smoked fats or ham hocks turned into a kale
column3: turnip and rutabaga recipe flavored with natural chicken broth fat
column4: oils and seasonings.

column1: She fostered her feelings into new recipes and brought them to North Sarah Food Hub
column2: which partnered with Barnes-Jewish Hospital to make packaged
column3: pre-made meals for St. Louis residents with diabetes and limited access to fresh food.

column1: “I had to restructure the food that I put in my mouth. I had to think about what I was eating and how I was eating and how it was going to be good for my body
column2: ” she said. “I became excited about food again
column3: and food became a joy.”

column1: It isn’t always easy
column2: of course. Ray admits to an occasional cookie craving. But now she takes the time to think about how her body processes that cookie and whether it’s worthwhile.

column1: She hopes her cooking can help other people make the same transformation she did. Her staff at North Sarah helps her create new recipes for others. She wants to provide nourishment that allows people to avoid illness and medicine.
“Nobody wants to take 55 pills
column2: nobody wants to feel like a patient
column3: but how do you fix that? It’s by our food
column4: ” she said. “That should be what we’re teaching our community and our culture and our children. … It’s not always about the macaroni noodle with a smile
column5: it’s about what’s good for your body.”

column1: Castrucci is a third-generation diabetes patient. The lifetime risk of developing Type 2 diabetes if a parent has it is 40%. If both parents have it
column2: the risk jumps to 70%.

column1: He knew he was at risk
column2: but he pushed his luck
column3: he said
column4: by eating poorly during the pandemic and falling out of his exercise routine. With the luxury of working from home
column5: walking to the kitchen and bathroom was often the extent of his daily activity.

column1: On Feb. 14
column2: 2022 – Valentine’s Day – he went to an urgent care clinic
column3: concerned his breathing trouble meant he had bronchitis. His blood pressure measured 210 over 110
column4: well above normal levels that top out at 120 over 80. A chest X-ray showed fluid filling his lungs
column5: leading to congestive heart failure.

column1: The clinic sent him straight to a local emergency room
column2: where he was diagnosed with a blockage of the left descending artery – a clogged artery made worse by diabetes. If he had waited any longer
column3: he would have had a massive heart attack
column4: his doctor later told him.

column1: After his release from the hospital
column2: he went to the drugstore to fill his new prescriptions. The pharmacist told him she couldn’t fill one because it would cost $1
column3: 000. He’d have to wait until his insurance approved it. “Please fill it
column4: ” he said. She stressed the cost. “Fill it
column5: ” he pleaded
column6: putting the charge on his credit card.

column1: Medication helped him lose 70 pounds in three months. When his local drugstore ran out of the weight-loss drug
column2: he easily drove to another pharmacy and then another to find what he needed.

column1: His 100 hours of high-quality cardiac rehabilitation were fully covered by insurance.
For my midlife crisis, I got healthy, Castrucci said.
He could devote all his energy to getting well because he didn’t have to focus on how to afford his care. “(I) paid almost nothing for the whole episode
column2: ” he said
column3: “and never worried about it because I have really good insurance.”

column1: Even so
column2: Castrucci pays out-of-pocket for a cardiologist and an endocrinologist because the best ones near him don’t accept insurance.

column1: Every time he goes to Walgreens to refill his medications
column2: Castrucci said
column3: he sees someone turned away because they can’t afford their prescriptions. When they finally show up in the emergency room
column4: “because they will
column5: ” they will cost the system far more
column6: he said.

column1: “Health outcomes are dictated by economics. It’s a whole side of privilege that we don’t always talk about.”
On the day Haynes stepped on a rusty nail in 2019
column2: he walked all day as the nail pierced the sole of his sneaker and then his foot. By the time he took off his shoe that night
column3: his foot was infected. He landed in the hospital for two months as doctors and nurses tried
column4: mostly unsuccessfully
column5: to get the infection and Haynes’ blood sugar under control.

column1: By the time he was released
column2: he knew enough about Type 2 diabetes to realize his daily blood sugar levels – typically in the mid-400s – were four times above what he had been told to shoot for.

column1: But nothing he did or ate seemed to make a difference. He had long since traded ribs for salads
column2: beer for water.

column1: His wife
column2: Angela
column3: barely noticed when James started wearing multiple pairs of socks
column4: pouring powder on his feet and buying bigger shoes. His feet tingled a lot
column5: he said
column6: but he was coping with it.

column1: James ended up in the emergency room again
column2: dehydrated and in need of antibiotics. The doctor amputated the baby toe on his right foot
column3: leaving a large open wound.

column1:
We're going to leave this open because we'll probably have to take more,” Angela remembered the doctor saying. “I didn't like that we're not going to try to save anything, we're just going to start cutting.”
James was fading.
His arm muscles shriveled and he lost his Popeye physique. Antibiotics left him looking sickly, his voice so weak Angela could barely hear him. “I felt like I was watching my husband slowly dying,” she said.
Finally, taking her doctor sister’s advice, Angela emailed Dr. Foluso Fakorede’s office to ask for an appointment. She thought it would take months to get James in to see the heart disease specialist, but the office called and asked if they could come the next day. 
The Hayneses would end up going back to see Fakorede many times − sometimes twice in one week, driving more than five hours each way from Gulfport north to Cleveland, Mississippi.
“We started looking forward to these visits because there was always hope,” Angela Haynes said, though she felt guilty they were taking up so much of the important doctor’s time. 
Fakorede, who is on a personal mission to save people with diabetes from amputations, noticed what other doctors had missed. Haynes had blockages in blood vessels on both legs. 
Once he got the blood flowing again, Haynes began to feel better. His flesh returned to its normal color. The wound started healing at last. Walking became easier.
Then disaster struck again. 
On July 2, 2022, Haynes caught COVID-19. Everything went downhill after that
column2:
he said.
During his 13-day illness, the bacteria in his foot raged out of control. He ended up back in the hospital and unable to withstand the long drive to Fakorede’s office.
Every week, a surgeon would come to the door of his hospital room and before even stepping all the way in ask Haynes whether he had decided to get his leg amputated. 
This is my leg. I was born with this. And you're walking in like you're cutting a piece of cake
column3:
Haynes said.
He was worried about how he’d get around, how he’d be able to work to support his family if he had only one leg. No one took the time to explain why they thought the leg needed to come off or how he’d cope without it, Haynes said. 
In late November, he was finally sent home in a wheelchair. But just three weeks later, as he was getting out of the car after wound care, his right leg gave out and he fell to the ground. Back at the hospital, Haynes was told his foot was broken, essentially beyond repair. He agreed to a below-the-knee amputation.
Released right before Christmas, he spent the next three weeks in bed wondering how he’d manage the rest of his life.
Finally, it looked as if his luck might be turning around.
With the leg gone, his diabetes improved. His blood sugar dropped into the 120s or one-teens. His blurry vision cleared up.
During his long hospital stay, he befriended nurses and learned about a program for people who needed prostheses. The man who ran it called early in the year and said he had received a donated leg. If it fit Haynes, he could have it while waiting for insurance to pay for a personalized one. Miraculously, it did. 
Haynes spent the next six months teaching himself to walk again. The donor leg was heavy and uncomfortable. He wasn't mobile enough to hold down a job.
One late spring night, picking up dinner at a nearby restaurant, he headed to the bathroom for a pit stop. A sink had been leaking all day and Haynes slipped in the puddle, falling backward.
He's still recovering from the resulting wrist surgery.
He and Angela are living – barely – off her part-time salary as a secretary and a church organist.
Haynes has tried at least three or four times" to receive government assistance
column4: but they keep losing his paperwork
column5: or not believing he's disabled
column6: though he once checked himself out of the hospital and arrived at an appointment in his wheelchair to prove he didn't have a leg.

column1: Still
column2: he clings to his faith and the positive attitude he has long used to cheer up himself and others. These are his secret weapons against diabetes and everything else life throws his way.

column1: I try to put a smile on other people's faces, he said. "It keeps my day going."

column1: The USA TODAY Best-selling Booklist is back!
After a brief hiatus
column2: USA TODAY’s beloved bestsellers list has returned with the features and characteristics that have long made it the People’s Booklist.

column1: Our goal remains the same: Provide book lovers with the best
column2: most accurate snapshot of what people are reading by showing which titles are selling. It is a master list
column3: unbound by genre and format
column4: of what’s selling broadly across the U.S.

column1: “I am so thrilled that the USA Today Best-selling Booklist is coming back!" says bestselling author Colleen Hoover in a statement. "It gives so many authors the wonderful opportunity to be recognized as bestsellers and for readers to discover their next favorite book.”
Hoover
column2: the self-published writer turned bestselling powerhouse who's authored dozens of novels including "It Ends With Us" and "Verity
column3: was the undisputed queen of the Booklist in 2022 and spent weeks atop the list. Her novel It Starts With Us" claimed the No. 1 spot in its first week

column5: selling more than 800
column6: 000 copies on its first day of sales. It was her fourth book to hit No. 1 in 2022.

column1: Check out: USA TODAY's weekly Best-selling Booklist
The USA TODAY list is a ranking of the top-selling titles each week from a broad range of businesses including major chains
column2: independent bookstores and online retailers. It reflects combined sales of titles in print and electronic format
column3: if available. Our data team weighs and compiles those numbers to generate the week's 150 top-selling titles. The rankings reflect sales from the previous Monday through Sunday. The full list will publish online at 6 a.m. Wednesdays
column4: with the top 50 titles publishing in print Thursdays.

column1: The list
column2: which began in 1993
column3: went on hiatus in December. It is the longest-running USA TODAY data journalism project.

column1: In our continued commitment to bring readers more books coverage

column1: We can't wait to see what you've been reading!
Hamas and Israel have been blaming each other for a deadly blast at a Gaza hospital complex.

President Joe Biden backed up Israel’s statements on Wednesday as he visited Tel Aviv. Biden said he was “outraged and saddened” by the loss of life in Gaza City. But he said U.S. intelligence indicated that Israel was not behind the explosion.
Here's a look at what happened
column2: and what the different parties are saying:

column1: An explosion in a courtyard and parking lot adjacent to al-Ahli Hospital in a Gaza City suburb reportedly killed or injured hundreds of patients and people in the vicinity.
Mohammed Abu Selmia − general director of Shifa Hospital
column2: where the wounded and dead were transferred after the explosion − said early Wednesday that he believed the death toll was close to 250
column3: with hundreds more wounded
column4: The Associated Press reported.

column1: The American Friends of the Episcopal Diocese of Jerusalem
column2: which operates the medical center
column3: said in a statement Tuesday evening that hundreds of staff
column4: patients
column5: and refugees who were sheltering at Ahli Arab Hospital were killed and wounded.

column1: Palestinians have been seeking refuge in and around hospitals from the Israeli bombardment of Gaza prompted by the Oct. 7 Hamas rampage that killed 1
column2: 400 people in Israeli territory. More than 3
column3: 000 people have been killed and more than 12
column4: 500 have been injured in Gaza
column5: according to its health ministry.

column1: Keep up with developments from Gaza:Sign up for our Israel-Hamas War newsletter
The U.S. said Wednesday that its intelligence assessments indicated Israel was not behind the hospital explosion.
“While we continue to collect information
column2: our current assessment
column3: based on analysis of overhead imagery
column4: intercepts and open source information
column5: is that Israel is not responsible for the explosion at the hospital in Gaza yesterday
column6: ” National Security Council spokeswoman Adrienne Watson said in a statement.

column1: Air Force Gen. Pat Ryder
column2: the Pentagon press secretary
column3: said separately that the Defense Department’s intelligence assessment is that Israel was not responsible for the explosion.

column1: USA TODAY received more detail about the U.S. perspective from U.S. officials who were not authorized to speak publicly. Imagery that shows the lack of a bomb crater and heat trails from rockets being fired inside Gaza have led officials to believe that the blast that killed hundreds at a hospital there Tuesday came from a rocket fired by Palestinian militants.
The explosives in Israeli bombs
column2: even in the smallest version
column3: leave a crater when they explode
column4: according to U.S. officials who have been briefed on intelligence findings about the explosion. Sensors can detect the heat generated during the blast off a rocket or missile
column5: a trail known a “heat signature.” Israeli airstrikes rely principally on joint direct attack munitions

Israel Defense Forces Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Herzi Halevi said Oct. 12 in his first public statement since the war began. “We will attack them, we will dismantle them, dismantle their system.” 
Arouri lacks the same profile. One of his current titles is deputy chief of Hamas’ political bureau, but sources say Arouri’s role in Hamas has become much more prominent than that. In addition to still playing a role in the Qassam Brigades, Arouri has spent years helping rebuild Hamas operations in the other Palestinian territory blockaded by Israel, the West Bank, according to former Israeli and U.S. counterterrorism officials who have tracked him.  
And, they say, he acts as a chief deputy of sorts to Ismail Haniyeh, one of several Hamas leaders based in Qatar as they try to do political outreach for the group, including to Iran and Hezbollah. 
Five days after the attacks, Arouri offered Al Jazeera Arabic some of the first inside details about the operation, including how 1,200 members of the Qassam Brigades had been given “detailed instructions” about their targets, the Israeli military’s Gaza Brigade, just across the border from the Gaza Strip. 
“We were surprised that the Gaza Brigade collapsed in less than three hours, faster than we expected,” Arouri said.  
Officially, Iran has denied playing a role in the attack even as it congratulates Hamas. President Joe Biden told 60 Minutes on Oct. 15 that there’s no evidence “at this point” that Iran was behind the attack. Israeli officials have made similar comments, stressing that the investigation is in its early stages. 
But U.S. and Israeli intelligence analysts say that if anyone could give the group the ability to launch such stunning land, air and sea attacks against the Israeli military, it would be Iran and its Revolutionary Guard. Even as the hunt for Arouri continued this week, Iran and Hezbollah both raised prospects of openly entering the conflict to respond to Israel’s strikes at Gaza. 
Arouri’s role as an alliance-builder among terrorist organizations has been known to Israel since at least 2018. And his role in raising money and plotting terrorist attacks for Hamas has been known to both governments for a generation.
“It's not just the guys who pulled the trigger or approved the battle plan or gave the final order to do it but the people who are directing all of the strategy and really promoting the (anti-Israel) militarism,” said former FBI counterterrorism analyst and U.S. Treasury terror finance official Matthew Levitt. “And that's Saleh al-Arouri.” 
Yet he has evaded authorities for years.  
“He knows that if he steps anywhere close, we will kill him,” a former top Israeli intelligence official until earlier this year told USA TODAY. He was on the run. You can imagine that there were several plans regarding that
column6: but it just didn't happen.”

How do you protect innocent civilians while conducting effective urban military operations against an enemy who is integrated into the civilian population and entrenched in a location’s infrastructure?

Israeli civilian and military decision-makers face this question anew after Hamas’ unprecedented attack from Gaza into southern Israel on Oct. 7. The explosion at a Gaza hospital on Tuesday that killed hundreds of people points up the dangers faced by civilians in an active war zone.

Israel’s initial answer to the question of how to avoid civilian casualties in Gaza was to tell more than a million Palestinian residents to flee their homes and head south. Barring an 11th-hour mass exodus from northern Gaza
column2: Israel will face the possibility of further civilian casualties.

column1: Fighting urban battles amid civilian populations is certainly an issue U.S. decision-makers have grappled with during military operations over the two decades since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11
column2: 2001. And there are lessons about protecting civilians that Israel could take from America's recent experience.

column1: Among them: Consider potential civilian losses when planning airstrikes
column2: seek improved methods of collecting and deploying intelligence
column3: and provide safe passage for civilians away from war zones.

column1: So far
column2: more than 1

column5: the moral obligation to reduce civilian harm cannot be ignored.

column2: conducted with an eye toward reducing civilian harm
column3: suggests that military effectiveness can be retained while protecting civilians and reducing damage to civilian infrastructure.

where Israel's bombs are killing scores of Palestinian families − sometimes entombing them in their collapsed homes; sometimes leaving their mutilated bodies scattered among the ruins.
On both sides of the Israel-Gaza border, faith traditions define the rules of burial. For Jews, who believe the dead must be watched until buried, and that every part of a body must be buried, the idea of an unguarded corpse is an almost unthinkable lapse. Within the Muslim tradition, the body is wrapped in a shroud and the head is positioned to face Mecca with the eyes and mouth closed.
Jadallah said he's lost nine family members to Israeli airstrikes, according to updates he's been posting on his Instagram account. He filmed himself this week as he was driving in his car. Across the back seat his father, killed in one of those Israeli strikes, lay dead.

They finally came to their senses and brought back their slick J-E-T-S logo from the 1980s in the “Legacy White” package they’ve already used to honor the “New York Sack Exchange” twice this season – including opening night. You remember, when new QB Aaron Rodgers got the win in his glorious NYJ debut. Moving forward, boys, let’s continue catching up to the Giants by also adding a home green jersey to pair with the flashback Boeing-esque sigil. After that, let’s maybe consider an entirely radical logo – which actually incorporates the silhouette of a jet fighter – and slap that on your crowns while scrapping the dopey Stealth Black helmet introduced in 2022.
When it comes to the extra uniform – forgettable throwbacks or gray Color Rush – they’ve done alternate in pretty much the most forgettable ways. Until now. Make sure you see Week 8’s Monday night game at Ford Field, when the Lions will break out their new metallic “Honolulu Blue” helmets featuring their 1960s alternate logo plus two stripes – the display effectively a nice co-brand with Ford’s famous Mustang, another icon from the ‘60s. Very cool way to commemorate what’s already becoming a memorable season between the lines for the NFC North leaders, not to mention the franchise’s 90th year as the Lions.
You could argue – and I have – no club has better unis. Not only that, since moving back to LA and updating their closets in 2020, they’ve given themselves so many mix-and-match scenarios, in addition to the royal blue and navy (with corresponding helmet lightning bolt) Color Rush options. But as much as folks used to pine for their Powder Blue alternates – which have lost just a little luster in the current iteration – now it’d be nice if the Bolts could either bring back the royal helmet with sunshine-y lightning used in the Air Coryell days, or the navy buckets with white bolts rocked by Junior Seau, LaDainian Tomlinson and so many others. (For the record, love the navy and white.)
Let’s commend them for maximizing the use – three appearances this season – of the retro red helmets and original logo with the black, white and gold striping mix meant to honor both the University of Georgia and Georgia Tech. Wouldn’t mind occasionally seeing the classic falcon on the black helmets as a callback to the Deion Sanders days, but that can wait. At least we won’t be subject to those vile gradient alternate jerseys in 2023.
Little reason to mess with something that’s practically perfect, but their deviations work well. The “Steel Curtain” era throwbacks won’t pop off the screen, but the 1970s number font style is the giveaway. Pittsburgh’s all-black Dark Knight look is among the best alternates going – especially when you consider the mistake it would be to revive some of the club’s awful appearances from yesteryear, bumblebees, shoulder swatches and whatnot.
Sunday afternoon, they’re going to roll out their new “Indiana Nights” one-off for 2023. Couple of thoughts here. They’ve added black helmets because Indy fans allegedly demanded them, and they play into the nocturnal theme – fine … aside from the fact the Colts have zero prime-time games this year. Otherwise, this is fairly boss. The secondary logo – with the state of Indiana serving as the center of the “C” for Colts on the shoulder is a plus. But the “heather pattern” used for the blue-on-blue uniform – golfers will recognize it immediately – really distinguishes this get-up.
Never too far afield, their alternates provide truly nice subtleties. They reverted to the “Purple People Eaters” days while rocking The Vikings Classic” in Week 1. And keep your eyes peeled for the perfectly pleasing and pristine purple-and-gold alternates.

The white Color Rush and white throwback jersey (with silver numbers) they’ve utilized in recent years are totally ... fine. But there’s a real opportunity to take their sinister look to a new
column5: Darth Vader-caliber level a few times a year. Black pants? Black helmets with a chrome Raiders shield? Seriously
column6: Mark Davis
column7: what are we waiting for here? Commit to uniform excellence!

column1: Pulling on the red pants is as frisky as they get
column2: so no alternates or throwbacks to assess. And a team based in K.C. has little reason to dust off its long-ago Dallas Texans roots. As far as anything in the pipeline? “I think we have a very distinct brand with the red and white
column3: and I don’t anticipate steering away from that any time soon
column4: ” owner Clark Hunt revealed this year
column5: saying he also wanted to honor the wishes of his later father – AFL and team founder Lamar Hunt – who wanted uniform continuity. Welp
column6: it wins.

column1: Indianapolis Colts quarterback Anthony Richardson will indeed undergo shoulder surgery that will end his rookie season after just four games. Team owner Jim Irsay made the announcement Wednesday.
The news doesn't come as a surprise after Irsay told ESPN on Monday that Richardson would "probably" miss the rest of the regular season
column2: with surgery possible in the next week or so. Richardson suffered a reported Grade 3 AC joint sprain in his shoulder during a Week 5 win over the Tennessee Titans and was placed on injured reserve last week.

column1: The No. 4 overall pick in April's NFL draft missed two games and left two others early as the Colts have gotten off to a 3-3 start.

After consultation with our medical staff, Anthony, and those close to him, it has been determined that he will undergo surgery to repair his injured shoulder, which will end his season, Irsay said in a statement. "Anthony is a competitor
column2: and we know how difficult and disappointing this is for him and our team.

column1: We collected several medical opinions and we felt this was the best course of action for his long-term health. We anticipate a full recovery and there is no doubt Anthony has a promising future.

column1: EXETER
column2: N.H. — Many candidates in the Republican presidential field are calling for a new generation of leaders in Washington. Former Vice President Mike Pence isn’t one of them.

column1: “It’s not a time for on-the-job training
column2: ” he told a crowd of New Hampshire voters at a town hall sponsored by the USA TODAY Network last week
column3: repeating an argument he’s made time and again on the 2024 campaign trail.

column1: “I’m running for president because
column2: and I do say this with all humility
column3: I’m the most qualified
column4: tested and ready conservative seeking the Republican nomination”

column1: Pence has pitched a more traditional brand of conservatism than other candidates in the race that's focused on Republican values
column2: fiscal responsibility and a strong U.S. military presence. Once deputy to former President Donald Trump
column3: Pence also has offered strong rebukes of his ex-running mate's populist style
column4: arguing it is "unmoored to conservative principles.”

column1: But that argument doesn’t appear to be resonating with voters in the Granite State
column2: or across the country. A recent Suffolk University survey
column3: conducted in partnership with The Boston Globe and USA TODAY
column4: showed Pence at just 1% in New Hampshire.

column1: At the national level
column2: Pence is doing slightly better. A Morning Consult survey on the race
column3: fielded between Oct. 13 and 15
column4: showed Pence at 6% – over 40 points behind Trump. He's also trailing GOP contenders like former United Nations Ambassador Nikki Haley
column5: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy.

column1: So
column2: how is Pence attempting to win over voters? Here’s a look at the priorities he outlined in New Hampshire that would impact Americans coast to coast if the former vice president is elected to the White House.

column1: When it comes to balancing the federal budget and reducing the national debt
column2: Pence has called for reforming mandatory spending programs like Social Security and Medicare – at least for some Americans.

column1: “I’d say to everybody that’s got hair the same color as me
column2: this doesn’t affect you ... we’re not going to make changes to the deal
column3: ” the one-time talk radio host told voters in New Hampshire.

column1: For Americans under age 40
column2: however
column3: Pence said he would opt to privatize Social Security by allowing young workers to invest their payroll taxes into savings accounts. He insisted that the plan would give American workers twice what they earn from Social Security.

column1: The idea has been floated before by members of the Republican Party
column2: most prominently during former President George W. Bush's administration. But it has never garnered enough support in Congress to become a reality for Americans.

column1: As the war between Israel and Hamas rages on
column2: Pence in New Hampshire pledged to unequivocally support Israel
column3: calling the country “our most cherished ally.”

column1: “We’ll make it clear to Hezbollah and Lebanon
column2: to Iran and any other powers in the region
column3: that everybody needs to stand down
column4: ” Pence said. “We’re going to defend Israel.”

column1: During the Trump administration
column2: Pence helped negotiate the Abraham Accords
column3: a bilateral agreement signed by Israel
column4: the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain in 2020 to normalize relations. However
column5: at the town hall
column6: Pence noted that facilitating further peace talks likely wouldn’t be a priority under his administration
column7: given the ongoing war.

column1: “It feels to me like real progress is going to have to take a second chair to Israel doing what it needs to do
column2: ” he said.

column1: Pence offered similarly strong words on other issues of U.S. national security
column2: including ongoing efforts to bolster Ukraine in its war against Russia.

column1: When asked about his views on allocating U.S. taxpayer dollars to aid foreign conflicts
column2: he argued that it’s among the most powerful ways America can stave off future aggression by countries like China.

column1: “China has made no secret of the fact that they would like to grab Taiwan
column2: ” Pence said. The Chinese government views the East Asian island as an extension of its territory and in recent years has ramped up military activity around its shores.

column1: Describing the growing superpower as “the greatest economic and strategic threat facing the U.S.
column2: ” Pence told New Hampshire voters that
column3: as president
column4: he would push to implement tariffs on Chinese goods and expand U.S. military presence in the South China Sea to defend American interests in the region.

column1: “The way we deal with China is not by diminishing our commitment to the Asia-Pacific. It’s by increasing our commitment
column2: ” Pence argued. A strong defense strategy would pave the way toward “a peaceful future with China and progress for the Chinese people
column3: ” he said.

column1: CONCORD
column2: N.H.−It’s a “really bad day” for former President Donald Trump
column3: according to GOP presidential hopeful Chris Christie.

column1: That’s because Sidney Powell
column2: Trump’s former attorney
column3: pled guilty Thursday to six misdemeanor charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election results in Georgia.

column1: Under the terms of the agreement
column2: Powell will serve a six-year probation
column3: pay a fine of $6
column4: 000 and testify at the trials of several co-defendants in the case. She also agreed to write an apology letter to Georgia residents.

column1: “The interesting part of that plea is that she will be testifying against Mark Meadows
column2: against Rudy Giuliani
column3: against Donald Trump
column4: ” Christie told reporters shortly after filling to put his name on the ballot in New Hampshire’s first-in-the-nation primary. “You don't give a no-jail plea deal unless that person's got something very good to say that will help your case against the others.”

column1: Powell was among 19 defendants named in Fulton County
column2: Georgia District Attorney Fani Willis’ Georgia election interference case
column3: which also included Trump.

column1: “I did this for seven years in the fifth largest office in the country
column2: said Christie, who served as the U.S. attorney in New Jersey from January 2002 to December 2008. You don't give a no-jail plea deal unless that person's got something very good to say that will help your case against the others."

column1: After 31 long years of waiting
column2: a woman from New York has stepped forward to share with local lottery officials she was the person who never claimed $12 million from a 1991 Lotto jackpot.

column1: Janet Valenti
column2: age 77
column3: revealed that she was the rightful owner of a $12 million New York Lotto jackpot that sat unclaimed for over 30 years.

column1: One small mistake led to the unfortunate fate of the ticket
column2: and there was nothing she could do to retrieve it.

column1: Valenti claimed she had the winning lottery ticket worth $12 million sitting on an end table next to her couch
column2: among other lottery tickets
column3: according to the Lottery Post. She believed she had previously checked all the tickets on the table
column4: so as she was preparing to leave her home with her two teenage children and mother to spend the weekend at a friend's house
column5: she threw the tickets in the trash. That was back in July of 1991.

column1: Over the weekend
column2: she was unaware of her huge mistake. When she returned
column3: a friend informed her of a winning $12 million Lotto ticket sold in Staten Island. Valenti discovered she had won after seeing the winning numbers in the paper.

column1: Upon arriving home
column2: she rushed to retrieve her ticket from the garbage
column3: but could not find it.

column1: My next-door neighbor, who has never in her life, the whole time I lived there, ever put my garbage out for collection, she did, Valenti told the Lottery.
She couldn't go digging in the trash due to sanitation already picking up the garbage. It was over
column2: Valenti was out that $12 million.

column1: The woman from Staten Island attempted to contact lawyers but was informed that the only way to claim the prize was with a physical lottery ticket. Even obtaining surveillance footage from the retailer would be of no use.
I was a wreck, Valenti recalled to the Lottery. "I was sick for a long time over it."
On July 17
column3: the $12 million Lotto jackpot went unclaimed and was returned to the state lottery fund. This unclaimed prize holds the record for being the largest in New York's history.

column1: Valenti was a single mother to her two teenage children
column2: Kevin and Jennifer
column3: at the time. Her husband
column4: Bruno
column5: had passed away in 1984. To cope with the incident
column6: she turned to reading stories about "lottery curses"
column7: infamous stories of people whose lives took a turn for the worse after winning the Lottery. This helped her from losing her mind over the situation.

column1: Given that kind of money, things can go bad, Valenti told the Lottery. "That was a saving grace. Who knows what would have happened if I'd had that money? You read these stories
column2: a lot of people win Lotto
column3: they drop dead. Maybe it was [Bruno] looking out for us to not have that kind of money."

column1: Despite her tremendous loss over 30 years ago
column2: Valenti remains steadfast in her pursuit of playing the Lottery.

column1: The most I ever get is a free play or a couple of dollars, she said. "That's it."

column2: 000 from Powerball and $2 million from scratch-off game

column1: Someone won $12 million in Lotto on July 17
column3: with a ticket purchased for $1 at J.N.J. Delicatessen in Graniteville. Despite holding the winning numbers (2
column7: and 51) the winner never claimed the prize. Carolina Cutroneo
column8: the store owner
column9: asked customers if they had the ticket for a year following the win.

column1: I think somebody, when they saw they'd won, died or never found out in the first place, she had said at the time. "In the beginning
column2: we were putting up signs every day
column3: but no one came forward. It's probably somebody who really needs it."

column1: According to New York Lottery spokesperson Bill Knowlton
column2: the big prize winner could have been a visitor to the state or someone unfamiliar with playing the Lottery in New York. Knowlton also explained that some winners may wait to claim their prize because they are in the process of assembling an advisory team or they forget to do so.

column1: According to Knowlton

column1: A trendy Barcelona bar decorated in pastel pink and green hues has been named the world’s best bar of 2023.
Sips
column2: located in the heart of Barcelona’s L'Antiga Esquerra de l'Eixample district has not only earned the title of best in the world
column3: but also best in Europe
column4: according to this year’s The World’s 50 Best Bars list
column5: an annual ranking of bars determined by the votes of 680 drinks experts from across the globe.

column1: Don’t be fooled by the cozy interior
column2: Sips can turn into a “a dark and sultry hideaway” as soon as the sun begins to set. Esencia
column3: a bar inside the bar offers customers a wine tasting experience of sorts that breaks down the signature cocktails they offer in sips.

column1: There is the off chance that any one of their “wondrous creations” may be served in a metal cast of two hands
column2: or a glass
column3: depending on how colorful the cocktail
column4: of course.

column1: This is the second year in a row that a Barcelona bar has taken possession of the top spot.

When we started Sips, we strongly believed that the bar was a beacon name itself. The drinks, music and the architecture of the bar itself are like 'little drops that fill the glass,' creating an experience that is unique to Sips,” Marc Álvarez, co-founder of Sips shared with CNBC.
Honorees from 28 different cities around the world were recognized at a live awards ceremony in Singapore on Tuesday, marking the first time the ceremony has been held in Asia. 
Double Chicken Please in New York City was named second best for the first time, while Handshake Speakeasy in Mexico City took third place. 
The U.S. tied with England for most bars on the list, with a total of five U.S.-based bars included. Three of the bars named are in New York City. Café La Trova in Miami came in 24th place, while New Orleans bar Jewel of the South ranked 49 out of 50. 
Mexico City follows the U.S. and London closely, with four bars making the list. Argentina and Singapore were the countries with the third most number of winning bars with three wins each. 
Other special awards include the Roku Industry Icon awarded to Renato Tato" Giovannoni of Florería Atlántico in Buenos Aires and The Ketel One Sustainable Bar Award bestowed upon Röda Huset in Stockholm
column2: among many other awards presented that night.

For some
column2: giving gifts is a way to show how well you know the birthday honoree. If you
column3: your friend or loved one is born in November
column4: you'll want to know each of its symbols if you want to give the perfect November birthday gift.

column1: People born in November can have one of two astrological signs: Scorpio (born between November 1 and 21) or Sagittarius (born between November 22 and 30). The chrysanthemum also represents those born in November.
But what about November's birthstone? Each month has at least one gemstone. Here's what you need to know about November's birthstones
column2: including their colors
column3: symbolism and more.

column1: Topaz and citrine are the two birthstones for November.
Topaz comes in an array of colors
column2: such as blue
column3: yellow
column4: orange
column5: pink
column6: violet
column7: red and brown.

column1: The name is believed to derive from the Sanskrit word "tapas
column2: meaning fire"
column3: according to the Geological Institute of America
column4: which is fitting since one of the gem's best known forms is yellow. Others
column5: however
column6: believe topaz gets its name from the Greek word "topazos"
column7: states the International Gem Society. Another popular topaz variety is blue.

column1: Topaz is mostly mined in Brazil and northwestern Pakistan
column2: states GIA. Other countries that mine topaz include Namibia
column3: Nigeria
column4: Madagascar
column5: Mexico
column6: Myanmar
column7: Sri Lanka and the U.S.

column1: Historically
column2: pink-orange topaz was popular among royalty. This is no surprise since the stone is often referred to as "Imperial topaz." The nickname is said to originate from the Russian royal family's usage of the stone
column3: according to GIA. Another justification is thanks to Brazilian Emperor Pedro II being gifted the gem in 1881.

column1: This birthstone is believed to symbolize wealth and health. The ancient Greeks thought topaz brought strength. For centuries in India
column2: wearing topaz above your heart meant a long life
column3: beauty and intelligence. Yellow topaz
column4: in particular
column5: is said to attract wealth since its color "represents the riches of gold"
column6: according to IGS.

column1: Besides being the birthstone for November
column2: blue topaz is given for the fourth wedding anniversary
column3: while Imperial topaz is for the twenty-third wedding anniversary.

column1: Citrine is a type quartz
column2: with its colors ranging from yellow to brown-orange. Its name originates from the French word "citron
column3: meaning lemon
column4:
states IGS.
Most citrine comes from the heat treatment of amethyst, according to GIA. The gem can be found in Bolivia, Spain, Madagascar, Mexico and Uruguay.
As for its history, citrine dates back to the ancient Greeks and Romans. The Greeks made ornaments from the stone, while Roman pontiffs wore rings made of citrine and amethyst, states GIA. Additionally, Scottish jewelry from the Victorian era often utilized citrine.
The stone is associated with happiness and joy, according to IGS. It is seen as a success stone" and is said to bring prosperity. Citrine is also believed to affect the wearer's mood and calm them
column5: states GIA.

column1: Citrine is given as a gift for the thirteenth wedding anniversary.

column1: There’s no contest: people love condiments. From ketchup
column2: to mayo to mustard
column3: condiments are a way to enhance flavors and textures that make an already great dish even better. We love to spread our favorite condiments on sandwiches
column4: hot dogs
column5: burgers and even pizza. (By now you’re either enraged or nodding along.)

column1: Diets have often demonized condiments because they can add calories
column2: sugar and fat to a dish. But we want to hone in on one condiment in particular – mustard. Should mustard be lumped in with all condiments or does mustard offer unique benefits? We spoke with Lon Ben-Asher
column3: MS
column4: RD
column5: LD/N
column6: Registered Nutritionist and educator at Pritikin Longevity Center to find out everything you need to know about mustard.

column1: First
column2: it’s worth mentioning that there are many different types of mustard. When you think of mustard
column3: you most likely think of yellow mustard – the traditional bright yellow smooth paste that’s commonly zig-zagged on top of hot dogs and sandwiches. Other less common types of mustard include spicy mustard
column4: dijon mustard and honey mustard.

column1: Yellow mustard
column2: spicy mustard and dijon mustard all have very similar nutritional profiles. They are low in calories
column3: sugar and fat
column4: which makes them an excellent addition to a dish
column5: especially if the goal is weight management. Ben-Asher explains
column6: “Mustard can be utilized as a condiment which is low in calories and can help with weight management/control by enhancing flavor as an alternative to many high-calorie sauces
column7: marinades and dressings.”

column1: Honey mustard
column2: on the other hand
column3: is a little bit different. Although its flavor balances sweetness with acidity in a harmonic way
column4: it does add a little bit more calories
column5: fat and sugar to your meal. One serving (1 tbsp) of yellow mustard
column6: for example
column7: has 9.2 calories
column8: and negligible fat and sugar. One serving (1 tbsp) of honey mustard contains 69.5 calories
column9: 6 grams of fat
column10: and 2.4 grams of sugar. These statistics do not make honey mustard off limits
column11: it’s just something you need to be mindful of.

column1: It turns out that mustard is packed with helpful nutrients. Ben-Asher says
column2: “Mustard provides nutritional value as well by its mineral composition of selenium and magnesium
column3: which are important for many systemic functions.”

column1: The powerful potential of mustard:How to use the condiment as an ingredient instead
According to the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health

column1: Taking supplements can be scary
column2: especially when you don’t really know what is inside.

column1: Melatonin is no different
column2: especially because it is regulated as a dietary supplement
column3: which is given considerably less oversight than medications
column4: according to the National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (NIH).

column1: In fact
column2: some melatonin supplements may not reflect the label accurately
column3: according to the NIH. A study in 2017 tested different melatonin supplements and found that the amount of melatonin in the product did not match what on the product label.

column1: So
column2: is melatonin safe? Here are your unanswered questions
column3: answered.

column1: Generally
column2: yes.

column1: Melatonin is a natural hormone that your body produces to help regulate the sleep/wake cycle
column2: according to Dr. Hal Alpert
column3: telemedicine consultant for Blue Sleep.

column1: Melatonin levels are highest at the age of three
column2: and they steadily decrease with age. For example
column3: a 70-year-old will have about 25% of the melatonin level that a teenager has
column4: according to Alpert.

column1: That being said
column2: if a person's natural melatonin levels are not very high
column3: the supplement can assist them to fall asleep quicker at the beginning of the night
column4: said Alpert.

column1: “There's always been this potential concern that if we're replacing something that's naturally occurring or using something that's naturally occurring
column2: will our bodies stop producing the naturally occurring substance?” said  Dr. Michelle Drerup
column3: Director of Behavioral Sleep Medicine at the Cleveland Clinic. “There's no evidence that supports that.”

column1: However
column2: just like every supplement
column3: there are some side effects that can be caused by melatonin.

column1: How long does melatonin last?:What to know about the sleep aid supplement
While it is rare to have any side effects from the popular supplement
column2: it is possible.

column1: Risks are involved with higher dosages
column2: said Alpert. It is best to start lower and go higher if needed
column3: with 10 milligrams being the maximum safe amount.

column1: These are some of the side effects to be aware of
column2: according to Alpert:

column1: Melatonin can also interfere with other drugs
column2: so it is important to talk to your physician about the medication you are on and the safety of using melatonin as well
column3: said Alpert.

column1: Did you know that roughly 1 in 3 adults have insomnia? According to the Cleveland Clinic
column2: 10% of adults fit the criteria for an insomnia disorder.

column1: Many people who suffer from insomnia and sleep disorders turn to supplements like melatonin to help them fall asleep faster
column2: but does it work?

column1: Find out how long melatonin lasts in your system
column2: how long it takes to work and how much melatonin you should take for the best night's sleep.

column1: “The half-life of melatonin is between 20 and 50 minutes
column2: so that means half of the initial dosage is eliminated after that amount of time
column3: ” explained Dr. Michelle Drerup
column4: Director of Behavioral Sleep Medicine at the Cleveland Clinic. “So
column5: it would stay in your system around four to five hours.”

column1: Melatonin does not do much for the body in terms of helping people stay asleep
column2: if any effect occurs it has to do with initially falling asleep
column3: said Drerup.

column1: Is melatonin safe?:What to know about the supplement
Melatonin should be taken about two to four hours before your desired sleeping time
column2: said Dr. Hal Alpert
column3: a telemedicine consultant at Blue Sleep. Additionally
column4: it is best not to drive for at least five hours after taking melatonin due to its lasting sedative effects.

column1: “[Melatonin] is a hormone that signals that it's time to go to sleep and light exposure
column2: particularly blue light from computers
column3: cell phones
column4: and fluorescent lights will inhibit the release of melatonin
column5: ” explained Alpert. “That is why for people who have insomnia it is best not to use these devices for at least four hours or so before bedtime.”

column1: A starting dose of melatonin can be as low as .1 to .3 milligrams and the usual over-the-counter dosage is one to three milligrams in adults
column2: said Alpert.

column1: “The maximum safe dose is up to 10 milligrams
column2: but it's shown that once you get to three milligrams
column3: the higher doses don't get you to sleep any faster than the three-milligram dosage
column4: ” explained Alpert.
