column1: “People throw rocks at things that shine.”
That lyric flashed through my head as I read a recent opinion column claiming that Taylor Swift “has yet to make a significant mark as a philanthropist
column2: ” and that her estimated $4 billion Eras Tour earnings are a chance for the singer to champion left-leaning causes in honor of her fans.

column1: As Swifties know
column2: though
column3: this dismissive characterization of the 12-time Grammy Award winner’s charitable giving is anything but perfectly fine. Swift has a mind of her own
column4: and she’s not afraid to use it. Her approach to philanthropy is no exception.

column1: Map out Swift’s philanthropy and one finds the singer’s empathetic approach to giving is deeply personal and powerful
column2: transcending political divides. That includes her support of friends
column3: cancer patients
column4: sexual assault survivors
column5: disaster relief organizations and food banks along her Eras Tour. The list goes on.

column1: 'Eras' movie shows women have options:In 'Eras Tour' movie
column2: Taylor Swift shows women how to reject the mandate of one identity

column1: Take her steady support of friends who have fallen on hard times. Swift
column2: for example
column3: loaned her New York City home to Sophie Turner amid the “Game of Thrones” star’s divorce from Joe Jonas and gifted Kesha $250
column4: 000 after a judge ruled against the singer in a civil court case.

column1: What’s more
column2: after Swift won a countersuit against former country music DJ David Mueller
column3: who groped her during a red-carpet event in 2013
column4: “The Man” singer pledged money to the Joyful Heart Foundation
column5: a nonprofit that helps counsel sexual assault survivors.

column1: Perhaps the most personal of Swift’s charitable giving
column2: however
column3: is her ongoing support of those fighting cancer
column4: just as both of Swift’s parents have battled cancer – an experience Swift writes about in “Soon You’ll Get Better
column5: ” a deep track on her "Lover" album.

column1: Rather than make splashy
column2: polarizing donations to Planned Parenthood
column3: as fellow artists Harry Styles and Lizzo have done
column4: Swift speaks up about important policy concerns but stops short of big politicized left-leaning donations – perhaps out of respect for her more traditional fans.

column1: Swift rose to fame as a country singer
column2: securing the admiration of more moderate women who found escape in songs like “Love Story” and “Ours
column3: ” in which Swift sings about prioritizing love
column4: marriage and the allusion of family life over a depressing 9-to-5 cubicle job.

column1: Yet
column2: since her transition to pop superstardom and amassing a global following
column3: Swift has done a remarkable job of staying true to her progressive values without overly politicizing her brand. Her focus
column4: instead
column5: is on connecting with her fans – whether from a stage or a hospital room.

column1: Republicans should fear Swifties:Taylor Swift has power to swing the presidential election. What if nothing else matters?
What’s more
column2: it’s reasonable to assume that a singer savvy enough to question the legitimacy of FTX
column3: a now bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange
column4: has already mapped out her philanthropic goals.

column1: In fact
column2: Swift could already be donating to the left-leaning groups that some people want her to give to
column3: but – for a variety of reasons – does so privately
column4: which is her prerogative and part of her constitutional right to free speech.

column1: Whatever direction Swift decides to tack with her charitable giving – now or in the future – her decision likely will be personally driven
column2: intentional and an extension of her already significant mark on the world of philanthropy. And
column3: most important
column4: the decision will be entirely her own.

column1: Carolyn Bolton is the communications and marketing director for DonorsTrust
column2: a giving-account provider based in Alexandria
column3: Virginia.

column1: How do you protect innocent civilians while conducting effective urban military operations against an enemy who is integrated into the civilian population and entrenched in a location’s infrastructure?

Israeli civilian and military decision-makers face this question anew after Hamas’ unprecedented attack from Gaza into southern Israel on Oct. 7. The explosion at a Gaza hospital on Tuesday that killed hundreds of people points up the dangers faced by civilians in an active war zone.

Israel’s initial answer to the question of how to avoid civilian casualties in Gaza was to tell more than a million Palestinian residents to flee their homes and head south. Barring an 11th-hour mass exodus from northern Gaza
column2: Israel will face the possibility of further civilian casualties.

column1: Fighting urban battles amid civilian populations is certainly an issue U.S. decision-makers have grappled with during military operations over the two decades since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11
column2: 2001. And there are lessons about protecting civilians that Israel could take from America's recent experience.

column1: Among them: Consider potential civilian losses when planning airstrikes
column2: seek improved methods of collecting and deploying intelligence
column3: and provide safe passage for civilians away from war zones.

column1: So far
column2: more than 1
column3: 400 Israeli civilians and nearly 4
column4: 000 Palestinian civilians have been killed in the latest conflict. Despite the ferocity of the Hamas attack and the Israeli response
column5: the moral obligation to reduce civilian harm cannot be ignored.

column1: Urban battles are not unusual occurrences in the Middle East. The U.S.-led battle against the Islamic State terrorist organization for Raqqa
column2: Syria
column3: in 2017 provides parallels to the Gaza conflict in terms of environment
column4: adversary and humanitarian implications.

column1: Our research on that ISIS conflict
column2: conducted with an eye toward reducing civilian harm
column3: suggests that military effectiveness can be retained while protecting civilians and reducing damage to civilian infrastructure.

column1: Operating in densely populated urban environments is incredibly difficult even for experienced military units such as the Israel Defense Forces
column2: which have operated in Gaza before. Hamas
column3: not unlike ISIS
column4: has a history of using civilian infrastructure as a defense against Israeli military operations.

column1: Hamas invaded my brother's home.Now my family is held hostage in Gaza.
Organizations like ISIS and Hamas know their adversaries are committed to reducing civilian harm and take advantage of this adherence to international law and norms. Before the Battle of Raqqa
column2: the coalition along with Syrian Defense Forces partners initially encircled the city to weaken ISIS fighters rather than allowing them to escape to the next stronghold. However
column3: this also prevented the departure of civilian Raqqa residents.

column1: In Syria
column2: ISIS tactical facilities were often located near civilian infrastructure
column3: requiring individual strike decisions to consider ways to minimize civilian harm. Such considerations could help reduce civilian casualties in Gaza as well
column4: though civilian deaths and infrastructure damage can never be eliminated
column5: even with precision weapons. In Raqqa
column6: collateral damage to infrastructure made recovery and reconstruction operations difficult and time consuming.

column1: Urban fighting in a location you do not control
column2: especially when reliant upon air support
column3: also makes it difficult to collect
column4: verify and share real-time intelligence.

column1: In Syria
column2: intelligence efforts were hampered by civilians moving across Raqqa to escape bombardments
column3: searching for shelter
column4: food and new places to live. This also is now true in the Gaza Strip
column5: one of the most densely populated geographies in the world.

column1: I've seen firsthand the oppression:I'm a Palestinian American. I almost gave up hope people will see the humanity in us.
An enhanced focus on the task of gathering and leveraging intelligence is critical
column2: despite the many challenges facing the Israeli intelligence services in Gaza. An examination of U.S. intelligence shortcomings in Syria suggests the need for improved intelligence-specific tradecraft and training
column3: enhanced efforts to gather and validate open-source information and improved civilian casualty assessments.

column1: In Syria
column2: the U.S.-led coalition acted on the advice of the Syrian Defense Forces and opened humanitarian corridors out of Raqqa as the battle lasted longer than expected. This was critical for evacuations of civilians and reducing civilian deaths.

column1: While concerns persisted over the possibility of escaping ISIS fighters who could regroup in other locations
column2: the corridors reduced the civilian injury and death toll in Raqqa and its environs.

column1: Similar escape routes could save civilian lives in Gaza as well
column2: though the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt is now damaged and closed
column3: according to aid workers. This leaves residents of Gaza trapped and unable to escape the aerial bombardment from Israel.

column1: Israel’s new demand that civilians flee applies to northern Gaza
column2: but southern Gaza lacks the infrastructure to support the additional civilians
column3: who would still remain trapped.

column1: The United States regularly encourages all partners to limit civilian harm during conflict
column2: including in current hotspots such as Ukraine. Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s statements during his visit to Tel Aviv and Arab capitals
column3: along with efforts to open the Rafah border crossing for humanitarian aid and evacuations
column4: reminded the global community of the rules-based order and the criticality of shielding innocent civilians during conflict.

column1: One of the distinctions between the international community and organizations such as Hamas and ISIS is its commitment to reducing and limiting civilian harm during conflict. While extracting vengeance through an eye-for-eye approach may seem legitimate
column2: even necessary
column3: in the moment
column4: listening to better angels could help reduce civilian harm in the long run.

column1: Karen M. Sudkamp
column2: a national security researcher at the nonprofit and nonpartisan RAND Corporation
column3: spent more than a decade in the U.S. intelligence community supporting military counterterrorism operations.

column1: As usual
column2: it’s a great day to not be former president and current criminal defendant Donald J. Trump.

column1: Sidney Powell – his former legal adviser
column2: fellow champion of the gargantuan and ongoing “rigged election” lie and co-defendant in the sweeping Georgia election interference case – pleaded guilty Thursday and agreed to testify against others involved in the alleged conspiracy.

column1: The word “others” is important
column2: as it may well include Trump
column3: the far-and-away leading GOP presidential primary candidate who
column4: one imagines
column5: is presently hurling all available ketchup at the walls of his Mar-a-Lago pout room.

column1: Powell was known among Trump fanatics and election conspiracy theorists as the person who would “release the Kraken” and unleash unassailable evidence the election was rigged
column2: righteously returning Trump to the White House. In a Nov. 24
column4: Fox Business interview with Lou Dobbs
column5: Powell said of the election
column6: "There's no way there was anything but widespread election fraud here."

column1: She has now pleaded guilty to six misdemeanor counts of conspiracy to commit intentional interference of election duties and been sentenced to six years of probation.
She also has to pay some fines and write an apology letter to the people of Georgia
column2: which is quite the thing when you consider the unbridled conviction with which she lied to the American public
column3: often via Fox News appearances
column4: about the 2020 presidential election being “stolen” from Trump.

column1: Trump's Georgia arrest isn't an anomaly:Take a good look at Trump's booking photo
column2: Republicans. That's your GOP.

column1: Powell's unhinged conspiracies were featured prominently in Dominion Voting Systems successful lawsuit against Fox News
column2: and she's facing her own $1.3 billion defamation lawsuit from the company as well.

column1: It appears the Kraken may not be all she was cracked up to be. Worse yet for the MAGA crowd
column2: said Kraken will now be released in Trump’s direction.

column1: Duly flipped
column2: Powell will undoubtedly help Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis’ case against other defendants like former Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani and the former president himself
column3: as she was central to much of the hysterical lying and scheming that transpired after Joe Biden won the presidency fair and square.

column1: In a Nov. 14
column3: tweet
column4: Trump hailed Powell as part of his “truly great team” of lawyers.

column1: Powell was part of an election conspiracy news conference held at the Republican National Committee headquarters on Nov. 19
column3: an event made famous largely because Giuliani was sweating so profusely that hair dye ran down the side of his face.

column1: At the news conference
column2: Powell said: “What we are really dealing with here and uncovering more by the day is the massive influence of communist money through Venezuela
column3: Cuba and likely China and the interference with our elections here in the United States.”

column1: People with even a pinky toe still dipped in the pool of reality knew at the time that was nonsense
column2: but it's clear from her guilty plea that Powell knew it was nonsense as well.

column1: She went to meet with Trump at the White House on Dec. 18
column3: and talked about declaring a national emergency and having the president order the military to seize certain voting machines.

column1: How long until Trump breaks gag order?Trump
column2: who never shuts up
column3: now has a gag order to whine about. And you know he will.

column1: It’s easy to write Powell off as a conspiratorial crackpot
column2: but they were all conspiratorial crackpots
column3: and she marched side by side with Giuliani and Trump.

column1: So the Kraken pleading guilty does three significant things:
For all her zany nonsense – which was featured over and over on Fox News in the wake of the 2020 election
column2: helping brainwash a sizable swath of the populace – Powell was sane enough to know when to save her own hide.

column1: Asked by the judge Thursday whether she believes “there are enough facts that support this plea of guilty
column2: ” Powell responded: “I do.”

column1: That’s one of the first honest things she has said in a long time. And it pulls the curtain all the way back on the scam Trump and his cronies have been running since the day he lost the 2020 election.

column1: We found room for both hope and pessimism in a recent free expression survey that the University of Chicago helped develop with The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research. One of the most worrying results was that not everyone is seen as having the same freedom to speak their minds on college campuses.
People said conservatives had the least freedom to speak
column2: but they perceived problems of exclusion beyond just one group. Asian people also were seen as having less freedom of expression than other groups
column3: and respondents said campuses did the worst at providing an inclusive environment for conservatives
column4: visiting speakers
column5: Asian people and transgender people.

column1: We see related problems for campus expression as people respond to the tragedies of the Israel-Hamas war. Many students don’t feel free to express their views
column2: and some universities risk chilling discussions on their campuses by taking collective positions
column3: sending the message that there is one “official” stance and other opinions are not welcome.

column1: That is a troubling trend in our polarized times. We face huge challenges as a society
column2: and we can’t address them fully if people at colleges and universities – our greatest engines of new thinking and innovation – do not feel free to challenge each other and pursue ideas and breakthroughs wherever they lead.

column1: Sadly
column2: just as the need for new knowledge and discovery becomes more acute
column3: universities have been riddled with challenges to free inquiry from all ideological factions. We find ourselves in something of a moral panic
column4: from which neither the left nor the right is immune.

column1: But we also see signs that the tide is turning
column2: and fast. Our survey found heartening public support for many aspects of free expression
column3: including bipartisan resistance to state restrictions on what professors at public universities can teach.

column1: Among the encouraging stands that universities are taking on free expression
column2: Cornell University in Ithaca
column3: New York
column4: this year rejected a call for mandatory trigger warnings for potentially offensive course content. In Northern California
column5: Stanford Law Dean Jenny Martinez
column6: who wrote an articulate defense of free expression after the disruption of a talk by U.S. Circuit Judge Kyle Duncan
column7: was appointed provost of the university.

column1: Many schools – including our own – are launching new free inquiry and expression initiatives
column2: while others have adopted the “Chicago Principles” on free expression.

column1: Biden is too old. And so is Trump.As a Gen Z voter
column2: I want younger candidates.

column1: Such bold moves are critical
column2: but they go only so far. To realize the potential of free inquiry we need an active shift in campus culture.

column1: The project of free inquiry and expression is about much more than solitary acts of expression – it’s about unlocking the power of discovery and knowledge in the context of an academic community to address major challenges and promote the flourishing of knowledge.
Freedom of expression on college campuses is not the same as an absence of personal constraint on speech
column2: nor is it grounded primarily on the First Amendment.

column1: Universities are crucibles of truth-seeking
column2: for faculties and students alike. To advance that ideal
column3: they must be places where students and scholars are challenged by alternative viewpoints.

column1: Don't let Israel-Hamas war divide US.We need to cooperate across our differences.
Universities have it in their power to take concrete steps to build stronger cultures of free inquiry and expression
column2: including:

column1: Despite the challenges to free inquiry
column2: we remain enthusiastic about the breakthroughs of human ingenuity and discovery that our colleges and universities will yet make possible. They can’t happen soon enough.

column1: Combining the remarkable burgeoning activity across the higher education landscape with the creativity and passion of Generation Z makes for a very bright future.
Doubling down on free inquiry and expression is the key. Without it
column2: universities will lose all that makes them distinctive.

column1: Tom Ginsburg is a professor of law at the University of Chicago and the inaugural faculty director of the university’s Forum for Free Inquiry and Expression; Tony Banout is the forum’s inaugural executive director.

column2: to mayo to mustard

column4: hot dogs
column5: burgers and even pizza. (By now you’re either enraged or nodding along.)

column1: Diets have often demonized condiments because they can add calories
column2: sugar and fat to a dish. But we want to hone in on one condiment in particular – mustard. Should mustard be lumped in with all condiments or does mustard offer unique benefits? We spoke with Lon Ben-Asher
column3: MS
column4: RD

column6: Registered Nutritionist and educator at Pritikin Longevity Center to find out everything you need to know about mustard.

column1: First

column1: Yellow mustard
column2: spicy mustard and dijon mustard all have very similar nutritional profiles. They are low in calories
column3: sugar and fat
column4: which makes them an excellent addition to a dish
column5: especially if the goal is weight management. Ben-Asher explains
column6: “Mustard can be utilized as a condiment which is low in calories and can help with weight management/control by enhancing flavor as an alternative to many high-calorie sauces
column7: marinades and dressings.”

column1: Honey mustard
column2: on the other hand
column3: is a little bit different. Although its flavor balances sweetness with acidity in a harmonic way

column5: fat and sugar to your meal. One serving (1 tbsp) of yellow mustard
column6: for example
column7: has 9.2 calories
column8: and negligible fat and sugar. One serving (1 tbsp) of honey mustard contains 69.5 calories
column9: 6 grams of fat
column10: and 2.4 grams of sugar. These statistics do not make honey mustard off limits
column11: it’s just something you need to be mindful of.

column1: It turns out that mustard is packed with helpful nutrients. Ben-Asher says
column2: “Mustard provides nutritional value as well by its mineral composition of selenium and magnesium
column3: which are important for many systemic functions.”

column5: and even the creation of DNA.

column3: “In addition
column4: mustard seeds contain antioxidant compounds called glucosinolates
column5: which help protect cells from oxidative stress.”

column3: which can reduce inflammation and support liver function.  Mustard seeds can also support the liver’s detoxification processes and aid in eliminating toxins and other substances from the body.”

column1: “Justin definitely wasn’t happy about the pregnancy. He said we weren’t ready to have a baby in our lives

column1: Spears’ statements underscore the benefits that male partners receive from having access to abortion care — an often overlooked aspect of reproductive health in light of Roe v. Wade’s downfall last year that
column2: if ignored in society and politics alike
column3: perpetuates the idea that abortion is solely a women’s issue.

column1: “Abortion is a highly stigmatized form of healthcare

column8: who also benefit from abortion access — benefits that are rarely recognized by the broader public or policy makers.”

column1: Everett
column2: who studies the social and political implications of reproductive health
column3: said Spears' claim that Timberlake did not want to become a parent suggests he was aware that a child could “derail his career
column4: ” a reality that “men rarely publicly acknowledge” but is critical to recognize in a post-Roe world.

column1: (On June 24
column3: the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion
column4: leaving it up to states to determine its legality. Some states have since banned nearly all abortions
column5: while others have passed legislation protecting abortion access.)

column1: Timberlake has yet to publicly respond to Spears’ comments.
Andréa Becker
column2: a medical sociologist and postdoctoral research fellow with the University of California San Francisco’s Advancing New Standards in Reproductive Health program
column3: said this example is “consistent with the literature
column4: ” in that “men don’t necessarily have to come forward and tell their abortion stories if they don’t want to
column5: even though it would benefit them immensely.”

column1: This pattern is due in part to a lack of research analyzing how access to abortion impacts male partners
column2: a shortfall that Becker said “reinforces the way we talk about birth control
column3: condom use and pregnancy avoidance as a woman’s responsibility and issue.”

column1: “We just forget about the sperm involved in creating a pregnancy
column2: ” Becker said.

column1: As a result
column2: stigmas associated with abortion disproportionately impact women.

column1: “Men are rarely acknowledged as beneficiaries from abortion access so it is much easier for them to avoid the stigma and shame around abortion if they don’t think it’s something that impacts them personally
column2: ” Everett said.

column1: Data show that 1 in 5 men in the U.S. have been involved in abortion
column2: which researchers say is likely an undercount. It's estimated that about 1 in 4 women in the U.S. will have an abortion by age of 45
column3: according to the Guttmacher Institute.

column1: The total number of abortions in the U.S. is difficult to measure
column2: but the most recent estimates from 2020 show that there were anywhere between 620
column5: according to data from the CDC and Guttmacher Institute. (The number of abortions in the U.S. dropped immediately after the fall of Roe v. Wade.)

column1: Meanwhile
column2: research has found that some men are hesitant to admit their involvement with abortion. In a 2022 study
column3: men were less likely to disclose the fact they were involved in an abortion during face-to-face interviews compared to an online survey.

column1: In one of the few studies to analyze how abortion impacts male partners
column2: Everett found that men who impregnated someone as a teenager were more likely to pursue post-high school education and graduate from college when the pregnancy ended in abortion compared to those that ended in live birth.

column1: More on maternal health care inequities:Inequities in maternal health care access are not new. They have deep roots in history.
“When men don’t speak up
column2: the burden of having to make decisions about unplanned pregnancies and access to abortion falls exclusively on women — and that’s an equity issue
column3: ” said Dr. Brian Nguyen
column4: an associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Southern California’s Keck School of Medicine. Nguyen runs a research group called the EMERGE Lab that conducts studies aimed at ensuring men recognize their responsibility in women’s reproductive health and gender equity.

column1: While questions still abound about what role male partners should have in the abortion landscape
column2: it’s important to recognize the general lack of knowledge about abortion in the U.S.
column3: particularly among some men
column4: Becker said. Consequently
column5: research shows many policy decisions now in place threaten the lives of women and girls who would benefit from abortion care
column6: especially for people of color
column7: migrants
column8: people with disabilities
column9: and those living on low incomes or in rural areas.

column1:
Men do have a place in advocating for reproductive rights,” Everett said. “They can donate to abortion funds and reproductive health care organizations, and, importantly, with the consent of their partners, acknowledge how abortion access has benefited them.”
This is the third story in a series exploring grief, how people face it, cope with it and heal from it.
Click here to read the first installment: This family went through an unimaginable tragedy. How YouTube helped. And here for the second: At 25 she found out she had the breast cancer gene. Now, she's grieving motherhood.
Lisa Bowman had everything going for her − until she didn't.
The now 56-year-old was the global chief marketing officer for United Way. United Way, an education, economic mobility and health-focused nonprofit, recruited her.
What should've been a dream job spiraled into a nightmare: she alleged she was sexually harassed at work, and more than 20 former employees of the company said sexual harassment
column2: discrimination and retaliation is commonplace
column3:
at the company, according to a 2021 HuffPost report. The nonprofit fired Bowman in January 2020, months after she reported the harassment. Multiple claims have been filed with the EEOC; United Way told USA TODAY it doesn't comment on matters of employment. The CEO of United Way resigned as the chaos swirled.
But Bowman didn't just lose her job. She lost much more.
The loss of my job was really that loss of my identity
column4: she says. All of a sudden
column5: I went from being Lisa Bowman
column6: CMO of the world's largest nonprofit where anybody would take my call
column7: people were beating down the door to talk to me
column8: to all of a sudden just being Lisa Bowman
column9: private citizen
column11: so to speak. And that was a really
column12: really tough thing for me to navigate."

column1: Grief doesn't apply to death alone. It comes in a series of shapes and sizes different than you might expect. And all can coexist. (You can share yours with us at the bottom of this article).
There's room enough in the world for all these losses, and one doesn't take away from the other, says David Kessler
column2: grief expert and founder of Grief.com.

column1: Bowman says her grief affected her as a woman: "When I talk about the grief over the loss of a job
column2: I think for women
column3: as we fight so hard sometimes to get to executive levels
column4: and those C-suite positions
column5: when we get there
column6: that job becomes an integral part of our identity
column7: she says. And so we identify very closely with our role."

column1: She attempted to push through her grief – a "fake it 'til you make it" mentality – the same way she dealt with it at 26 following the death of her mother.

She never got to see certain things happen in my life. She wasn't there for a wedding, for example, or to see the career trajectory that I ended up with, which have largely been influenced by her, Bowman says. "And in some cases
column2: this is kind of the same thing. I'm missing out on all of those things
column3: because of this loss of a job. And that in and of itself – it's grief. Every time something happens
column4: and I have a financial challenge
column5: it brings it all back."

column1: Bowman confided in friends and family in lieu of professional help. While none could relate to her quandary
column2: they listened to her. Heard her cry.

column1: She later poured those thoughts into a book – "Harasshole" – which
column2: while therapeutic
column3: made it that much harder for her to get a job. Bowman previously had a 15-year stint in executive-level marketing roles at UPS but now freelances.

column1: It's made it very, very difficult for me to find employment, she says. "I have candidly applied for over 1000 jobs. I've had people tell me that they would love to hire me and they can't
column2: because they can't take a risk with me. I've had job offers rescinded when people have found out about this."

column1: Another kind of grief: missed opportunities.
Bowman's grief is not more or less than any other type of grief. "There's a context to think about it
column2: as sometimes we approach grief like it's a pie
column3: Kessler says. And it goes wrong if we think
column4: Wait
column5: wait
column6: you're taking some of the pie on your job loss. But I need a lot of it because my spouse died. And that isn't how grief works."

column1: Some might call Bowman's job loss "disenfranchised grief" – a loss not openly acknowledged
column2: socially mourned or publicly supported
column3: according to Loree Johnson
column4: a licensed marriage and family therapist. It's grief felt on an individual level not necessarily seen by others.

column1: Plus
column2: "the emotions can be the same
column3: regarding all kinds of loss
column4: says Amy Morin, psychotherapist and the host of a podcast. Someone who lost their job may feel sad
column5: anxious
column6: and a bit disoriented
column7: which might be the same feelings someone experiences when they lose a friend or relative."

column1: Read next:At 25 she found out she had the breast cancer gene. Now
column2: she's grieving motherhood.

column1: Today
column2: Bowman's grief hasn't dissipated. It's morphed: "Similar to the loss of a person
column3: the grief doesn't go away. It's just that you get used to carrying it. So it doesn't feel quite as heavy."

column1: For those going through a similar crisis
column2: Bowman offers these words of advice: "You have to realize that it's not your role that defines who you are. It's who you are that makes you you. It's your skills
column3: it's your capabilities
column4: it's the value you provide."

column1: Catching a flight across the country or just having some trouble sleeping? Many people turn to melatonin supplements in these instances for extra help catching some Z’s.
While melatonin does not have huge risk factors tied to it
column2: every supplement can bring side effects if too high of a dose is taken or if used instead of prescribed medicines
column3: according to the National Institutes of Health Office of Dietary Supplements.

column1: Whether you are using the supplement to avoid jet lag or fight insomnia
column2: or just want to sleep better
column3: these are the side effects of melatonin and what to watch out for.

column1: Side effects from melatonin are rare
column2: but there is more risk involved when taking higher doses
column3: explained Dr. Hal Alpert
column4: telemedicine consultant for Blue Sleep. Here are some of the side effects to be aware of:

column1: If a person were to take much too high of a dosage
column2: the following could occur

column1: Additionally
column2: melatonin can interact with other drugs

column1: “Melatonin can decrease the effectiveness of drugs for epilepsy and immune suppressive drugs
column2: ” said Alpert. “You should avoid using melatonin in pregnant women

column1: NEW YORK – The Rolling Stones will not go quietly.
Nearly 60 years since dropping their blues-steeped debut
column2: the legendary rock band rooted by Mick Jagger and Keith Richards continues to make a glorious noise
column3: continues to pique our attention with every utterance of a new tour and
column4: simply
column5: continues to matter.

column1: The band’s latest album
column2: “Hackney Diamonds
column3: ” their first new material since 2005’s “A Bigger Bang
column4: ” arrived Friday.

column1: But a few hours before the clock struck midnight
column2: the Rolling Stones roared through a seven-song set that blurred the lines between vintage and fresh – the the dozen tracks on “Hackney” really are that robust – at an invite-only club show at Racket NYC.

column1: “Yes
column2: yes
column3: yes
column4: ” Jagger uttered as he roamed the corners of the small stage to greet the crowd of about 650 before offering a sly smile. “We’re gonna play some old
column5: and we’re gonna play some new.”

column1: More:Inside Rolling Stones 'Hackney Diamonds' London album party with Fallon
column2: Sydney Sweeney

column1: What Jagger didn’t mention was the band was going to welcome a surprise guest to close their set – and really

column1: The groove-infested “Shattered
column2: ” their 1978 seedy ode to New York

column4: his vocal delivery as elastic as his facial expressions
column5: slithered between Ronnie Wood and Richards
column6: his feet following his hips
column7: as he spat the lyrics “pride and joy and greed and sex

column9: “shadoobie.”

column1: But first Jagger
column2: Richards
column3: Wood
column4: longtime bassist Darryl Jones

column1: Seesawing between classic and new
column2: the band stomped through the staccato rocker “Angry
column3: ” the Stones-iest Stones song in decades. Richards
column4: all scarves and bandannas
column5: ripped out the instant classic riff
column6: filling in the notes between Jones’ rumbling bass lines.

column1: Everyone on stage appeared to be steeped in joy. Wood
column2: who has endured a few recent bouts of cancer
column3: grinned as he stepped up to solo during “Whole Wide World
column4: ” while Jones thundered behind his kit
column5: already a master at Watts’ signature playing style of never hitting the high hat and snare drum simultaneously. (Watts played on two songs on “Hackney Diamonds” – “Live By the Sword” and “Mess It Up.")

column1: Jagger
column2: as if it needs to be said
column3: remains an indefatigable wonder at 80
column4: his moves a blend of peacock strutting and karate chopping
column5: his voice as distinctive and grainy as ever.

column1: While the turbo-charged newcomer “Bite My Head Off” (featuring Paul McCartney playing bass on the album) already sounds primed for the stadiums the Stones still rule
column2: it was the memory-ingrained guitar chords of “Tumbling Dice” and “Jumpin’ Jack Flash” that galvanized a crowd speckled with celebrities including Chris Rock
column3: Daniel Craig
column4: Trevor Noah
column5: Elvis Costello
column6: Diana Krall
column7: Jimmy Fallon and Christie Brinkley.

column1: The band
column2: however
column3: saved its showstopper for the inevitable encore. “Sweet Sounds Of Heaven
column4: ” a muscular gospel-blues standout on the new album
column5: was already landing with visceral intensity thanks to Jagger singing like a preacher
column6: drawing the crowd in with his gestures and falling to his knees.

column1: But then Lady Gaga strutted out with her blond hair in a Debbie Harry-esque rocker ruffle
column2: sparkly jumpsuit cut low in the front and divided vertically between pink and black.

column1: She immediately confirmed she is a worthy sparring partner for Jagger as the pair circled one another
column2: each approaching the other as prey. Their intensity was palpable as they traded soulful wails
column3: simultaneously bounced – she in platform heels – and fed off the force of the music. After Lady Gaga tossed down the mic stand in a frenzied moment of singing
column4: Jagger ceded the spotlight to her to close out the song with iron-lunged ferocity.

column1: The two pros were left breathless from being completely possessed by the song
column2: and as Jagger led her to the front of the stage to take a bow with the band
column3: it solidified that not only do the Rolling Stones still matter
column4: but their legacy continues to inspire.

column1: ARLINGTON
column2: Texas – Postseason baseball is not supposed to be like this.

column1: In a sport where you can’t simply go one-on-one
column2: where a pitcher may simply choose not to throw you the ball in a spot you can hit it
column3: where solid contact and 100-mph line drives are no guarantee of success
column4: one player cannot determine the outcome of a game
column5: the fate of a team.

column1: Yet night after night
column2: series after series and now year after year
column3: Yordan Alvarez is the body around which the Houston Astros rotate
column4: digging them out after they fall into a hole
column5: influencing outcomes even when he’s two
column6: three or four spots away in the lineup.

column1: They are now two games away from a third consecutive World Series appearance and six victories away from defending their championship after a 10-3 thrashing of the Texas Rangers in Game 4 of the American League Championship Series
column2: a win that squared the ALCS at two games apiece.

column1: The heroes were many: Jose Altuve got his flowers
column2: celebrated for playing in his 100th postseason game and characteristically banging out three hits. Alex Bregman got the party started
column3: a two-run
column4: first-inning triple igniting a team-wide strafing of the Rangers’ pitching staff.

And Jose Abreu
column2: a first-year Astro
column3: administered the kill shot
column4: a three-run home run that put the Rangers to sleep.

column1: It is Alvarez
column2: though
column3: who is bracketed by Bregman and Abreu in the lineup
column4: who banged out two more hits
column5: drove in three more runs and broke a tie by hitting a ball 411 feet for a sacrifice fly
column6: a plate appearance that was the baseball equivalent of a crushing lead block that enabled Abreu to waltz into the end zone.

column1: In eight postseason games
column2: Alvarez is now batting .419 (13 for 31)
column3: reaching base at a .471 clip
column4: and has driven in 13 runs. It won’t appear on his playoff game log
column5: but let the record reflect that the hitters in front and behind him in the lineup combined to drive in five runs.

column1: And after getting shut out 2-0 in Game 1 of this ALCS
column2: the Astros have scored four
column3: eight and 10 runs in their next three games. The swagger is back

column2: ” says outfielder Chas McCormick
column3: whose third career postseason home run gave Houston a 9-3 lead. “So when our guy’s going
column4: and we get Altuve going and Jose Abreu going

column1: “Having Alvarez hit like he’s been hitting
column2: nothing can stop us right now.”

column1: Thursday’s action offered plenty of evidence.
For both teams
column2: Game 4 was the get-through game: No Justin Verlander
column3: no Max Scherzer or Nathan Eovaldi or Framber Valdez on the hill. It figured that itinerant starters Andrew Heaney and Jose Urquidy would give way to a bullpen battle

column2: Heaney’s capable piggyback partner
column3: started the inning issuing two walks and a single

column5: was not going to face Alvarez with the bases loaded.

column2: a soft-throwing but deceptive rookie lefty

column1: They battled for nine pitches
column2: Alvarez fouling off four pitches
column3: fastballs at 91 and changeups far slower than that
column4: before Bradford finally left one in the zone.

column1: Alvarez clubbed it just to the right of dead center field
column2: 111 mph off his bat and looking for all the world like it was his seventh homer in eight games this postseason. Bradford backpedaled and looked
column3: hoping for the best. The ball went 401 feet and would have been a grand slam in 17 of 30 ballparks
column4: according to Statcast.

column1: In this one
column2: it was a go-ahead sacrifice fly.

column1: Yet for Rangers manager Bruce Bochy
column2: Alvarez was the focal point of the sequence. The three-batter minimum ensured Bradford would have to face Abreu
column3: too.

column1: And if Alvarez was pounding away and softening up a piece of red meat
column2: it was Abreu who got to eat.

column1: He pummeled a Bradford fastball
column2: a low screamer that eventually rose over the Astros bullpen and the first layer of seats
column3: landing in the second level of Globe Life Field. It was 7-3 Houston.

column1: “Yordan's hit two balls 111 to center field that haven't been homers. It’s crazy
column2: ” says Bregman
column3: recalling a similar shot in Game 3 that center fielder Leody Taveras brought back over the fence to rob a home run. “I've never seen it before in my life. And for him to come through like that time and time again for us
column4: it's huge.

column1: “And then Abreu coming up with another big swing
column2: it was massive for our team.”

column1: You’d think Abreu had the best job in baseball
column2: hitting behind Alvarez
column3: but the year has at times been a struggle for the White Sox legend. He’s found a groove in October
column4: hitting four home runs
column5: three of them at least 430 feet.

column1: Even if there’s not much on the table when he comes up.
“It’s been difficult at times
column2: I’m not going to lie
column3: ” says Abreu through a team translator. “The most important things are the victories. If we keep getting the victories
column4: I’ll continue hitting there.”

column1: Um

column1: “He drives in all the runs.”
When told of his Cuban countryman’s gripe

Back in the good old days
column2: when Jim Harbaugh was provoking someone in college football on a near-daily basis

column1: “If the Georgia coach is implying any intent on our part to break rules
column2: he is barking up the wrong tree
column3: ” Harbaugh tweeted on Feb. 24
column5: after Kirby Smart suggested the NCAA would be forced to step in after Michigan held spring practice at IMG Academy.

column1: The following year
column2: when ESPN’s Paul Finebaum suggested that Michigan hiring the father of a top recruit to his coaching staff was unsavory (albeit allowed)
column3: Harbaugh fired back with a Tweet calling him “Pete Finebaum
column4: the unabashed SEC water carrier.”

column1: But when you play in the gray area of the NCAA rulebook while walking around like you’ve just been blessed by the Pope
column2: you tend to make a lot of enemies.

column1: And now that Michigan is residing near the top of college football again
column2: all the fangs are coming out.

column1: For the second time this year
column2: Harbaugh is in the middle of a snit with the NCAA over potential rules violations that were petty
column3: completely avoidable and ultimately quite stupid if they indeed took place.

column1: Harbaugh served a self-imposed three-game suspension at the beginning of this season for misleading or not cooperating with NCAA investigators during an investigation into impermissible contact with recruits and coaching activities during the COVID-19 dead period.
Now
column2: in a story reported first Thursday by Yahoo! Sports and confirmed by the Big Ten
column3: Michigan is under another inquiry for in-person scouting of opponents
column4: which has been against the rules for nearly 30 years and is quite unnecessary these days
column5: unless the goal is to glean extra information about an opponent's play-calls that teams often try to disguise on the sideline.

column1: Now I know what you
column2: the well-informed college sports fan
column3: is thinking. If the NCAA couldn’t pin anything on Kansas basketball coach Bill Self just last week for having Adidas help him recruit players despite years of investigative work and loads of evidence pointing toward a significant punishment
column4: how in the world is Harbaugh going to get popped for relatively petty crimes?

column1: The answer is because NCAA enforcement is a lot like traffic cops. They’re not going to catch everybody. They may pick one speeding car to turn the siren on for over another for biased reasons. But when they have you on the radar gun going 90 miles per hour on the highway
column2: they’re going to write you a ticket — especially if you act difficult and indignant when they pull you over.

column1: If all of this stuff is proven true
column2: Harbaugh made it easy on them. And given his proclivity toward Michigan Man self-righteousness
column3: the rest of college football is snickering away.

column1: Selective enforcement? Maybe.

But the rules Michigan allegedly violated are so clear and straightforward — and ultimately offer so little upside — that all suspicions about the way Harbaugh conducts his program are now completely fair game.
Back in 2020
column2: when the world was figuring out COVID-19 one day at a time
column3: NCAA schools agreed that it was better for everyone to just take a pause on recruiting and other normal offseason activities.

column1: Is it a huge deal if Harbaugh went to a restaurant with a couple of recruits who were in town during that time? Not really
column2: but it is a willful violation in order to gain a competitive advantage. And then to not be truthful or forthcoming about it with the NCAA? That’s another bright red line that the NCAA has used many times to penalize coaches
column3: because catching them in a lie is one of the few hammers they actually have.

column6: 42 and 45 points.

column1: If you need to steal signs to beat Nebraska and Rutgers

column1: It’s an interesting topic

column5: interviewed with an NFL team the next and then come back to say it was a one-time thing (at least until the next one-time thing).

column1: When you're that slippery
column2: aloofness is a helpful trait -- and Harbaugh uses it to his advantage time and time again.

column1: But the more interesting part of the story is really how this comeuppance has been kind of in the works ever since Harbaugh got back into college football.
You can stand up and say you do things by the book and take great offense to accusations that you’re shading the rules
column2: but make no mistake: Harbaugh at Michigan has absolutely made a home in the gray area while tacitly accusing everyone else in the sport of being cheaters.
author John Bacon — someone who is closely tied to the Michigan program and wrote a book on Harbaugh — claimed that Rashan Gary was offered $300
column3: 000 by another school during his recruitment before choosing the Wolverines (this is before name
column4: image and likeness would have allowed for similar arrangements).

column1: Most people in college sports would look at that claim skeptically — not about the offer itself but the idea that somebody would choose to play for a school offering nothing but the standard scholarship when they could have pocketed $300
column2: 000 somewhere else
column3: even if it was against the rules.

column1: Why even put that out there other than to glorify Mr. “Do it the right way” while casting aspersions on competitors? It’s not just unseemly
column2: it’s phony. Because another huge part of the story in the Gary recruitment was that Harbaugh in 2015 hired Chris Partridge as director of player personnel and recruiting. Who is Chris Partridge? Well
column3: he was the head coach at Paramus Catholic High School in New Jersey
column4: where Gary played until enrolling at Michigan in 2016.

column2: just like the example that got Harbaugh crossways with Finebaum
column3: it’s not against the rules. Partridge was qualified for the job and is now in his second stint on the Michigan staff after working as the co-defensive coordinator and safeties coach the last three seasons.

column1: But hiring the high school coach of the No. 1 prospect in the country and then landing that prospect from several states away is a gray-area move. Just like Harbaugh holding so-called “satellite camps” for recruits in Southern states

UPDATE: This story has been updated with news that within hours of publication of USA TODAY's investigation
column2: MSU suspended Coach Mel Tucker without pay.

column1: Two years ago
column2: one of the nation’s star college football coaches and a prominent rape survivor teamed up to fight the culture of sexual violence in sports.

column1: Their partnership should have been a force for good. Instead
column2: it has devolved into scandal
column3: with the activist accusing the coach of the same misconduct that both of them preached against.

column1: The accused is Mel Tucker
column2: the head football coach at Michigan State University and one of the highest paid coaches in all of sports. Accusing him is Brenda Tracy
column3: a rape survivor who has made educating athletes about sexual violence her life’s work.

column1: Over eight months
column2: they developed a professional relationship centered on her advocacy work. Tucker invited Tracy to campus three times – twice to speak to his players and staff and once to be recognized as an honorary captain at the team's spring football game.

column1: But their relationship was upended during a phone call on April 28
column3: Tracy says in a complaint she filed with the university’s Title IX office in December that remains under investigation.

column1: According to her complaint
column2: Tracy sat frozen for several minutes while Tucker made sexual comments about her and masturbated. His violation
column3: she said
column4: reopened 25-year-old wounds from her rape by four men – two Oregon State University football players
column5: a junior college player and a high school recruit.

column1: “The idea that someone could know me and say they understand my trauma but then re-inflict that trauma on me is so disgusting to me
column2: it’s hard for me to even wrap my mind around it
column3: ” she told USA TODAY. “It’s like he sought me out just to betray me.”

column1: In his statements to the Title IX investigator
column2: Tucker acknowledged masturbating on the call but said Tracy grossly mischaracterized the episode. According to him
column3: they had consensual “phone sex.”

column1: “Ms. Tracy’s distortion of our mutually consensual and intimate relationship into allegations of sexual exploitation has really affected me
column2: ” Tucker wrote in a March 22 letter to the investigator. “I am not proud of my judgment and I am having difficulty forgiving myself for getting into this situation
column3: but I did not engage in misconduct by any definition.”

column1: Michigan State hired an outside Title IX attorney to investigate the complaint. She finished her investigation in July. A formal hearing to determine whether Tucker violated the school’s policy banning sexual harassment and exploitation is scheduled for Oct. 5 and 6
column2: during the Spartans’ bye week.

column1: The stakes are high for everyone.

Tracy says Tucker is following through on a threat to ruin her career and reputation by painting her as a woman who mixes professional and personal relationships and files false reports. She fears he will undo her legacy.
Tucker
column2: who signed one of the most lucrative contracts in college sports history two years ago
column3: could lose out on the roughly $80 million he is owed if Michigan State fires him for cause
column4: which would be a stunning fall from the elite ranks of college coaches.

column1: Reached by USA TODAY on his cellphone Saturday night
column2: Tucker hung up after a reporter mentioned the case.

column1: Hours after USA TODAY published its investigation
column2: the university suspended Tucker without pay
column3: pending a resolution of the Title IX case.

column1: “This step
column2: suspending Mel Tucker without pay
column3: is … necessary and appropriate for today's circumstances
column4: ” Interim President Teresa Woodruff said at a Sunday evening press conference. “These actions are not taken lightly.”

column1: USA TODAY typically does not identify people who allege sexual harassment. Tracy agreed to be identified and shared more than 1
column2: 200 pages of case documents.

column1: Title IX
column2: the federal law banning sex discrimination in education
column3: requires schools to investigate allegations of sexual harassment that took place in the context of a school program or activity. Such claims are inherently difficult to adjudicate because of many of the factors at issue in this case: a lack of eyewitnesses and recordings
column4: the passage of time and the thorniness of litigating consent.

column1: Adding to the uncertainty
column2: the institution tasked with sorting out the facts is perhaps best known for missing repeated opportunities to stop one of the most prolific sexual abusers in American history.

column1: For nearly two decades
column2: Michigan State leaders failed to act on complaints against Larry Nassar
column3: the disgraced former U.S.A. Gymnastics and campus physician accused of sexually assaulting more than 300 female athletes under the guise of medical treatments. He has been sentenced to a minimum of 100 years in prison.

column1: Amid its efforts to rebuild trust among students
column2: employees
column3: alumni and the East Lansing community
column4: Michigan State's leaders must now decide whether the face of its prestigious football program is guilty of sexually harassing one of the country’s most influential advocates against gender-based violence.

column1: For some
column2: how the university navigates the crisis will send a clear message about its commitment to progress.

column1: “This goes beyond coach Tucker and Brenda Tracy
column2: ” said Jennifer Gomez
column3: a Boston University professor who researches the effects of interpersonal trauma and violence. “What happens here has the potential to be very healing or very harmful for lots and lots and lots of other people.”

column1: Tracy and Tucker met in August 2021 during her first visit to Michigan State

column1: Standing before a packed auditorium in the Spartans’ football operations building

column3: 000 speaking fee.

column1: The training was never rescheduled
column2: and they never spoke again.

column1: Tracy initially stayed quiet about Tucker for the sake of her career
column2: she said. Ultimately
column3: she decided that if she let it slide
column4: she wouldn’t be the person she claimed to be – the one who encourages people to speak up about sexual misconduct and hold others accountable.

column1: She filed her complaint in December – eight months after the call. In dry and bureaucratic language
column2: the record of that complaint begins: “The specific allegations of prohibited conduct against Respondent are as follows …” A notification was delivered to Tucker the following day.

column1: Tucker was “absolutely shocked
column2: ” he would tell the university’s investigator. In subsequent correspondence
column3: he and his attorney suggested Tracy’s motive: She held a vendetta against Spartans athletics because of its history of sexual misconduct scandals and falsely accused him for financial gain.

column1: “To say that I have learned from this situation is an understatement
column2: ” Tucker wrote in a letter to the investigator on March 22. “I will never again allow myself to be duped by kindness.”

column1: The university tapped Rebecca Leitman Veidlinger
column2: an Ann Arbor
column3: Michigan-based Title IX attorney
column4: to conduct the investigation.

column1: A former Indiana sex crimes prosecutor who now heads a private practice
column2: she also previously worked in the Title IX offices at Michigan State and the University of Michigan.

column1: Veidlinger started her investigation in January by interviewing Tracy and six people she had identified as witnesses
column2: including three of Tucker’s assistants who had been involved in coordinating and canceling her campus visits.

column1: Tracy’s other three witnesses – her assistant
column2: therapist and attorney – told Veidlinger that a distraught Tracy had disclosed the situation to them in early August
column3: within days of her final phone call with Tucker.

column1: Jacqueline Swanson
column2: Tracy’s attorney who is also her friend
column3: turned over a copy of the notes she took from their conversation on a yellow legal pad.

column1: Ahlan Alvarado
column2: Tracy’s assistant and best friend who had attended the April 2022 spring game
column3: said she had been with Tracy in their hotel after the game when Tucker repeatedly called Tracy asking to meet her alone.

column1: Alvarado said Tracy had told her previously that Tucker “liked” her and it could become a problem. She shared a screenshot of a Dec. 2 text message in which Tracy told her she had just spoken with Tucker
column2: who had agreed they could only be friends.

column1: “I’m glad it didn’t get weird
column2: ” Tracy wrote.

column1: Tracy provided phone bills and emails that corroborated her timeline of events and showed Tucker had been calling her from his personal cellphone.
Although Veidlinger had interviewed all six of Tracy’s witnesses before the end of January
column2: Tucker didn’t agree to be interviewed until late March. In the intervening weeks
column3: he and his attorney
column4: Jennifer Belveal
column5: tried to stop the investigation.

column1: Tracy said Belveal twice contacted her attorney
column2: Karen Truszkowski
column3: proposing a settlement agreement. Tracy said no.

column1: Tucker and Belveal also urged Michigan State to drop Tracy’s complaint. In January
column2: they sent a 12-page letter to the school arguing it lacked jurisdiction to investigate Tucker's “purely personal” relationship with Tracy.

column1: They later commissioned Brett Sokolow
column2: board chairman and co-founder of the Association of Title IX Administrators
column3: to write an “expert witness” report asserting that policing employees’ “off duty” activities would set a dangerous legal precedent.

column1: “Can an employee never have phone sex?” Sokolow wrote. “How far does MSU intend to go in policing the private conduct of its employees
column2: and how does it expect its 20
column3: 000+ employees to react when they find out that they no longer have private lives outside the reach of their employer?”

column1: Michigan State was not persuaded. The alleged conduct would be covered by school policy
column2: it concluded
column3: because it took place in the context of Tracy’s work as a vendor for the school and affected their ongoing business relationship.

column1: The case would go forward.
Tucker sat down for his interview on March 22.
He said he wanted to be transparent and set the record straight. But Veidlinger would note some key inconsistencies.
For instance
column2: Tucker claimed he had made the phone sex call from home in East Lansing – not in a Florida hotel. He had just returned from a trip to Florida
column3: he said
column4: where he had been doing charity work unrelated to his employment with the school.

column1: Veidlinger
column2: however
column3: had obtained documents showing Tucker had
column4: in fact
column5: been in Naples
column6: Florida
column7: the day of the call – attending the Greg Montgomery Foundation Golf Outing on the school’s dime.

column1: An expense report Tucker submitted to Michigan State for his hotel and meal costs showed the trip's purpose was “administrative” and did not involve any personal travel. The costs were paid by the Spartan Fund
column2: the athletic department’s fundraising arm; he had flown to Florida on a donor’s private plane.

column1: Tucker told Veidlinger he had canceled Tracy’s July 25 in-person training because his new mental conditioning coach
column2: Ben Newman

column1: During the interview

column3: Tucker said
column4: made him question how Tracy “goes about her business.”

column1: Veidlinger did not address this allegation in her report
column2: but Lavigne denied the allegation.

column1: “Neither (Tracy's) organization nor Tracy is or has been the target of any investigative reporting
column2: ” Lavigne said in a statement to USA TODAY. “I’m perplexed that Mel Tucker would respond to a complaint of sexual harassment by involving me or ESPN.”

column1: Tucker did not identify any witnesses who could support his version of events
column2: including his associate

column4: Tucker said
column5: told him that Alvarado
column6: Tracy’s assistant

column1: Veidlinger delivered her final 106-page investigation report in July.
Along the way

Tucker would tell her that he deletes his messages regularly because he receives so many; Tracy said she did so in a panic after their last phone call
column3: feeling she needed to cut all ties with him.

column1: Per Title IX and school policy
column2: Veidlinger did not issue a finding of fault in her final report

column1: At the hearing

column2: Alvarado. She died in a car accident in June.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Belveal argued Alvarado’s death “presents yet another reason that this case should be dismissed.”

column1: Letters Belveal sent Veidlinger throughout the case accuse her of bias against Tucker – and men more broadly.

One letter in May contained a list of 170 perceived problems with Veidlinger’s draft report and questions she should have asked Tracy and her witnesses. They included why Tracy had not returned Tucker’s gifts

column2: Belveal wrote
column3: would expose Tracy’s allegations as “nothing more than another agenda-driven attempt … to defame Respondent and the University.”

column1: “We request that the investigation be reopened
column2: ” Belveal wrote
column3: “that each of the questions be asked of the appropriate witnesses
column4: that jurisdiction be reassessed
column5: and that the matter be dismissed.”

column1: Kenny Jacoby is an investigative reporter for USA TODAY covering sexual harassment and violence and Title IX. Contact him by email at kjacoby@usatoday.com or follow him on X @kennyjacoby.
On a sunny Thursday morning
column2: Michigan State University football coach Mel Tucker strolled through tomato fields at a farm in Immokalee
column3: Florida
column4: toured its processing plants and loaded baskets of bright green fruit into a truck.

column1: It was a private event thrown by the school to promote its migrant student services program
column2: which provides financial aid and support to farmworkers seeking college degrees. After the April 28
column4: tour
column5: disclosed in records obtained by USA TODAY this week
column6: Tucker met with community leaders and alumni.

column1: That night

column3: during which he is accused of masturbating and making unwanted sexual comments to Brenda Tracy
column4: a prominent rape survivor and activist he had hired to speak to his team about sexual violence.

column1: Yet
column2: when Tucker met with the university’s outside investigator in March for his interview in the sexual harassment case against him

column1: It’s just one example of Tucker failing to keep his story straight at the most consequential moment of his career.
With his job
column2: reputation and the roughly $80 million left on his contract at stake
column3: Tucker repeatedly made false statements to the investigator and misled her about basic facts
column4: such as his location during the phone call and the date it occurred
column5: a USA TODAY review of more than 1
column6: 200 pages of case documents found.

column1: The investigator
column2: Rebecca Leitman Veidlinger
column3: and the news organization both obtained documents and witness statements that discredit key aspects of Tucker’s version of events.

column1: Michigan State suspended Tucker without pay on Sept. 10
column2: hours after Tracy went public for the first time with her story in USA TODAY. On Monday
column3: the school informed Tucker it plans to fire him for cause based on the conduct he had admitted to and the embarrassment he had caused the school.

column1: Investigation:Michigan State football coach Mel Tucker accused of sexually harassing rape survivor
Although Tucker denied sexually harassing Tracy
column2: he acknowledged masturbating on the call
column3: saying he and Tracy had been in a romantic relationship and had consensual “phone sex.” Tracy said Tucker’s romantic interest in her was completely one-sided and that she had tried to set boundaries multiple times during their yearlong business partnership.

column1: Per his contract
column2: Tucker has until Tuesday to make a case for keeping his job. Regardless
column3: a formal hearing to determine whether Tucker violated school policies against sexual harassment and exploitation is expected to proceed on Oct. 5 and 6.

column1: Since his suspension
column2: Tucker has issued multiple public statements defending himself
column3: attacking Tracy and accusing Veidlinger of bias. He accused the school of conducting a “sham” hearing and having “ulterior motives.” Yet even in these written statements
column4: the central details of his story changed entirely.

column1: Tucker
column2: who previously hung up on a reporter who called him on his cellphone asking about the case
column3: did not respond to a message seeking comment for this story. His attorney
column4: Jennifer Belveal
column5: has not responded to phone calls and emails. Tracy declined to comment for this story.

column1: In the absence of eyewitnesses or recordings
column2: sexual harassment cases usually boil down to whose account is more credible
column3: said Elizabeth Abdnour
column4: a Lansing-based attorney and former Michigan State Title IX investigator who has taken part in dozens of campus cases.

column1: “It’s very
column2: very unusual that you would have some outside piece of evidence that would give you a clear decision
column3: ” Abdnour said. “Very often you’re weighing credibility based on little bits and pieces of information.”

column1: In multiple cases she has worked
column2: Abdnour said the respondents lost because they were found to have a greater propensity for lying than the complainants. The hearing officer must determine how much weight to give Tucker’s false and conflicting statements
column3: Abdnour said
column4: and they could sway the case in Tracy’s favor.

column1: “I believe a fact finder could assess these pieces of evidence about credibility and make a determination that Brenda is more credible than Mel
column2: ” she said. “In my experience
column3: a clear sign of a lack of credibility is generally taken very seriously.”

column1: By the time Tucker met with Veidlinger for his interview
column2: he had had months to prepare.

column1: The school had informed him of Tracy’s complaint on Dec. 22
column2: the day after she filed it. Veidlinger had interviewed Tracy and all six of her witnesses by the end of January. Tucker was the only holdout.

column1: Rather than tell his side of the story right away
column2: Tucker and his attorney spent three months trying to stop the investigation
column3: case documents show. They wrote legal arguments urging Michigan State to drop the case and twice approached Tracy’s attorney proposing a settlement agreement. Tracy said no
column4: and the school pressed forward.

column1: On March 22
column2: the day of his interview
column3: Tucker sent Veidlinger a seven-page written account of his interactions with Tracy and lists of their “currently existing” text message and call history
column4: which he said his legal team had compiled. Only a handful of text messages remained; he and Tracy both told the investigator they had deleted their texts with each other in the months after the April 2022 phone call.

column1: In his interview
column2: which lasted 3 ½ hours
column3: Tucker questioned whether Tracy had mixed up the date of the call. He said he recalled being at his home in East Lansing when it occurred
column4: but his own records showed that he had been in Florida on April 28
column5: attending a charity function that was “absolutely not a University-sponsored event.”

column1: His seven-page account told a different story – that he had called her while he was “alone in a hotel room.”
Veidlinger does not appear to have asked Tucker about the discrepancy
column2: based on case documents. But by then she knew what he told her in the interview was untrue: she had already obtained records proving he had not been home in East Lansing.

column1: An expense report he had submitted to the university for reimbursement of his hotel and meals shows Tucker flew to Naples
column2: Florida
column3: to attend a golf fundraiser hosted by The Greg H. Montgomery Jr. Foundation for Ultimate Growth
column4: which raises awareness for suicide prevention. It showed he stayed at the Hilton from April 27 to 29
column5: that the trip’s purpose was “administrative” and that it did not involve personal travel. He had flown there on a donor’s private plane.

column1: The trip is when Tucker toured the farm in Immokalee to help promote Michigan State’s College Assistance Migrant Program. The event was titled “Working to make dreams a reality
column2: ” according to an agenda obtained from the university by USA TODAY through a public records request. The agenda features Tucker’s name prominently. Tucker posted photos from the tour on his Twitter account.

column1: That Tucker was on a university-sponsored work trip during the incident was a contributing factor in the university’s determination that it had jurisdiction to investigate
column2: the investigation report shows.

column1: Tucker’s lists of calls and text messages also were missing an important detail: They did not show any communication with Tracy on April 28. He acknowledged in the interview
column2: however
column3: that he had not reviewed the lists before submitting them and that they may have been incomplete.

column1: Tracy
column2: meanwhile
column3: had already provided Veidlinger with her official cellphone records from Sprint that confirmed the date of their call: April 28.

column1: Tucker and Tracy did not speak in the three months after the April 28 call.
Meanwhile
column2: their assistants were planning Tracy’s third visit to campus – an in-person training with coaches and players scheduled for July 25.

column1: Tucker canceled that training three days before
column2: the investigation report shows. When Tracy spoke to him by phone on Aug. 2 seeking to find out why
column3: she would tell the investigator in her interview that Tucker insinuated he would harm her career if she spoke about his conduct. He never rescheduled her visit
column4: and they never spoke again.

column1: The cancellation became a key focus of the investigator – one of a series of alleged incidents that taken together would meet the definition of sexual harassment

column1: “Reported allegations that a University employee is engaging in misconduct within the vendor-vendee relationship for which they are the decision-maker
column2: and/or impeding in such a services relationship based on a quid-pro-quo sexual harassment allegation
column3: is within a University sponsored program or activity
column4: ” Veidlinger wrote in the report

column2: the day after Michigan State suspended him without pay.

column1: “I never cancelled any presentation
column2: ” he wrote. “Given a personnel change and scheduling challenges as football season approached
column3: we merely postponed it until January 2023. She chose to file her complaint instead of proceeding with the training.”

column1: But that statement contradicts what he told the investigator. When Veidlinger asked in his March interview if he had a role in canceling Tracy’s visit
column2: Tucker said
column3: “Yes
column4: absolutely I did
column5: ” the report shows
column6: and that he did not recall any discussions about rescheduling Tracy for January. Such timing would not make sense

column1: Tucker also told the investigator why he canceled the visit
column2: blaming it on a scheduling conflict. He said he had recently hired a mental conditioning coach
column3: Ben Newman
column4: who needed to implement his new program on short notice. There was limited time in fall camp
column5: Tucker said
column6: and he didn’t want to “overwhelm” the players. He said he decided to yield the time to Newman.

column1: Veidlinger
column2: however
column3: would later obtain records showing Newman did not meet with the team on July 25
column4: the day of Tracy’s planned visit. He had been meeting with them weekly since June 6
column5: the records showed but held no meetings between July 15 and July 28.

column1: One of Tucker’s assistants
column2: who is a witness in the case
column3: also told the investigator that Tucker asked him via text message to cancel it. He said he was never instructed to reschedule.

column1: In his interview
column2: Tucker told Veidlinger that his relationship with Tracy frayed after the April 2022 phone call – not because of the incident

column1: According to Tucker
column2: an associate of his had told him over the summer that Tracy’s assistant
column3: Ahlan Alvarado
column4: had been gossiping about Tucker’s marriage
column5: telling others it was “on the rocks.” Tucker said he was “devastated” because he had confided in Tracy about his marital problems

During the Aug. 2 call
column2: Tracy said she pressed Tucker to identify his source – the associate. She told Veidlinger she believed Tucker had made it up as a pretext for canceling her visit and ending her relationship with the school.

column1: Veidlinger also asked Tucker to reveal the source of his claim
column2: but he refused to say. In her report

column1: Tucker never revealed the associate’s name to the investigator
column2: nor did he identify anyone who could support his version of events. In his Sept. 11 public statement
column3: however
column4: he lamented that the hearing would not afford him the opportunity to “offer any substantive evidence of innocence.”

column1: It was not the only claim he attributed to his anonymous associate. In his interview
column2: he said that same person told him that ESPN investigative reporter Paula Lavigne was investigating how Tracy “goes about her business” by claiming to be a rape survivor.

column1: Tucker said this further caused him to believe Tracy was untrustworthy because she believed Lavigne was her friend but didn’t know she was investigating the rape story at the center of her public persona.
It turned out to be yet another falsehood.
Reached by USA TODAY
column2: Lavigne said in an emailed statement that she was “perplexed that Mel Tucker would respond to a complaint of sexual harassment by involving me or ESPN.” She said Tracy has been a source of information for her for several years
column3: and that she has featured Tracy’s comments and advocacy work in multiple news stories.

column1: “That has been the extent of my reporting on Tracy and her organization
column2: ” Lavigne wrote. “Neither the organization nor Tracy is or has been the target of any investigative reporting.”

column1: Asked who might have told Tucker this misinformation
column2: Lavigne responded
column3: “I have absolutely no idea who would have alleged this to anyone.”
