The bullets came in plywood crates.
Any given box was about the size of a small microwave oven. The printed label stuck to each one demonstrated a militaristic brevity. “CARTRIDGES FOR WEAPONS
column2: INERT PROJECTILE
column3: ” next to a bright yellow hazmat sticker
column4: “EXPLOSIVES.”

column1: Inside the boxes: drab green steel cans of .50-caliber ammunition. Each round was giant
column2: more than 5 inches long
column3: built to be fired from a gun so big it is typically bolted to a truck. The bullets were clipped together in long strands for rapid
column4: machine-gun fire.

column1: By the time Bill Brown got to the boxes
column2: they sat double-stacked eight high atop wooden pallets inside a Missouri warehouse. The pallets went on
column3: row after row. Three million bullets in all.

column1: It was enough ammunition to feed a single machine gun – if fired nonstop at its rated speed eight hours a day
column2: seven days a week – for almost six months.

column1: Brown’s job was to get it out of there and toward the Ukrainian front lines. The faster
column2: the better.

column1: “War is bad
column2: ” Brown said. “Loss of life is bad. But at the end of the day
column3: it’s very profitable and injects revenue into this military industrial base.”

column1: There would be virtually no public record of this Ukrainian arms shipment. As a weapons dealer
column2: Brown’s company would deliver the bullets under a system known as a direct commercial sale. The ammunition required a State Department signoff – but the secret deal would never appear in a White House announcement or the Congressional Record.

column1: Instead
column2: it was part of a shadowy system of brokers
column3: exporters
column4: arms dealers and country-to-country transfers that has become one part of the race to meet demand on distant battlefields.

column1: Western weaponry fueled Ukraine’s summertime counteroffensive along a 600-mile front. President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said the effort was delayed in part by the wait for more arms. Amid concerns about that slowly progessing counteroffensive
column2: Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrived in Kyiv on Wednesday with a promise of up to $175 million more in military equipment.

column1: Most of America’s $44 billion in documented support to Ukraine came in the form of old U.S. military stock
column2: donated directly by the federal government. In general
column3: commercial sales over $14 million
column4: and sales of military-grade weaponry like mortars or missiles
column5: require State Department approval and congressional notification.

column1: But other aid comes via private sales.
More than 14
column2: 000 U.S. entities are registered to conduct defense trade activities. Their deals are monitored by an alphabet soup of agencies including Departments of Homeland Security
column3: Commerce
column4: Defense and the Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco
column5: Firearms and Explosives. Trade secrecy clauses in federal law mean this flow of gear
column6: weapons and ammunition is almost never revealed to the public.

column1: Brown
column2: who works for a small Nevada-based logistics company called Battle Born Munitions
column3: provided USA TODAY with a rare look behind the curtain of these private sales. Details about the shipment were verified by his employer and the European government that made the purchase. State Department officials declined to answer questions about the specific shipment Brown described.

column1: This March sale and the secret number of other shipments like it fuel Ukraine’s fight against a Russian invasion. Those sales also release an unknown amount of weaponry into the world. What becomes of that weaponry after it’s sold – and especially after it’s delivered – is difficult to track.
As Brown surveyed the warehouse in Missouri
column2: a crew steered forklifts and skid lifts among the stacks of plain wooden boxes. From high in the trusses
column3: suspended lamp fixtures bathed the boxes in artificial daylight. Brown lifted his camera and started snapping photos.

column1: In just a few hours
column2: he and his cargo would be boarding a jumbo jet. Three million bullets would climb to the stratosphere and hurtle across the north Atlantic toward a European dawn.

column1: From Ukraine:War crimes in Ukraine may be unprecedented. So is the country's push for swift justice.
The bullets had once been bound for Saudi Arabia.
Lot number SMQ19K401L026 had rolled off the assembly line in 2019 at Lake City Army Ammunition Plant near Kansas City. Lake City
column2: owned by the government and run by a contractor
column3: sprawls across nearly 4
column4: 000 acres of green Missouri farmland. Roads curve past World War II-era bunkers known as igloos
column5: spaced out amid the countryside – far enough apart that an explosion in one won’t trigger a chain reaction in the others.

column1: Lake City has been pumping out ammunition almost without pause since 1941. It is the largest small-arms manufacturing plant in the world.
Today the plant is run by Olin-Winchester
column2: but in 2019
column3: the bullets were made by some of the 1
column4: 700 workers employed by Northrop Grumman. And in 2019
column5: Saudi Arabia was stocking up on weapons during the Trump administration
column6: fueling the war in Yemen and other conflicts that drew criticism from congressional Democrats.

column1: The plant manufactures .50-caliber ammunition on a rolling basis
column2: for both military and commercial buyers. That’s a testament to just what a legend the bullet – and the gun that shoots it – has become.
the technology was already a century old. The .50 caliber was the brainchild of American gunsmith John Browning during World War I. Built to respond to German anti-tank rifles
column3: the M2 was first tested in 1918
column4: and it entered widespread service in 1923. It earned the nickname “Ma Deuce” and has served in combat ever since
column5: bolted to trucks
column6: ships
column7: planes and handheld stands on the battlefield.

column1: The .50-caliber rounds – named for their diameter
column2: about half an inch – can easily hit targets more than a mile away. At closer ranges
column3: they will blast through solid concrete or armored vehicles. The gun can fire at a sustained rate of about 40 shots per minute.

column1: Military setups use strings of “linked” ammunition to feed into machine guns. Spaced out after every fourth bullet
column2: so-called tracer rounds have small pyrotechnic charges that illuminate the line of fire
column3: aiding in targeting.

column1: The gun’s longevity and versatility made it popular for militaries the world over. But this particular batch of bullets wouldn’t end up being sold to Saudi Arabia.
The Biden administration put a temporary freeze on sales to the Saudi government in 2021 as it reviewed weapons deals approved under Donald Trump. Instead
column2: Brown said
column3: the bullets were sold to a U.S. ammunition provider
column4: only to be held up again. Ultimately
column5: they were mothballed.

column1: Then
column2: in spring 2023
column3: the bullets found a buyer
column4: or actually two: first Battle Born; ultimately
column5: the Netherlands.

column1: The European country
column2: a NATO ally
column3: needed a big supply of ammunition. It wouldn’t be keeping the bullets but giving them to Ukraine. Its purchase
column4: essentially a donation
column5: would count toward the country’s required NATO contribution.

column1: Brown had a line on exactly what they needed. It was sitting in the warehouse in Missouri.
He arrived in March to personally oversee the shipment. As he prepped for delivery
column2: Brown dropped tiny black tracking devices onto several of the pallets. Just $55 apiece
column3: the units use GPS and cell signals to keep tabs on the load. The idea was to ensure it wouldn’t fall into the wrong hands.

column1: But packing up the bullets was just the beginning. As with anything that’s deadly and made of metal
column2: the shipping costs can be extreme.

column1: Brown said the question for the buyer was simple: “How fast do you want it? Forty-five to 60 days on a ship? Or in five days if I fly it?”
Brown – or Chief Bill
column2: as he prefers – is a no-nonsense 35-year veteran of the U.S. Army and former helicopter pilot. He retired as a chief warrant officer and lives in Orlando.

column1: Now 59
column2: he still spends a lot of time on the road – 10 international trips this year. He says his arms logistics work takes him to places most Americans would rather avoid – near the Syrian border or to unstable regions of Iraq.

column1: He’ll travel halfway around the world
column2: he quips
column3: “have some soup
column4: and go back to Warsaw to head home.” The trips aren’t really about the destinations. They’re about the cargo.

column1: On that spring day in Missouri
column2: forklifts carefully loaded 107 pallets of the ammo onto 18 flatbed semitrailers. They’d all make the eight-hour drive to O’Hare International Airport.

column1: In Chicago
column2: two Boeing 747-400s operated by National Airlines would be ready for the freight.

column1: Four pallets each were stacked and shrink-wrapped to create “air pallets” or “cookie sheets” weighing 12
column2: 800 pounds. Each plane could carry up to 17 of the pallets that ran the length of each plane secured by white cargo netting.

column1: Flight records Brown provided show the two planes departed about seven hours apart
column2: one in early afternoon
column3: one after dark.

column1: The flight would take nine hours. Brown wasn’t going to the Netherlands
column2: even though it was the buyer. The planes were bound for Rzeszów
column3: Poland.

column1: The ancient city sits at the foot of the Carpathian Mountains in southeastern Poland. It has a gleaming modern airport next to a major east-west freeway. From there
column2: it’s barely 60 miles to the border with Ukraine.

column1: It was an expensive journey. The trucking company’s bill for those 18 semis? $85
column2: 000. Chartering the two 747s? $625
column3: 000. Each.

column1: But this shipment of .50-cal rounds was profitable for Battle Born Munitions
column2: according to Brown.

column1: The company purchased the 3 million rounds from Northrop Grumman at a bargain and resold them for more than double the price. (In subsequent interviews
column2: representatives at BBM disputed the specific totals Brown mentioned
column3: saying the accurate figures were protected by “various commercial and government non-disclosure agreements.” They did not dispute the other specifics of the deal he provided.)

column1: Retail prices for .50-caliber ammunition run roughly $5 per bullet. At that rate
column2: the whole shipment would have been worth $15 million.

column1: The pricing might also be elastic. The Dutch mark up the price of the bullets and count it toward their NATO contribution
column2: pegged to a percentage of gross domestic product
column3: Brown said. The Netherlands has contributed about $15 billion to NATO this year
column4: or about 1.7% of its GDP and just under the NATO mandate of 2%.

column1: Representatives of the Dutch military confirmed the shipment to USA TODAY but declined to comment further about the pricing or details.
The war in Ukraine has only increased the demand for private deals. The State Department signed off on more than $154 billion in commercial arms deals directly to foreign countries in 2022
column2: a 48% increase from the previous year.

column1: Direct commercial sales represent a modest portion of the contribution to Ukraine compared with the $44 billion donated by the U.S.
column2: but they still amounted to more than $600 million in sales from U.S. companies to the Ukrainian government last year alone. That doesn’t include sales to other countries that also support Ukraine – sales like the one Brown described.

column1: Jim Bartlett
column2: an attorney with expertise in the specialized international arms transactions
column3: said private U.S. businesses are playing a small but important role in the conflict.

column1: “American companies are happy to export defense articles to foreign buyers approved by the U.S. State Department
column2: ” Bartlett said. “There’s an effort at the State Department to quickly clear the ones headed for Ukraine. … You get head-of-the-line privileges.”

column1: Those sales also come with risks.
Direct sales face fewer regulatory controls
column2: oversight and enforcement
column3: said Robert Nichols
column4: an international military sales expert and attorney at the law firm Nichols Liu.

column1: “You can imagine the range of characters involved in supplying a war effort
column2: ” Nichols said. “Some are highly credible. Others will skirt the law and sometimes step over the line by paying bribes
column3: committing fraud and hiding their transactions.”

column1: So far
column2: the Department of Justice has indicted just a handful of arms brokers over deals related to the war in Ukraine. Court records show the government has charged Miami-based Oleg Patsulya and Vasilii Besedin with illegally attempting to sell American-made aircraft parts to Russia. They allegedly lied to Commerce Department agents and told them the parts were bound for Turkey. Both pleaded not guilty to the charges this summer.

column1: A State Department spokesman declined to provide details of enforcement actions but said
column2: “The United States takes seriously our responsibility to protect American military and dual-use technologies and prevent their diversion
column3: including through strong enforcement actions.”

column1: NATO said it oversees allied arms deliveries
column2: and that those arms generally reach Ukraine. NATO itself technically only provides non-non-lethal aid
column3: like fuel
column4: medical supplies and generators.

column1: Brown
column2: of Battle Born
column3: says he fields calls weekly from “clowns” without the proper licensing
column4: whom he reports to the State Department for potential violations. Some raise red flags when they approach him about transactions that include payment via diamonds or gold.

column1: He prefers traditional wire transfers with approved sales partners since he knows government officials are watching. He validates the contracts and checks certificates for the final users. That’s part of why he traveled with the ammunition. He would be meeting a Dutch military official for the official handoff.
“My job is to keep us all out of jail
column2: ” Brown said.

column1: The two 747s touched down in Poland
column2: one before the sun
column3: the other in late morning. Brown exchanged paperwork with a young Dutch military staffer who signed for the delivery
column4: he said. They traded military patches as souvenirs. They snapped a photo together.

column1: The bullets bought by the Netherlands would never touch Dutch soil.
U.S. aid:Billions from the US flows to Ukraine. Here's where it comes from
column2: and how it adds up

column1: Despite playing a small role proportionately in the war
column2: $600 million in direct commercial sales can buy a lot of small weaponry.

column1: And those weapons are the kind most apt to fall into illicit use
column2: said Elias Yousif
column3: a research analyst at the Stimson Center
column4: a nonprofit think tank.

column1: Put another way: It’s hard to sneak away an F-16 or a missile launcher the size of a tractor-trailer. But a bunch of guns or a pallet of ammo? Much easier to resell.
“In the commercial sector
column2: especially in a new market
column3: the risk increases
column4: ” Yousif said.

column1: After Russia invaded Ukraine in 2014
column2: the Small Arms Survey
column3: a Swiss arms research project
column4: estimated that within a year
column5: battlefield seizures and other forms of diversion led to 300
column6: 000 small arms and light weapons going missing
column7: including 100
column8: 000 in Crimea alone.

column1: When small arms go missing
column2: they can go missing into another country
column3: maybe one led by a despot or even a terrorist organization.

column1: The U.S. government says diversion of American donations has been widely absent so far in Ukraine. That could be a combination of intensive “end-use-monitoring” programs and the reality of the battlefield
column2: where supplies are rapidly put to use.

column1: But even if not now
column2: unused ammo could be resold someday.

column1: “History shows us this isn’t a short-term issue
column2: ” Yousif said.  “These are commodities with very long shelf lives.”

column1: Florida-based Global Ordnance
column2: another State Department-licensed exporter
column3: is a competitor in the direct weapons sales business. General counsel Bryan Van Brunt said the company has extensive protocols in place to track shipments and make sure the end-users are federally approved
column4: though he declined to provide specifics about those systems.

column1: Brown
column2: with Battle Born Munitions
column3: says the company employs a mix of simple and sophisticated tracking technology to ensure his shipments are tracked to end users. The black GPS devices he dropped onto his cargo tracked the ammo all the way across the globe.

column1: But that system only works as long as Brown is actually tracking. “Technically
column2: my role ends when I deliver it to NATO
column3: ” he said.

column1: Sometime after the 747s touched down in Poland
column2: along with signing the paperwork and snapping a selfie with the Dutch official
column3: Brown found the tiny black GPS trackers and lifted them off the pallets.

column1: Ukrainian trucks would arrive at the airport to pick up the ammunition. They would point toward the border
column2: and onward to Lviv
column3: and some distant battlefield.

column1: Brown would point in the opposite direction. Just like one of his quips: Fly in
column2: have soup
column3: get home. He headed toward Warsaw
column4: with the GPS trackers in his bag.

column1: Nick Penzenstadler is a reporter on the USA TODAY investigations team. Contact him at npenz@usatoday.com or @npenzenstadler
column2: or on Signal at (720) 507-5273.

column1: The geography professor didn’t hide his clown fetish or the fact that he sometimes indulged his urges by recruiting students as subjects. He posted regularly about it on social media.
“I have a facepaint fetish and convince the cute girls in my classes to let me paint their faces
column2: ” he once wrote.

column1: Yet Joseph Tokosh held jobs at two colleges and was on the tenure track at a third before student journalists at Nicholls State University in Louisiana exposed his behavior. He submitted his resignation the same day their story was published.

His interactions with students and open discussion of his fetish happened in both mainstream and tailored digital spaces. He popped into Facebook groups geared toward new students and niche forums on websites like Reddit. He posted videos on YouTube. In one Reddit post on a forum meant to highlight hard-to-believe stories
column2: Tokosh posted pictures of several women in white face paint.

column1: Over the years
column2: two students reported him to campus police; others complained online. He left Kent State University after pleading no contest to something different: a theft charge that involved entering his peers’ offices without permission and taking a USB drive. Tokosh has not been charged with any other crime.

column1: Tokosh’s career trajectory exposes inadequacies in the background check system that colleges and universities are supposed to have in place to protect students – especially when evidence of the concerning behavior resides largely on the internet. Nicholls State
column2: for example
column3: told USA TODAY Network reporters it does not routinely check social media for new hires.

column1: A federal law intended to ensure the academic privacy of students also makes it difficult to determine how Tokosh was able to move so freely from campus to campus. Both Kent State and Northern Illinois University – where he taught while finishing his doctorate – noted Tokosh’s protected status as a graduate student in declining to answer questions.
Sophie Levan was a freshman at Kent State in 2017 when she encountered Tokosh
column2: then 28
column3: in a Facebook group intended as a gathering place for new students. Tokosh had offered cash to anyone willing to let him paint their faces. Levan
column4: then 18
column5: agreed.

column1: The money was appealing but the interactions soured.
Tokosh
column2: she said
column3: insisted he come pick her up and take her to the building that housed the geography department
column4: where he would paint her face. Uneasy
column5: Levan stopped responding. Tokosh got angry and wouldn’t give up
column6: she said
column7: which led her to file a police report.

column1: “I felt like the school would want to know about it
column2: ” Levan said. “I thought maybe they could prevent anything bad from happening since other girls would go with him.”

column1: She said there was never any followup from campus police – or anyone else.
USA TODAY Network reporters reviewed the experiences of six students who were the subject of Tokosh’s attention going back to his time at Kent State.
In addition to Levan
column2: the other person who reported Tokosh to campus police could not be reached for comment. The two who expressed public concerns on social media told USA TODAY they never heard from their campus officials either.

column1: USA TODAY attempted to reach Tokosh via phone
column2: social media and a certified letter. A person answered a phone call to a number associated with Tokosh
column3: but he hung up after the reporter identified himself. A reporter also reached someone who identified herself as Tokosh’s mother. She said she would pass along that reporters were trying to reach him.

column1: Tokosh told the Nicholls student journalists that he did have an assignment where students were required to paint their faces as part of a cultural exercise. Prior to the article in the student newspaper The Nicholls Worth
column2: the university had already cut Tokosh loose. He said his contract was not renewed because he was the target of a “grade inflation task force.”

column1: The university
column2: however
column3: “does not have any such task force
column4: ” according to Nicholls spokesman Jerad David.

column1: Tokosh also told students the face painting was a requirement in his cultural geography class to better understand other cultures. In a video interview with Hannah Robert
column2: the station manager for the student-run KNSU TV
column3: he says: “That's an assignment in one of my classes where they actually come up with their own face paint and makeup design inspired by a culture and they implement it.”

column1: It’s a well-established trend in the academic world for professors to bounce from one institution to another without having to disclose why they left their last post
column2: said Julie Libarkin
column3: an associate dean at Michigan State University. She has seen the pattern often in her work maintaining a database of publicly documented sexual misconduct by faculty and staff.

column1: As for grad students? Libarkin said people have requested she add them to her list
column2: but universities’ conservative interpretations of the law get in the way.

column1: “I don’t on purpose
column2: ” she said
column3: “because that’s information that almost never comes out.”

column1: Tokosh arrived at Kent State in 2015 with bachelor’s and master’s degrees in geography from Indiana University of Pennsylvania
column2: according to his curriculum vitae. He was working toward his doctorate and researched fading businesses. His work about shopping malls in the Rust Belt won several awards. Like many graduate students
column3: he also taught classes.

column1: Then
column2: Tokosh started showing up in the Facebook groups for new students. In a December 2017 post
column3: an account under the name “Joe Tokosh” posted several pictures of women made up to look like clowns or skulls.

column1: “If anyone is looking for some extra cash
column2: I am looking for people to practice facepainting on!” he wrote. “I will literally pay you!”

column1: Those are the types of posts that caught Levan’s eye. Not only was she pressed for cash
column2: she was interested in movie makeup and thought the face painting could be fun based on the photos Tokosh had posted. But Levan said she soon realized that those images were stock photos and not representative of what Tokosh could do.

column1: What’s more
column2: she figured out that he was a graduate student
column3: a fact she said he didn’t disclose in his posts.

column1: When Tokosh offered to pick her up from her dorm
column2: she refused. But
column3: she said
column4: Tokosh kept insisting she agreed to participate. Levan stopped responding to his messages and filed a police report with the Kent State police in January 2018. They advised her only to stop talking to Tokosh
column5: she said
column6: and let them know if “anything of consequence occurred.”

column1: Months after she refused to meet up and filed the police report
column2: Tokosh texted a picture of himself wearing white face paint to her cellphone. It arrived at midnight and contained no message
column3: although writing on his shirt read: “I'm not a failure.”

column1: “There was some negative intention with sending that photo
column2: ” Levan said. “It’s definitely burned into my mind.”

column1: What Levan didn’t know is that campus police had been put on notice a year earlier when another student filed a similar report. That student told police Tokosh reached out to her and her friends after they posted their numbers on a Facebook group for undergraduates. He would send “get to know you” messages
column2: the police report said
column3: and then ask the student if she was “interested in having her face painted for one of his class projects.”

column1: When she found out Tokosh was a graduate student
column2: she said no and eventually blocked him on Facebook and Snapchat
column3: according to the report. Tokosh continued to text her.

column1: “She does not have any concerns for her safety
column2: but just wanted this documented
column3: ” the police report read.

column1: In July 2017
column2: another student had retweeted a message from Kent State’s Twitter account that asked for Kent State love stories. She wrote: “A geography professor requested me on facebook and asked if he could paint my face like a clown.”

column1: The student confirmed to USA TODAY that the professor was Tokosh and shared a screenshot of a Facebook friend request he sent her. She said she suspected Tokosh also found her on a freshman Facebook group because she posted there often.
She said she tweeted to draw officials’ attention to it and moved on but now wishes she had reported it officially.
College campuses are supposed to offer students special protections from sexual harassment even when it falls short of criminal behavior. Title IX
column2: often associated with equity in women’s sports
column3: also addresses “sex-based harassment
column4: which encompasses sexual assault and other forms of sexual violence” at schools that receive federal funding.

column1: Colleges infrequently and unevenly enforce the rule
column2: however. A 2022 USA TODAY investigation found just one of every 12
column3: 400 students was suspended in connection with sexual misconduct.

column1: The student who shared her story online said the only response she received was from a graduate student in the geography department
column2: who contacted her on Oct. 1
column3: 2018. In an email
column4: he wrote that he had seen her post and suspected he knew which faculty member had asked her about face painting.

column1: “I brought it to the attention of some of our faculty because I was pretty sure I knew who it was
column2: but they were certain it wasn’t that individual and that you probably just meant geology
column3: ” he wrote.

column1: He went on to reference another student being “approached in (at least by just looking at your tweet) a much more aggressive way.” The grad student asked the undergraduate for more information
column2: but
column3: she told USA TODAY
column4: she didn’t respond. She said she started drafting a reply
column5: but a year had passed. She wanted to move on.

column1: Kent State would not say whether any actions were taken after the students’ reports
column2: but Eric Mansfield
column3: a spokesman for the university
column4: said the police department confirmed that the students who filed police reports were provided with “university resources
column5: which would include other non-criminal avenues to pursue (Counseling Services
column6: Title IX
column7: Center for Sexual and Relationship Violence Services
column8: etc.) as a general police practice.”

column1: Levan does not recall police offering her services
column2: but she said she didn’t want counseling. She wanted Tokosh investigated.

column1: Mansfield also said that the university monitors social media but that colleges “can’t always see or track every mention on social media.”

Police records show that officers did investigate when Tokosh was accused of breaking into geography department offices. A blotter item in the local newspaper shows police obtained an arrest warrant in connection with a third-degree felony burglary charge. Court documents indicate Tokosh pleaded no contest to a theft on Oct. 19
Kent State would not explain what led to Tokosh’s departure during that fall semester. Instead
column2: the university said that since Tokosh was a graduate student
column3: any information about him was protected by the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act. It also would not say whether school officials shared Tokosh’s disciplinary record with other colleges or even if it was standard practice to do so for grad students.

column1: “Due to FERPA
column2: student education records are private
column3: ” said Emily Vincent
column4: a university spokeswoman. “Also
column5: we do not comment on personnel matters.”

column1: When Congress passed FERPA in 1974
column2: its author
column3: Sen. James L. Buckley of New York
column4: said the intent was to protect the academic privacy of students and their families. In more recent years
column5: Buckley has become critical of the law and how schools interpret it. He told the Columbus Dispatch in 2010 that “the law needs to be revamped.”

column1: Survivors of sexual violence and students accuse universities of using the law to avoid negative media coverage. Students with a history of bad behavior may jump from one school to another without the public ever knowing about their histories. Law enforcement records don’t fall under FERPA’s purview
column2: but a wide variety of questionable behavior does.

column1: One case involved Brandon Austin
column2: who was accused of sexual assault at Providence College in 2013 while on the school’s basketball team. But Providence College initially said Austin was suspended for violating the school’s code of student conduct and declined to share further details with the Providence Journal
column3: citing federal privacy laws. Austin denied wrongdoing and was not charged with a crime.

column1: Austin was able to transfer to the University of Oregon
column2: where he was again accused of sexual assault
column3: along with other players. Police investigated the claims
column4: and the local district attorney declined to press charges. The university expelled him anyway but raised FERPA when it declined to release records showing what Oregon knew about the allegations
column5: according to the Oregonian.

column1: LeRoy Rooker was the director of the U.S. Education Department office that oversaw FERPA for more than two decades. Rooker
column2: now a senior fellow with the American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers
column3: said FERPA is not a confidentiality law – it is focused on education records. And it doesn’t apply when a student is “seeking or intending to enroll” at another college.

column1: Therefore
column2: Rooker said
column3: Kent State could have shared information about Tokosh with Northern Illinois.

column1: Rooker also said FERPA would not have prevented Kent State from telling reporters if other universities had inquired about Tokosh
column2: though they could not have disclosed what they shared.

column1: He blamed the overuse of the law on fear of being sued.
“In this litigious age
column2: institutions get a little wonky about whether they will forward
column3: say
column4: disciplinary records
column5: ” Rooker said. “On the other hand
column6: if you have something and you don’t share it when you can and something happens at the next institution
column7: I would say that’s a big liability.”

column1: Backgrounding job applicants has become increasingly complex.
While most U.S. employers conduct background screening
column2: according to trade group data
column3: those inquiries typically focus on criminal history. Social media receives far less attention even though that is where people are most likely to share their unguarded thoughts.

column1: Undertaking a full review of a person’s social media presence is more difficult than just checking an applicant’s Facebook page.
Does an applicant have an account on X
column2: formerly Twitter? How about an account with Discord
column3: an online platform frequented by gamers
column4: where leaked Pentagon documents were recently shared? Or what about a Telegram account
column5: a messaging platform popular among white nationalists? Further complicating things
column6: it’s common on sites like Reddit for users to adopt usernames and describe experiences with little to no ties to reality.

column1: A little digging
column2: however
column3: can turn up a lot of dirt.

column1: Tokosh has a LinkedIn page that includes his teaching stints at Northern Illinois University and Nicholls State University. His time as a student and instructor at Kent State is absent.
For LinkedIn
column2: a custom URL includes a play on his name and his chosen field of study: Joeography. Tokosh would later use that moniker in promotional materials for a class at Nicholls State. That is the same handle used on Reddit by someone with a special interest in face paint.

column1: One post features a video of Tokosh throwing a pie at someone. Other posts mention a “clown fetish.” In a forum titled “Creepy
column2: ” he wrote
column3: “I convince pretty girls to let me paint their faces
column4: ” along with a photo with multiple women in white face paint.

column1: That and other similar posts remained live for years until they were taken down after the Nicholls students published their story in late March.
USA TODAY Network reporters captured screenshots before they disappeared. With dates in 2019
column2: the posts feature a young woman wearing a Kent State T-shirt. The material would have been available to administrators at Northern Illinois before the start of the fall 2019 semester.

column1: Joe King
column2: a spokesman for Northern Illinois
column3: said departments hiring new graduate students are “not required to check social media or investigate a disciplinary history.” He added some departments may reach out to the graduate students’ former advisers.

column1: King said he could not determine if the university was aware of Tokosh’s behavior at Kent State. He said that due to FERPA
column2: he could not share specifics about Tokosh’s time at Northern Illinois
column3: including whether students had complained about him.

column1: But there are signs the behavior continued.

A YouTube account under the name “Joe Tokosh” included at least two videos in 2020 of a man throwing pies at women. One of the videos features a young woman also seen in the screenshots from Tokosh’s Reddit account.
Comments on one from October 2020 read: “You can have a video of her tied up getting pied via cash app.” That video was viewed more than 30
column2: 000 times before it was turned off in late July
column3: around the time a USA TODAY reporter reached out to Tokosh.

column1: A former Northern Illinois State student shared text messages exchanged with Tokosh in which he asked to paint her face on multiple occasions. USA TODAY has agreed not to name her because she is concerned Tokosh might retaliate against her.
In the text messages
column2: Tokosh shared a photo of a young woman in white face paint – an image also posted to the Joeography Reddit account. She said she declined to do it but was aware that other Northern Illinois students had participated.

column1: By fall 2022
column2: when he had moved on to Nicholls
column3: Tokosh revealed to the student that he had required students in his cultural geography class to paint their faces.

column1: The Northern Illinois student asked Tokosh what he did with the photos
column2: and she said he suggested that he might spin them off into a research project someday. She asked
column3: had anyone complained? She said Tokosh responded: Why would they?

column1: Many students would find a reason to complain
column2: as Nicholls State student journalist Sally-Anne Torres learned firsthand. It started in January when one of her fellow reporters picked up an odd rumor: a professor was offering extra credit for students willing to paint their faces like clowns. Initially
column3: Torres dismissed it because it seemed too unusual and there weren’t a lot of leads to follow.

column1: By Feb. 7
column2: university administrators informed Tokosh that his contract would not be renewed
column3: according to an email obtained by USA TODAY via a records request. They gave no reason for the nonrenewal
column4: but on Feb. 12
column5: Tokosh emailed his students that the university was letting him go. He blamed his departure on giving too many A’s.

column1: That seemed suspicious to Torres.
During her reporting
column2: she received a tip about Tokosh’s Reddit posts in which he wrote of his “clown fetish” and how he enlisted his students to participate in it.

column1: “It wasn’t just this innocent thing that a lot of these girls thought it was
column2: ” Torres said. “As a professor or teacher
column3: that is somebody students are supposed to trust. He used his power to ruin that trust and to do these things
column4: and that made me angry for them.”

column1: Torres spoke to six students who shared their experiences with Tokosh. Some
column2: she said
column3: were followed on Twitter by him while others opted into an extra credit assignment he offered.

column1: The women told Torres he sometimes giggled and laughed as they painted their faces in his office.
On March 27
column2: the Nicholls Worth published a story headlined
column3: “Geography professor suspended immediately
column4: students allege sexual harassment.” KNSU TV
column5: a student broadcast network
column6: also aired footage in which Tokosh defended the assignment on camera. That same day
column7: Tokosh submitted his resignation.

column1: The story’s publication prompted other students to come forward about Tokosh and their frustration with the university.

Bradley Price took an online class with Tokosh and said the professor required students to photograph themselves with their faces painted. Price said Tokosh told them the assignment was to help them understand Japanese culture
column2: but then Tokosh offered him bonus points if he could get a female friend to paint her face.

column1: It seemed unusual at the time
column2: Price said
column3: because his friend wasn’t in the class. It became more concerning to him on reading the student newspaper’s report.

column1: “I feel frankly disgusted and disappointed that Nicholls couldn’t do a proper background check on this professor
column2: because this is unacceptable
column3: ” Price said.

column1: Bella Ramos
column2: a junior at Nicholls State who did not take any of Tokosh’s classes
column3: told USA TODAY that someone using the handle @Joeography21 followed her on Twitter in late 2021 and started liking all her selfies.

column1: Ramos learned that the person behind the account was likely a professor at the university. She posted about the behavior in January 2022
column2: but nothing came of it. She also found the Joeography Reddit account. On March 27
column3: the same day the student newspaper published its piece
column4: Ramos posted screenshots of her discoveries on Twitter with the message
column5: “Found a Nicholls state university professor on Reddit.”

column1: “I wish the university had acted sooner because all this information was public on the internet
column2: ” she told USA TODAY.

column1: No one from the university
column2: she said
column3: has ever reached out.

column1: Chris Quintana is an investigative reporter at USA TODAY. He can be reached at cquintana@usatoday.com or via Signal at 202-308-9021.He is on X at @CQuintanaDC. Colin Campo is a reporter for the Houma Courier And Daily Comet. He can be reached at CCampo@gannett.com.

President Joe Biden argued in an Oval Office address that U.S. leadership abroad and congressional aid to Israel and Ukraine is essential. Also in the news: Jim Jordan is giving it a third go at becoming House speaker on Friday and Hollywood film and TV actors near their 100th day of strike.
🙋🏼‍♀️ I'm Nicole Fallert

column1: Now here we go with Friday's news.
The president has made his case for the U.S. backing Israel and Ukraine in their respective wars with Hamas and Russia.
In an address to the public Thursday night
column2: Biden sought to drive home the value of continued U.S. support for the close allies to a war-weary public less than a day after his visit Israel to meet with the country's prime minister.

Lawmakers looked like they were coming close to a deal after Rep. Jim Jordan
column2: R-Ohio
column3: backed a plan empowering Rep. Patrick McHenry
column4: R-N.C.
column5: as speaker until January to get the House moving again. McHenry has already been serving as an interim speaker with limited powers
column6: and Jordan has lost two speaker elections on the House floor. But after an hours-long
column7: closed-door meeting
column8: House Republicans appeared to reject the plan
column9: putting the lower chamber − and the nation − back at square one. But Jordan vowed not to give up his bid for the speakership. Read more

column1: What's the weather today? Check your local forecast here.
A second co-defendant with Donald Trump in the Georgia election conspiracy case
column2: Sidney Powell
column3: pleaded guilty Thursday to a half-dozen misdemeanors dealing with a conspiracy to interfere in the 2020 election. Powell
column4: an election lawyer who baselessly claimed widespread election fraud in 2020
column5: had been charged with racketeering and six other counts as part of a wide-ranging scheme to overturn the election so Trump could remain in power. Powell is the second co-defendant to plead guilty in the case
column6: after Scott Hall. Read more

column1: There is no end in sight for film and TV actors who are striking in what has become the longest work stoppage in the industry's history. The strike by the Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists hits its 100th day on Saturday
column2: while writers are busy back at work after ending their strike.  Negotiations unraveled earlier this month
column3: when studios said discrepancies with actors' demands were too significant to find common ground. The actors union decried their opponents’ “bullying tactics” and said they were wildly mischaracterizing their offers. The prolonged strike means films and TV shows will remain sidelined indefinitely
column4: as buzzy films like "Killers of the Flower Moon" hit theaters. Read more

column1: Ready or not

Six weeks before Hamas’ deadly attack on Israel
column2: a deputy political advisor in the group did an interview with a Lebanese news outlet. Tucked into it was a specific warning.

column1: “We are preparing for an all-out war
column2: ” Saleh al-Arouri said of Hamas. “We are closely discussing the prospects of this war with all relevant parties.”

column1: At the time
column2: his statements were couched as a caution. Israel had plans including targeted killings of leaders of the Palestinian resistance group that controls Gaza
column3: he said. If it followed through
column4: Arouri warned
column5: “a regional war” would ensue.

column1: Those Israeli provocations never happened. Yet by mid-October
column2: an all-out war was under way. Hamas led a surprise attack on Oct. 7
column3: killing more than 1
column4: 300 people including more than 30 Americans and taking at least 200 hostages
column5: and a mounting response from Israel now brings more bloodshed.

column1: Already
column2: Israel has struck a range of targets
column3: and by mid-week announced at least six key Hamas operatives had been “eliminated.”

column1: But Israeli authorities also have launched an international manhunt for another Hamas leader
column2: USA TODAY has learned: Saleh al-Arouri.

column1: They’re pursuing him not just for his insider knowledge of the attack
column2: but for his ties to others – possibly those “relevant parties” he cited in August.

column1: The attack went far beyond what was expected from Hamas alone: A mass border invasion. Drones and paragliders. Withering rocket fire. Precise raids on military surveillance
column2: communications and intelligence hubs. Those plans bear the hallmarks of sophisticated backers from the outside.

column1: Current and former intelligence officials say Arouri sits at a strategic intersection of three entities: Hamas; Hezbollah
column2: the Lebanon-based terrorist group that is considered the world’s most formidable; and Iran
column3: the world’s deadliest state sponsor of terrorism.

column1: If Iran and Hezbollah were involved in the Oct. 7 attack – as security authorities now suspect – someone from Hamas coordinated their assistance. And current and former U.S. and Israeli intelligence officials
column2: and a USA TODAY review of government documents and court records
column3: all point to Arouri as a key link.

column1: Today most of the money that is going to Hamas is coming from Iran, and with the money comes the influence too, said Ehud “Udi” Levy
column2: who served for more than 30 years in Israeli intelligence
column3: including as head of the Mossad’s Economic Warfare Division that goes after terrorists' money. "And the Iran man inside Hamas is Saleh al-Arouri."

column1: More:Is Iran behind Hamas terrorist attacks? What it would mean for US and Middle East security
While experts said they do not yet know what specific role Arouri might have played on Oct. 7
column2: they see him at the heart of a changing − and alarming − dynamic in which these three U.S.-designated terrorist entities are teaming up and further destabilizing the Middle East under the direction of Tehran.

column1: “With him
column2: I cannot go into details about the involvement
column3: ” Danny Danon
column4: an Israeli lawmaker who sits on the Knesset foreign affairs committee
column5: told USA TODAY this week when asked about Arouri. “But I can tell you that Iran is heavily involved with everything that's happening in Gaza – the training
column6: equipment
column7: funding and method of fighting

column1: “We have knowledge of collaboration between Tehran
column2: Beirut and Gaza
column3: ” said Danon
column4: who was also Israel’s ambassador to the United Nations. “We are worried that the technology came from Tehran to Beirut and to Gaza.”

column1: And Arouri
column2: he said
column3: “was heavily involved in that triangle.”

column1: Arouri was a founding commander of the the Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigades
column2: the military wing of Hamas that carried out the attacks.

column1: Despite having spent years under U.S. terror sanctions
column2: and with a $5 million State Department bounty on his head
column3: he has traveled the region
column4: including in and out of Iran
column5: and collaborated with terrorist figures including the head of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps
column6: Qasem Soleimani
column7: before he was killed by a U.S. airstrike.

column1: And Arouri helped build and lead a new Hamas coalition with Iran and Hezbollah that so alarmed Israel
column2: it sought emergency help from the United Nations Security Council in 2017 and again in 2018 to stop him.

column1: Arouri is based in Lebanon
column2: where numerous media reports say Hamas leaders met with top Iranian and Hezbollah officials as recently as April. Now
column3: he’s a prime target as Israel seeks out the strategists behind Oct. 7.

column1: But even after being watched by international authorities for decades
column2: Arouri might not be easy to catch or kill.

column1: “They are looking for him like the Americans were looking for Bin Laden" after Sept. 11
column2: Levy said. "He is a shadow guy. He is under the radar. And believe me

column4: people like that."

column1: Publicly
column2: Israel is pointing the finger at more well-known Hamas figures based in Gaza
column3: including Yahya Sinwar and military chief Mohammed Deif.

column1: “Yahya Sinwar
column2: the ruler of the Gaza Strip
column3: decided on this horrible attack
column4: and therefore he — and the entire hierarchy under him — are dead men
column5:
Israel Defense Forces Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Herzi Halevi said Oct. 12 in his first public statement since the war began. “We will attack them, we will dismantle them, dismantle their system.” 
Arouri lacks the same profile. One of his current titles is deputy chief of Hamas’ political bureau, but sources say Arouri’s role in Hamas has become much more prominent than that. In addition to still playing a role in the Qassam Brigades, Arouri has spent years helping rebuild Hamas operations in the other Palestinian territory blockaded by Israel, the West Bank, according to former Israeli and U.S. counterterrorism officials who have tracked him.  
And, they say, he acts as a chief deputy of sorts to Ismail Haniyeh, one of several Hamas leaders based in Qatar as they try to do political outreach for the group, including to Iran and Hezbollah. 
Five days after the attacks, Arouri offered Al Jazeera Arabic some of the first inside details about the operation, including how 1,200 members of the Qassam Brigades had been given “detailed instructions” about their targets, the Israeli military’s Gaza Brigade, just across the border from the Gaza Strip. 
“We were surprised that the Gaza Brigade collapsed in less than three hours, faster than we expected,” Arouri said.  
Officially, Iran has denied playing a role in the attack even as it congratulates Hamas. President Joe Biden told 60 Minutes on Oct. 15 that there’s no evidence “at this point” that Iran was behind the attack. Israeli officials have made similar comments, stressing that the investigation is in its early stages. 
But U.S. and Israeli intelligence analysts say that if anyone could give the group the ability to launch such stunning land, air and sea attacks against the Israeli military, it would be Iran and its Revolutionary Guard. Even as the hunt for Arouri continued this week, Iran and Hezbollah both raised prospects of openly entering the conflict to respond to Israel’s strikes at Gaza. 
Arouri’s role as an alliance-builder among terrorist organizations has been known to Israel since at least 2018. And his role in raising money and plotting terrorist attacks for Hamas has been known to both governments for a generation.
“It's not just the guys who pulled the trigger or approved the battle plan or gave the final order to do it but the people who are directing all of the strategy and really promoting the (anti-Israel) militarism,” said former FBI counterterrorism analyst and U.S. Treasury terror finance official Matthew Levitt. “And that's Saleh al-Arouri.” 
Yet he has evaded authorities for years.  
“He knows that if he steps anywhere close, we will kill him,” a former top Israeli intelligence official until earlier this year told USA TODAY. He was on the run. You can imagine that there were several plans regarding that
column6: but it just didn't happen.”

column1: Born in the West Bank town of Ramallah

column4: or Islamic law.

column1: Security officials in Israel and the U.S. say Arouri joined Hamas soon after it was formed in late 1987 at the beginning of the first Palestinian intifada

column3: Levy

column2: N.H. — Many candidates in the Republican presidential field are calling for a new generation of leaders in Washington. Former Vice President Mike Pence isn’t one of them.

column1: “It’s not a time for on-the-job training
column2: ” he told a crowd of New Hampshire voters at a town hall sponsored by the USA TODAY Network last week
column3: repeating an argument he’s made time and again on the 2024 campaign trail.

column1: “I’m running for president because
column2: and I do say this with all humility
column3: I’m the most qualified
column4: tested and ready conservative seeking the Republican nomination”

column1: Pence has pitched a more traditional brand of conservatism than other candidates in the race that's focused on Republican values
column2: fiscal responsibility and a strong U.S. military presence. Once deputy to former President Donald Trump
column3: Pence also has offered strong rebukes of his ex-running mate's populist style
column4: arguing it is "unmoored to conservative principles.”

column1: But that argument doesn’t appear to be resonating with voters in the Granite State
column2: or across the country. A recent Suffolk University survey
column3: conducted in partnership with The Boston Globe and USA TODAY
column4: showed Pence at just 1% in New Hampshire.

column1: At the national level
column2: Pence is doing slightly better. A Morning Consult survey on the race
column3: fielded between Oct. 13 and 15
column4: showed Pence at 6% – over 40 points behind Trump. He's also trailing GOP contenders like former United Nations Ambassador Nikki Haley
column5: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy.

column1: So
column2: how is Pence attempting to win over voters? Here’s a look at the priorities he outlined in New Hampshire that would impact Americans coast to coast if the former vice president is elected to the White House.

column1: When it comes to balancing the federal budget and reducing the national debt
column2: Pence has called for reforming mandatory spending programs like Social Security and Medicare – at least for some Americans.

column1: “I’d say to everybody that’s got hair the same color as me
column2: this doesn’t affect you ... we’re not going to make changes to the deal
column3: ” the one-time talk radio host told voters in New Hampshire.

column1: For Americans under age 40
column2: however
column3: Pence said he would opt to privatize Social Security by allowing young workers to invest their payroll taxes into savings accounts. He insisted that the plan would give American workers twice what they earn from Social Security.

column1: The idea has been floated before by members of the Republican Party
column2: most prominently during former President George W. Bush's administration. But it has never garnered enough support in Congress to become a reality for Americans.

column1: As the war between Israel and Hamas rages on
column2: Pence in New Hampshire pledged to unequivocally support Israel
column3: calling the country “our most cherished ally.”

column1: “We’ll make it clear to Hezbollah and Lebanon
column2: to Iran and any other powers in the region
column3: that everybody needs to stand down
column4: ” Pence said. “We’re going to defend Israel.”

column1: During the Trump administration
column2: Pence helped negotiate the Abraham Accords
column3: a bilateral agreement signed by Israel
column4: the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain in 2020 to normalize relations. However
column5: at the town hall
column6: Pence noted that facilitating further peace talks likely wouldn’t be a priority under his administration
column7: given the ongoing war.

column1: “It feels to me like real progress is going to have to take a second chair to Israel doing what it needs to do
column2: ” he said.

column1: Pence offered similarly strong words on other issues of U.S. national security
column2: including ongoing efforts to bolster Ukraine in its war against Russia.

column1: When asked about his views on allocating U.S. taxpayer dollars to aid foreign conflicts
column2: he argued that it’s among the most powerful ways America can stave off future aggression by countries like China.

column1: “China has made no secret of the fact that they would like to grab Taiwan
column2: ” Pence said. The Chinese government views the East Asian island as an extension of its territory and in recent years has ramped up military activity around its shores.

column1: Describing the growing superpower as “the greatest economic and strategic threat facing the U.S.
column2: ” Pence told New Hampshire voters that
column3: as president
column4: he would push to implement tariffs on Chinese goods and expand U.S. military presence in the South China Sea to defend American interests in the region.

column1: “The way we deal with China is not by diminishing our commitment to the Asia-Pacific. It’s by increasing our commitment
column2: ” Pence argued. A strong defense strategy would pave the way toward “a peaceful future with China and progress for the Chinese people
column3: ” he said.

column2: Texas — Democrats in Texas and New Mexico joined forces this week to denounce the concertina wire installed along the Texas-New Mexico border as part of Gov. Greg Abbott's ongoing Operation Lone Star to limit crossings.

column1: Coils of razor wire were recently installed along the Rio Grande near Sunland Park
column2: New Mexico
column3: which neighbors El Paso. Abbott said migrants were bypassing miles of wire and fencing along the Texas side of the Rio Grande by moving west.

column1: Migrants are entering New Mexico illegally then crossing into Texas, he said earlier this month on X
column2: formerly known as Twitter. "We are stopping it."

column1: The Texas Military Department said the newly installed razor wired north of Downtown El Paso across from New Mexico's Sunland Park builds in the 18 miles of concertina wire the National Guard has laid on El Paso's border with Mexico.
We are now fortifying the border between Texas and New Mexico to block migrants, the Texas Military Department said in an unsigned statement.
'Recipe for death:'Migrant deaths more than doubled in El Paso Sector after scorching heat
In a joint statement released Tuesday
column2: Texas Democratic Party Chair Gilberto Hinojosa and Democratic Party of New Mexico Chair Jessica Velasquez blasted Abbott's move as a "stunt funded by the working Texas family's tax dollar that will result in environmental damage
column3: community division and injuries of vulnerable migrants."

column1: It's clear that Gov. Abbott has no plans on actually addressing our broken immigration system head on, Hinojosa and Velasquez wrote in the statement
column2: "but instead adding more fuel to Operation Lone Star's dumpster fire."

column1: The concertina wire strung along the Texas-New Mexico border is the latest in a string of efforts made by Abbott to stem border crossings by record numbers of asylum-seekers entering the U.S. Since August
column2: authorities have encountered more than 2.2 million migrants along the U.S.-Mexico border
column3: according to the latest Customs and Border Protection (CBP) statistics.

column1: What began as razor-wire along the Rio Grande and morphed into a floating barricade in the middle of the river has now transformed into an interstate conflict.
New Mexico Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham
column2: a Democrat
column3: did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

column1: In their statement
column2: the state party chairs praised New Mexico as having "some of the most humane
column3: people-oriented immigration laws in the country."

column1: New Mexico Democratic leaders believe that everyone who comes to our country in pursuit of a better life, as an asylum-seeker or otherwise, deserves just and humane treatment, and the laws of New Mexico reflect those values, the statement read. "Greg Abbott knows that our neighbors in New Mexico are not the enemy but is working overtime to gain Fox News airtime to cover up his proposed legislation to implement unpopular school voucher scams
column2: imprison vulnerable migrants and their families
column3: and his own party's public infighting."

column1: Abbott told a conservative audience during a trip to New York City late last month that migrants were bypassing the miles of razor wire along the Texas side of the Rio Grande near El Paso.
'New normal':High number of migrants crossing border not likely to slow

Not only are we building a border of barriers between the border of Texas and Mexico, Abbott said during a Sept. 27 appearance sponsored by the Manhattan Institute. "We're also having now to build border barriers between Texas and New Mexico."

Texas and New Mexico Democratic party leaders asserted in their joint letter that both Republicans and Democrats acknowledge that "harmful border stunts" serve only to make the crisis at the U.S.-Mexico border even more dire and called on Abbott to remove the barrier.

Shame on Greg Abbott for using public tax dollars to uplift his dangerous approach to border security and infringing upon Texans' and New Mexicans' right to move freely across state lines, the statement read. "Texas and New Mexico Democrats condemn Abbott's razor wire fencing along our state borders and call for its removal effective immediately."
In August
column2: there were 232
column3: 972 migrant encounters
column4: either arrests or detainments
column5: at the southern border
column6: the most since December 2002
column7: according to Customs and Border Protection.

column1: Customs and Border Protection officials said migrants without any legal basis to stay will be processed for removal and face consequences that include a minimum five-year bar on re-entry
column2: loss of eligibility to access lawful pathways
column3: and prosecution for repeat offenders.

column1: But for many migrants
column2: who travel hundreds
column3: if not thousands of miles
column4: many with their families
column5: to get to the U.S.
column6: they may think it's worth the risk
column7: said Victor Manjarrez
column8: a former Border Patrol chief in the El Paso sector and the director of the Center for Law and Human Behavior at the University of Texas at El Paso.

column1: Adam Isacson
column2: director of defense oversight for Washington on Latin America (WOLA)
column3: a nonprofit advocacy organization
column4: said while there may be a lot of policies migrants have to contend with
column5: many of them might assume it can't be as bad as what they've endured to get to the U.S.

column1: When you compare risking your life going through a jungle, a desert, or the Rio Grande to escape living in a dangerous slum in Caracas (Venezuela), Isacson said. "Compared to that kind of life
column2: they probably think there's no level of misery that these policies can impose that is worse than what they are fleeing from."

Smalltooth sawfish are categorized as ray

column3: showcasing gills and mouths on their undersides
column4: the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association (NOAA) Fisheries states. The marine creatures get their name from their distinct rostrum - a long
column5: flat snout edged with teeth - that looks like a saw. They are usually olive gray to brown on top and have a white underside.

column1: Sawfishes belong to a group of fish called elasmobranchs that include rays
column2: skates and sharks. Elasmobranchs have no bones. Their skeletons are instead made of cartilage.

column1: The pups are born fully developed at a length of approximately 2 feet
column2: with their sawfish teeth covered by a thick material that dissolves within a few days/weeks. This adaptation protects both the mother and other siblings while in utero.

column1: Smalltooth sawfish typically live in tropical seas and estuaries of the Atlantic Ocean
column2: the NOAA states
column3: preferring shallow
column4: coastal waters. In the U.S.
column5: they can be found in Florida’s coastal waters.

column1: Two adult smalltooth sawfish have lived at SeaWorld Orlando since the 1980s. The duo currently resides in the 700
column2: 000-gallon Shark Encounter main habitat and have the title of the largest fish in the park.

column1: In late May
column2: the marine center's veterinary teams discovered through ultrasound that the female sawfish was pregnant. Given the significance of this development
column3: the female sawfish was relocated to the Aquarium Health Center so that she could be closely monitored through the birth of the pups.

column1: The aquarium does not intend to put them the pups on display just yet. They will remain behind the scenes as they grow and develop under supervision.

column1: Vice President of Zoological Operations at SeaWorld Orlando

column1: Sawfish Recovery Coordinator for the NOAA
column2: Adam Brame

column1: These young sawfish will provide a great opportunity for researchers and aquarists to learn more about juvenile growth and development, said Brame

column1: The only species of sawfish to be found in U.S. water
column2: smalltooth sawfish are critically endangered and were the first marine fish to be protected by the Endangered Species Act twenty years ago
column3: following a significant decline in population from habitat loss and unintended capture by fishers.

column1: Efforts are being made to protect these species from becoming extinct with the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) developing the Sawfish Species Survival Plan to help facilitate the future reproductive success of these animals.

column1: An avid distance runner in Raleigh
column2: North Carolina
column3: diagnosed with a terminal neurodegenerative disease
column4: decided to enter what she thought would be her last race. Instead
column5: she ended up doing 50 more.

column1: For years
column2: Andrea Lytle Peet
column4: had competed in triathlons and even a half-Ironman. But in 2014
column5: after noticing her times were slowing and her muscles weren't as strong as they used to be
column6: she discovered she had ALS
column7: commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease.

column1: In six months, I went from the strongest I've ever been to walking with a cane, said Peet. "I was shocked and sad in the moment
column2: but I also realized that I had no more time to waste in this life."

column1: Doctors told her the typical life expectancy for someone with ALS is two to five years. She decided she wanted to use her time and her body in a way that she loves.
Neither of us really knew what the disease had in store, said David Peet
column2: Andrea's husband and caregiver.

column1: She bought a recumbent trike
column2: sometimes used in races as an accessibility alternative
column3: and competed in what she believed would be her last triathlon.

column1: I came in last by almost an hour, but people stayed to watch, she said. "This was really a profoundly moving experience."
It encouraged her to keep going. While her muscle movement was declining
column2: she appeared to be defying the grim prognosis she'd been given. Before she knew it
column3: Andrea had completed marathons in every state — the first person with ALS to do so. Her 50th one was in Alaska.

column1: Watch the moment Andrea crosses the finish line in the video below after competing in 50 races.
Since then
column2: Peet has written a memoir and been the subject of a documentary about her experience.

column1: I hope that it can be used to show people how to take on whatever marathon is in their lives, whether it's ALS, whether it's anything, said David.
Peet says she always feels better when she rides and can feel her muscles move
column2: even though the disease gradually removes muscle control.

column1: The worst thing that happens to you, it doesn't define you unless you let it, said Peet. "If you just put one foot in front of the other
column2: there's really no telling where you can end up."

column1: Sidney Powell – his former legal adviser

column1: In a Nov. 14

column1: At the news conference

column1: People with even a pinky toe still dipped in the pool of reality knew at the time that was nonsense

column1: So the Kraken pleading guilty does three significant things:
For all her zany nonsense – which was featured over and over on Fox News in the wake of the 2020 election

column1: Ready or not
column2: winter is coming − but how bad is it going to be? Federal forecasters from NOAA's Climate Prediction Center gave us their answer Thursday in an annual winter outlook.

column1: NOAA said the U.S. winter of 2023-24 will probably be dominated by the effects of what could be a powerful El Niño. That means a mild
column2: dry winter is likely on tap for much of the northern tier of the U.S.
column3: while the southeastern U.S. should see a wetter-than-average winter.

column1: The center's forecast covers December
column2: January and February
column3: which is known as meteorological winter.

column1: Warmer-than-average temperatures are favored across the northern tier of the U.S. and much of the far West
column2: NOAA said. The greatest odds for warmer-than-average conditions are in Alaska
column3: the Pacific Northwest and northern New England. No parts of the nation are forecast to to be colder than average
column4: according to the forecast.

column1: As for precipitation
column2: wetter-than-average conditions are most likely in northern Alaska
column3: portions of the West from California to the south-central Rockies
column4: the southern Plains
column5: the Gulf Coast
column6: the Southeast and the lower mid-Atlantic
column7: NOAA predicts.

column1: “An enhanced southern jet stream and associated moisture often present during strong El Niño events supports high odds for above-average precipitation for the Gulf Coast
column2: lower Mississippi Valley and Southeast states this winter
column3: ” said Jon Gottschalck
column4: of the Climate Prediction Center.

column1: The wet conditions across the South should help ease the drought in the region: "El Niño
column2: with its enhanced precipitation
column3: is expected to provide drought relief to the southern U.S. during the next few months
column4: ” said the Climate Prediction Center's Brad Pugh.

column1: As for where a dry winter is likely
column2: the greatest odds for drier-than-average conditions are forecast in portions of the northern Rockies and central Great Lakes region
column3: especially for Michigan and northern Ohio and Indiana.

column1: The main factor federal climate scientists use to forecast winter weather is the strength of El Niño or La Niña
column2: climate patterns that affect weather in the U.S. and around the world. The entire natural climate cycle is officially known as the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO)
column3: which swings between warmer and cooler seawater in the tropical Pacific Ocean.

column1: (El Niño is unusually warm water in the tropical Pacific Ocean; La Niña means cooler-than-average water in the Pacific.)
This El Niño
column2: which began in June
column3: is predicted to last through the winter. It could be a "historically strong" one
column4: the Climate Prediction Center said
column5: potentially rivaling those in 2015-16 and 1997-98.

column1: Let it snow?:Winter predictions start as El Niño strengthens. Here's what forecasters say.
The forecast released Thursday predicts only where above- or below-normal temperatures – and above- or below-normal precipitation – are most likely.
This winter forecast does not specify how much precipitation will fall as rain
column2: snow or ice
column3: only that more or less is likely overall. Snow forecasts depend upon the strength and track of winter storms
column4: which generally cannot be predicted more than a week in advance
column5: the center has said in the past.

column1: As for the 50 million Americans who live in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic

column1: How cold and snowy will US winter be?:Why October snow in Siberia could hold the answer.

Climate patterns such as the Arctic Oscillation – which can unleash intensely cold temperatures across the central and eastern U.S. – aren't included in this official forecast at this time because they can't be predicted more than one or two weeks in advance.
Other large-scale climate patterns in the atmosphere that can influence winter weather include the Madden-Julian Oscillation
column2: which can affect the number of heavy-rain events along the West Coast. It also can contribute to other extreme events in the U.S.
column3: including Arctic air outbreaks during the winter months across the central and eastern portions of the nation
column4: the Climate Prediction Center says.

column1: The forecast does also not factor in Siberian snow cover
column2: which other forecasters use as the basis for their winter weather forecasts.

Rep. Patrick McHenry, R-N.C., was chosen to be acting House speaker from a succession list that McCarthy provided to a House clerk in January in case his seat became vacant.
McHenry is serving his 10th term in Congress and represents the 10th congressional district in North Carolina. He is a McCarthy ally and chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, a role that helped him negotiate the debt limit deal earlier this year.
He was appointed in 2015 by then House Majority Whip Steve Scalise, R-La., to serve as the Chief Deputy Whip, helping Scalise build agreement around a conservative policy agenda for the House Republican Conference. 
−Sudiksha Kochi
No. 
Technically, Rep. Hakeem Jeffries could be elected, as there are no requirements for the speaker to be from the majority party (or even a member of Congress). In both rounds of voting this week, Jeffries has received 212 votes, the full backing of House Democrats and more than Rep. Jim Jordan both times.
However, the New York Democrat would still need five more votes to hit the necessary 217.
Despite infighting among Republicans, it's very doubtful any lawmaker on the right, let alone five, will cast a vote across the aisle.
−Savannah Kuchar
The number of votes needed is determined by a majority of House lawmakers present and voting.
On Tuesday, that number was 217. Because no lawmaker received 217 votes in the first election, the speaker race continues today.
When the vote for speaker begins Wednesday, members will have a roll call vote to determine how many are present and voting − and how many votes are needed to win. Then they will be called on individually to cast their vote for a speaker.
Voting could last several rounds Wednesday or be postponed until another day if a speaker isn't elected during the second try.
– Candy Woodall
Former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., had a rocky start to his reign as speaker. He went through 15 rounds of voting to get elected and had to make concessions with hard-line conservatives who opposed him.
But once elected, his detractors' frustrations only grew, particularly during debt ceiling negotiations between McCarthy and President Joe Biden
The boiling point of his speakership hit late last month when McCarthy worked with Democrats to pass a stopgap measure, also known as a continuing resolution, to avoid a government shutdown.
Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., who criticized McCarthy for the measure, introduced a motion to vacate and remove McCarthy as speaker.
Eight Republicans and 208 Democrats voted to oust him. The eight were Rep. Andy Biggs of Arizona, Rep. Ken Buck of Colorado, Rep. Tim Burchett of Tennessee, Rep. Eli Crane of Arizona, Gaetz of Florida, Rep. Bob Good of Virginia, Rep. Nancy Mace of South Carolina and Rep. Matt Rosendale of Montana.
– Sudiksha Kochi
Rep. Jack Bergman, R-Mich., is prepared to step up" and serve as House speaker to help lead the party out of the chaos both it and the nation currently face

The USA TODAY Opinion section publishes analysis
column2: argument and essays on a wide variety of subjects. We're looking for timeliness (pegged to news)
column3: persuasion pitched to the other side
column4: new information
column5: novel arguments
column6: revelatory insights
column7: passion without partisanship
column8: first-person experience
column9: original reporting that reveals fresh angles and makes news
column11: and/or a topic that will drive conversation on social media and in the real world.

column1: We accept only pieces that are submitted exclusively to USA TODAY. We do not accept material that has been published on blogs
column2: social media or anywhere else.

column1: Columns typically run 550 to 750 words. They should be pasted directly into an email and sent to theforum@usatoday.com. Pieces should include links (URLs
column2: not headlines or footnotes) to back up quotes and factual material. People featured in columns must be identified by their real
column3: full names.

column1: We do not publish open letters
column2: class projects or material that has been submitted to multiple outlets. Rebuttals to editorials and columns published in USA TODAY should be submitted as letters to the editor
column3: not as full-length op-eds.

column1: Due to the volume of submissions
column2: we can’t respond to all columns sent to us. If our Opinion team is interested in yours
column3: you will hear from us within three business days.

column1: Submissions may be edited for accuracy
column2: clarity
column3: style
column4: standards and length.

column1: Please include with your submission a short biography
column2: two sentences at most
column3: to run at the end of your column
column4: as well as a current photograph
column5: to which you own publishing rights. If you or a business
column6: trade group or other institution with which you are associated stands to gain financially or in any other way from your column
column7: you should disclose that information in detail. In most cases
column8: it should also be included in the body of the piece or in the author's biographical information.

column1: Columns are accepted for online publication; print publication is not guaranteed. All columns published by USA TODAY are available for use online and in print by the more than 250 properties in the USA TODAY Network. They include Austin; Bergen County
column2: New Jersey; Burlington
column3: Vermont; Cincinnati; Columbus
column4: Ohio; Des Moines; Detroit; El Paso
column5: Texas; Indianapolis; Louisville
column6: Kentucky; Memphis
column7: Tennessee; Milwaukee; Nashville
column8: Tennessee; Phoenix
column9: Reno

column1: Authors may post their columns elsewhere 48 hours after they are published at USA TODAY. By submitting a column to USA TODAY and agreeing to its publication
column2: authors are granting exclusive rights to the piece to the USA TODAY Network for 48 hours and non-exclusive rights thereafter.

column1: To get a sense of our range
column2: preferences and requirements
column3: check out our op-ed section
column4: follow us on Twitter and Facebook
column5: or sign up for our daily Opinion newsletter.

column1: If you're interested in joining conversations about topics in USA TODAY
column2: email letters@usatoday.com
column3: comment on Facebook or use #tellusatoday on Twitter.

column1: Letters are edited for accuracy
column2: clarity and length and to conform to our editorial style and standards. Submissions of 200 words or fewer have the best chance of being published. Letters must include a name
column3: address and phone number.

column1: Corrections to published letters or columns follow USA TODAY guidelines.
